story:
Short Summary

We are a mix of 2nd and 3rd year students from The University of Bolton studying Special Effects or Visual Effects for Film and Television.
We have been given a project in which we need to work together to create two futuristic military shots combining physical and Visual effects.

The physical effects team are going to create props such as bullets and guns. The makeup designs will include bruises, cuts and even robotic limbs.
Below is a concept design idea showing some of the makeup effects including a robotic cheek piece and a robotic leg.

Sections of toy guns will be the base for our prop guns, they can then be adapted using materials such as wood and plasticard to change the size and shape. Once this is completed they can be sprayed and painted to complete the look.


The robotic limb will be a cast of the actors arm which will then have panels which have been made to fit the arm using professional quality materials.


The visual effects team are responsible for compositing the shots and creating computer generated images such as helicopters and other futurist machinery.
This is one of our main shots below showing all four characters of which we need to provide military costumes combined with the props and makeup which we will make ourselves all filmed on a green screen and composited together with the computer generated imagery.

To be successful in this very competitive industry we need to build up a portfolio which shows off our work to the highest standard. We have the passion, the work ethic and the talent, (even if we do say so ourselves) we just need to be able to fund our work. 
We need to make the most of every opportunity! This could just be a university group project or we could use this project to improve our skills, gain experience and create high standard images to add to our portfolio.

What We Need & What You Get

This money will help us buy extra products, materials, costumes and equipment needed to create high quality shots. As university students we are provided with some materials but money raised in this campaign will allow us to buy more.
Any money donated to us will be appreciated but why not help us out and get something as a thank you - check out our perks!

The Impact

Our campaign is a test of teamwork and how well each individual will perform in industry conditions. We know we can do this, we just need your help to make this the best it can be.
 

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest risk is not having the money to make our ideas become a reality.
Our challenge in that case would be to try and put together high quality images on a very minimal budget.
If we don’t receive any money from this campaign we will still have to do the work. We have created a list of the essentials and found cheaper alternatives for each product but we know that this will affect the overall look of the shot.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Now we know that some of you will want to help but don’t have the money to spare – well we can definitely relate to you, but there’s still something you can do!
Just share our campaign and get the word out! You might be the reason that someone invests their money and helps us to reach our target - that will be your good deed of the day done!

story:
ITALIANO

Kam Na Yi Nere è una piccola associazione burkinabé-italiana che opera nel settore del sostegno all' alfabetizzazione, all'inserimento sociale, alla conservazione delle radici culturali e allo sviluppo dei talenti di bambini e giovani a Ouagadougou.

Per la realizzazione dei laboratori di alfabetizzazione e fiabe, di introduzione all'informatica e e di insegnamento di danza e musica di quest'estate vi chiediamo di aiutarci a comprare:

  • 15 computer portatili

  • 1 videocamera

  • 1 videoproiettore

  • 2 stampanti a colori

  • 100 pendrive

  • 1 scrivania + 1 sedia (angolo segreteria)

  • 10 ( 4 djembè, 2 dumdum, 2 bendrè, balaphon, maracas)

  • 25 abecedari

  • 50 libri ( album di fiabe e racconti, libri di grammatica, manuali, dizionari)

  • 25 stampe manuali per formatori

  • 100 t-shirt con logo associazione

  • 100 kit cancelleria ( blocknotes, penne, matite colorate, pennarelli, ecc)

  • 35 vestiti tradizionali per i danzatori e musicisti (adulti e bambini)

  • 100 bottiglie d'acqua

  • 100 bottiglie succhi di frutta

- allestimento aule corsi alfabetizzazione e sede corsi danza e percussioni

CONTESTO

Burkina Faso. Capitale:Ouagadougou

Il Burkina Faso è uno dei paesi più poveri al mondo (Programma delle Nazioni Unite per lo sviluppo – UNDP – Rapporto sullo sviluppo umano 2014).

Pop. sotto soglia povertà: 45% Indice sviluppo umano: 181esimo su 187 stati

Indice di povertà multidimensionale:0,508 (Uno dei più alti al mondo) (2010)

Tasso di alfabetizzazione giovanile: 39%

Il 2015 è stato proclamato Anno europeo per lo Sviluppo. La nostra attenzione ome giovane Associazione burkinabé-italiana è quella di partire da piccoli progetti in modo da sostenere l'educazione e l'inclusione sociale di bambini e giovani che risiedono in quartieri disagiati della capitale.

Il percorso estivo che abbiamo immaginato prevedere:

a) la formazione a 18 giovani adulti che continueranno percorsi formativi durante l'anno

b) la formazione di almeno 100 bambini ed adolescenti in 3 percorsi differenti ma intrecciati (atelier alfabetizzazione e fiabe, atelier alfabetizzazione informatica e atelier danze e musiche tradizionali).

I percorsi vogliono mirare a dare strumenti e tecniche ai giovani adulti in formazione e sostenere quei bambini che non possono frequentare la scuola e/o che la frequentano ma non hanno il supporto necessario per poter raggiungere buoni risultati. L'intero progetto non si conclude con gli ateliers ma mira ad essere sostenuto nel tempo grazie ai beni materiali ed immateriali prodotti.

Si tratta di un percorso sostenibile nel tempo grazie agli operatori locali e ai giovani che saranno formati in loco. Tutte le attrezzature servirannoa portare avanti l'alfabetizzazione nel quartiere – uno dei più poveri della capitale -e nelle zone limitrofe.

Gli ateliers, inoltre, intendono accrescere l'autostima, far scoprire i talenti di ciascuno e continuare a tramandare una tradizione culturale ricca e varia ma che rischia di essere persa.

Ecco il perchè del nome in morè della nostra associazione KAM NA YI NERE – Per il benessere dei bambini....e aggiungeremmo per una società più giusta, più critica e più felice!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   

FRENCH

Voici la liste du matériel et des différentes choses à demander pour la réalisation des laboratoires pour l’alphabétisation et les fables, l’alphabétisation informatique et la danse-musique.

-15 ordinateurs portables

-1 caméra

-1 video projecteur

-2 imprimantes (couleur)

-100 clés usb

-1 table et une chaise  (coin secrétariat)

-10 (4 djembè, 2 dumdum, 2 bendrè, balaphon, maracas)

-25 Guides spécifiques pour les artistes

-50 livres (fables, contes, livres de grammaire,….dictionnaires)

-25 copies du guide pour les formateurs

-100 tee-shirts avec le logo de l’Association

-100 kit papeterie (bloc notes, stylos bille, crayons de couleur, feutres etc)

-35 costumes traditionnels pour  les danseurs et pour les musiciens (enfants/adultes)

-100 bouteilles d’eau

-100 bouteilles de jus de fruit

-salle de classe pour les cours d’alph et salle pour les cours de danse et de musique

Contexte :

……………

Le BF est un des pays les plus pauvres au monde (programme Nations Unies pour UNDP-Rapport sur le développement humain 2014).

-Population sous le seuil de pauvreté :  45 %

-Indice de pauvreté « multidimentionnelle » 0,508 % (un des plus élevés au monde)-2010

-Taux d’alph chez les jeunes : 39 %

L’année 2015 a été proclamée « Année Européenne du Développement.  Le but de notre  jeune Association Burkinabé-Italienne est de commencer avec de petits projets de manière à soutenir l’éducation et l’inclusion sociale  des enfants et des

Jeunes qui habitent dans les quartiers pauvres de la capitale.

Le parcours que nous avons imaginé prévoit :

a-la formation de 18 jeunes adultes qui continueront un parcours permanent durant l’année.

b-la formation de 100 enfants et adolescents, divisés en 3 parcours différents reliés entre eux :

  -alphabétisation et fables

  -atelier pour l’alphabétisation  informatique

   -atelier de danse et de musique traditionnelles

Les cours ont pour but de fournir les instruments techniques aux jeunes adultes formés et  de soutenir les enfants qui ne peuvent pas fréquenter l’école et/ou qui la fréquentent sans le support nécessaire pour pouvoir atteindre de bons résultats. La formation n’est pas conclue à la fin des activités mais sera soutenue de manière permanente grâce aux biens matériels et  intellectuels fournis.

Il s’agit d’un parcours d’éducation permanente grâce aux opérateurs locaux et aux jeunes formés sur place.

Le matériel fourni  servira ensuite  à diffuser l’alp dans le quartier, un des plus pauvres de la capitale et de la zone limitrophe.

Les ateliers en outre ont le but d’augmenter l’auto-estime, de découvrir les capacités de chaque participant et de promouvoir et maintenir la tradition culturelle,  riche et variée qui risque d’être oubliée dans le temps.

Voici pourquoi nous avons choisi ce nom pour l’Association : …… »pour le bien-être des enfants »

Nous pouvons ajouter : pour une société plus équitable, plus critique, plus libre et donc plus heureuse !

MERCI

story:
Niki Reina-Guerra and Nicaragua

Niki Reina-Guerra is an amazing 5th grade teacher at Willett Elementary School in Davis, California.  She has nurtured and taught hundreds of our children in Davis.  And she is passionate about furthering the education of Nicaraguan kids, too.  A group of Niki's former students and their parents are raising funds to send Niki back to Nicaragua in summer of 2015 to help construct another school -- she will lay bricks, mix cement and build that school!  The funds raised help pay for the school including the rebar, wiring, plumbing, bricks and so on as well as Niki's housing and travel.  Please help by donating $5 or $10 or $500!  Many small donations make the goal light!  If you want to give Niki an end of the school year gift, please donate to her dream of helping to build another school.  If you cannot contribute money, that's ok!  We hope to send Niki with duffle bags full of new or gently used school backpacks and children's Spanish books.  And you can help at our garage sale - anything you can donate will help us raise funds.

What is Seeds of Learning?  Watch the video at www.seedsoflearning.org and you will understand Niki's love of this non-profit.  Seeds of Learning or "SOL" is a small but mighty non-profit whose sole mission is to further education in Nicaragua.  Since its inception in 1991, SOL has constructed or remodeled 152 classrooms in 55 communities in Nicaragua.   After a school is built, SOL matches the school in Nicaragua with a sister school in the United States.  Niki's 5th grade class at Willett Elementary is the sister school with Palo de Agua, a very small rural elementary school that Niki helped build in 2009.  You can see the video at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ekbVBx24GM from the 2009 workgroup.  Niki's 5th grade students continue to write to the students at the Palo de Agua elementary school.  The strong bonds between our communities will be lifelong because of Niki.Short Summary

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My friend Dawson and I (Adam) will be traveling to Nepal this summer to help out Medic Mobile. Our blog is www.gogivelearn.com.

Adam:

I have have had the opportunity to travel internationally, including a month-long mission trip to Uganda and 10 months in Peru and Ecuador. These international experiences have instilled in me a global awareness and concern.

This summer Dawson and I wanted to do a purposeful trip before starting college in the fall. I was moved and motivated to help in Nepal after seeing the horrible destruction of the earthquake.  After making a few contacts, we were invited and assured our skills would be useful and make a difference. For me, those skills are photography and videography.

My future goals are steeped in my life’s experiences. I engage in numerous extracurricular activities including Teens with a Purpose, a community service club at my school; Teen TV, a video program sponsored by the NC Museum of Natural Sciences; and have produced short promotional films for the Lake Eden Arts Festival. I have also served on several mission trips. I look forward to continuing to expand my horizons as well as learning about and helping others.

Dawson:

I have always been interested in art and documenting the world around me, and expressing myself through art has been essential to how I experience the world. I attempt to incorporate this expression through art into everything I do. During my high school career I was involved in several volunteer organizations and activities outside of school. I have also had my artwork displayed in galleries across the country and received awards from art competitions ranging in scale from local to national, along with several commissioned works.

I use artistic expression as a way of self-discovery and to connect with others. Through my drawings of people I gain understanding of others, and myself, exploring and appreciating the differences in culture, age, and life circumstances. While in Nepal I hope to continue to learn and understand the world in a new way. We all have a story. Through art, I pause, notice, and try to tell those stories. 

What We Need

We would like to offset our travel costs and help support Medic Mobile, the nonprofit we will be working with. Airfare to Nepal is not cheap. Our tickets cost $2,000 each. Our vaccinations cost $800 each and we have to buy supplies for rugged hiking/ camping. If we raise more than our expenses, the extra proceeds will go toward Medic Mobile (https://medicmobile.org) and the Light Foundation (http://www.lightfoundation.org).

The Impact

"Medic Mobile builds mobile and web tools to help health workers reach everyone. In the wake of the Nepal disaster, Medic Mobile is deploying Disease Outbreak Surveillance to all 53 health facilities in the most heavily impacted communities outside of Kathmandu. They are also supporting organizations with antenatal care coordination, childhood immunization coordination, disease surveillance, stock monitoring, general communication, and service reporting." Now, more than ever, Nepal needs international support. We will be helping  Medic Mobile and its partner organizations. Some of the things we will be doing are listed below.

1) Support mobile reporting in remote health posts. Involves lots of hiking and some tech briefings from Medic Mobile.

2) Document the deployment of reporting tools and support health posts that have been destroyed and are operating out of temporary facilities.

3) Help health facilities through various methods. Could be hauling supplies, helping set up tents, solving some logistics problems, etc.

Risks & Challenges

We will be living in a tent for the majority of our time in Nepal. Our work will involve lots of hiking to remote places, during the monsoon season, with potential earthquake tremors, disease, and apparently a lot of snakes. It is rugged travel.

We hope that our international experience and previous treks have prepared us for the upcoming challenges, but we know that we will encounter many unknowns. We are taking a two-day wilderness first-aid course before we depart. We also have several contacts in Nepal to help us navigate. 

Ways You Can Help

  1. Any financial contribution is greatly appreciated! 
  2. If you are unable to contribute monetarily, please spread the word about our work. 
  3. Keep the people of Nepal in your thoughts and prayers, and follow our blog at www.GoGiveLearn.com.

Dawson:

 

I have always been interested in art and documenting the
world around me, and expressing
myself through art has been essential to how I experience the world. I
attempt to incorporate this expression through art into everything I do. During
my high school career I was involved in several volunteer organizations and
activities outside of school. I have also had my
artwork displayed in galleries across the country and received awards from art
competitions ranging in scale from local to national, along with several
commissioned works.
I use artistic
expression as a way of self-discovery and to connect with others. Through my
drawings of people I gain understanding of others, and myself, exploring and
appreciating the differences in culture, age, and life circumstances. While in
Nepal I hope to continue to learn and understand the world in a new way. We all
have a story. Through art, I pause, notice, and try to tell those stories. 

  What We Need We would like to offset our travel costs and help support Medic Mobile, the nonprofit we will be working with. Airfare to Nepal is not cheap. Our tickets cost $2,000 each. Our vaccinations cost $800 each and we have to buy supplies for rugged hiking/ camping. If we raise more than our expenses, the extra proceeds will go toward Medic Mobile (https://medicmobile.org) and the Light Foundation (http://www.lightfoundation.org).
  The Impact 
"Medic Mobile builds mobile and web tools to help health workers reach everyone. In the wake of the Nepal disaster, Medic Mobile is deploying Disease Outbreak Surveillance to all 53 health facilities in the most heavily impacted communities outside of Kathmandu. They are also supporting organizations with antenatal care coordination, childhood immunization coordination, disease surveillance, stock monitoring, general communication, and service reporting." Now, more than ever, Nepal needs international support. We will be helping  Medic Mobile and its partner organizations. Some of the things we will be doing are listed below.
1) Support mobile reporting in remote health posts. Involves lots of hiking and some tech briefings from Medic Mobile.
2) Document the deployment of reporting tools and support health posts that have been destroyed and are operating out of temporary facilities.3) Help health facilities through various methods. Could be hauling supplies, helping set up tents, solving some logistics problems, etc.
  Risks & Challenges We will be living in a tent for the majority of our time in Nepal. Our work will involve lots of hiking to remote places, during the monsoon season, with potential earthquake tremors, disease, and apparently a lot of snakes. It is rugged travel.
We hope that our international experience and previous treks have prepared us for the upcoming challenges, but we know that we will encounter many unknowns. We are taking a two-day wilderness first-aid course before we depart. We also have several contacts in Nepal to help us navigate. 
  Ways You Can Help


Any financial contribution is greatly appreciated! 

If you are unable to contribute monetarily, please spread the word about our work. 

Keep the people of Nepal in your thoughts and prayers, and follow our blog at www.GoGiveLearn.com.

story:
This is such a wonderful group of students from a diverse cross section of our community.  We are raising money for Block Cello Straps for the entire Golden Strings cello section.  While this may seem to benefit only the cello students, the entire orchestra will profit because we will be more easily able to take our group out into the community and share our music to a wider audience for years to come.  Check out the straps at cellostrap.com.

We have done some community outreach in the past – our most recent was a performance for the Alliance for Victims’ Rights awards ceremony.  We want to do more performances like this for our community.

Your contribution may be recognized in several ways, of your choosing.  Because we are a public school you will receive a letter signifying your tax deductible donation (provided we have your contact information.)  In addition, if you would like, we will include your name on our concert programs this year to thank you for your donation.

If we do not meet our entire goal, we will purchase as many Block Straps as we have funds for and allow the students to take turns using the straps.

Thank you so much for considering a contribution to our group!

Caryn Neidhold

story:
The Bishop Anstey High School is AMAZING. Established in 1921 and nestled on the outskirts of downtown Port of Spain in Trinidad, it has honed strong, independent-thinking women who have made their mark in all walks of life – from politics to the performing arts. We are leaders, givers and hard workers. Our reputation as “Bishop’s girls” is known far and wide – don’t mess with us!

My name is Sonja, and I'm a proud Hilarian (= Bishop Anstey High School alumna).  I'm also a performer, producer and filmmaker. In commemoration of Bishop Anstey High School’s 100th Anniversary, which is a few short years away (2021), I’ve begun research and production for a film whose working title is "Excellent Women: 100 Years of Bishop Anstey High School".  This is to commemorate our centennial and what we have achieved as graduates of this stellar institution. The film is estimated at US$37,000 (TT$250,000), but at this point we need to get some of the older alumni on record, so we need to shoot these interviews as soon as possible. We’ve already interviewed Miss Shurland, a former (formidable) principal in her 90s and Miss Winifred Rose (an equally formidable student who celebrated her 98th birthday this year). We need some more of those voices, as well as the ones from more recent times! We also need the resources to source key photographs, documents and archival footage that will help us in the quest to make this film an incredible, permanent testament to the school that made us Excellent Women. So we’re asking you to help us raise US$15,000 initially, so we can continue this phase of the process as soon as possible. That will help us to conduct key interviews of the seniors, as well as to continue the research and documentation.

We hope you can help! If you're not in a position to send a monetary contribution, you can still help by sending photographs or clippings of key moments or people (including yourself) to bahsfilm100@gmail.com (300dpi preferred). Or you can send hardcopy information to P. O. Box 10322, St. James, Trinidad.  Please include a brief written explanation of what you are sending (including the year, the occasion and the people in the image, if applicable).

Even if you are not an alumna of the school, won’t you please support excellence and the achievements of women of this exceptional school in Trinidad?

Sonja Dumas is performer, dance practitioner and a filmmaker whose film works include the award-winning documentary, “Julia and Joyce: Two Stories of Two Dance Pioneers” and the Africa Movie Academy Award-nominated “Tickle Me Rich”. She is currently working on a screenplay entitled “Angels Live in Tunapuna”.
