story:
Help a Haitian Midwife With Her Midwifery Certification Exam

Haitian Midwife Ninotte Lubin will sit for the NARM exam in Feb 2013.

Ninotte Lubin, Haitian midwife from Jacmel, Haiti, began her midwifery journey shortly after the earthquake in 2010. She came to work at Mother Health International birth clinic as a translator and quickly began learning about birth and midwifery care through observing volunteer midwives from around the world.  She was asked if she wanted continued to learn the skills of midwifery care with volunteer CNM (certified nurse midwives,) CPM, (certified professional midwives) and OBGYN.  She said, “Yes, I want to help the women in my community, I want to prevent needless deaths of mothers and babies.”  She later joined Olive Tree birth clinic also in Jacmel, and has continued her midwifery education with volunteer midwives as well as educational birth related conferences and seminars. 

In October of 2012, she traveled for the first time out of her country to San Francisco and attended the MANA (Midwives Alliance of North America) conference as well as sat for the NARM* (Northern Registry of Registered Midwives) exam. You can imagine the culture shock as it was her first time out of her country. While she didn’t pass the exam the first time, she scored a 59 and needs 75 to pass the exam. This is phenomenal and she is very close to achieving her goal.

Ninotte will be one of the first Haitian midwives to obtain CPM** certification. Haiti needs more certified midwives to help reduce its maternal mortality rates.  Haiti has the highest rates of infant, under-five and maternal mortality in the Western hemisphere. (UNICEF)  670 pregnant women die per 100,000 live births in Haiti. (UNFPA). Haiti is ranked 36 world-wide in infant deaths with 63.7 children dying per 1,000 births; 71.5 die before they reach the age of 5 per 1,000.

Please support Ninotte today and make a donation of $15 or more. The impact on preventing deaths of mothers and babies in Jacmel will be tremendous. Everyone woman deserves this kind of care, especially during her pregnancy. All money raised will go to purchase her ticket from Haiti to the US and travel related expenses while she is in the US for 2 weeks. Volunteers will house, feed and transport her to and from the airport, exam etc. Thank you for your support and your kindness.

* NARM-North America Registry of Midwives NARM supports a health care system where every family in North America has access to skilled and responsible midwives. The individualized attention provided by the CPM in practice is of critical importance to her role as guardian of normal birth, and to the value of her compassionate maternity care. NARM sets standards for competency-based certification that allow a midwife to support a woman’s right to choose her birth attendants and place of birth and to involve those she identifies as her family in the birth experience. CPMs practice as autonomous health professionals working within a network of relationships with other maternity care professionals who can provide consultation and collaboration when needed.

As numerous studies have affirmed the safety of planned, midwife-attended birth at home, in hospitals, and in freestanding birth centers, NARM recognizes the potential for improved outcomes that include lower costs and fewer interventions to childbearing mothers and their babies when attended by Certified Professional Midwives.

 

**A Certified Professional Midwife (CPM) is a knowledgeable, skilled and professional independent midwifery practitioner who has met the standards for certification set by the North American Registry of Midwives (NARM) and is qualified to provide the Midwives Model of Care. The CPM is the only midwifery credential that requires knowledge about and experience in out-of-hospital settings.

story:
This project helps some of the poorest children on our planet. It takes a village to educate our planet's children. 

Short Summary

On the morning of September 11, 2001, I found myself and 12 of my students on a ship in New York harbor approximately 2000 feet from the World Trade Center when it was attacked.  This terrible experience convinced me that we need to reach across our world, not with guns and bombs, but with education and peace.  I began a project called the Global Coalition for Peace, Education and Cultural Awareness:

http://bcsd.k12.ny.us/middle/global/global.htm

This project connects students and teachers around our planet.  Our schools have collaborated to assist local volunteers from New York's capital region to build schools in Africa and Belize.  I have a 12 year proven track record of sending hundreds of impoverished children to school and funding the construction of more than five schools.  This coming year, in July, 2014, I want to personally travel to Uganda to help rebuild a broken down school and train teachers in several schools.  I want to supply the schools with technology and teaching materials that will enable them to provide some of our planet's most impoverished children with a worthwhile education.

What We Need & What You Get

I will be traveling with a valid registered non-profit, The Giving Circle Inc.,

http://www.thegivingcircle.org/

which has a proven track record of building schools and creating sustainable projects in Uganda.  The Ugandan government has a supportive working relationship with The Giving Circle Inc..

My original asking goal is $10,000, but my ultimate goal is $60,000.

 

The funds will purchase laptop computers, projectors, a generator, solar panels, books, maps, videos and an assortment of teaching materials to provide for two schools that already have a proven working relationship with the Giving Circle.   I will spend my time there training teachers in their utilization and classroom tools. I will travel to Uganda during July, 2014.

If I can raise more money - up to an additional $50,000, it will go to reconstruct a broken down school in the Jinja District of Uganda.  

 

The Impact

Uganda's children are some of the most impoverished on our planet.  There are over 2 million orphans.  By educating Uganda's children, we are creating a sustainable path toward improvement for both individuals and the nation.

I have a proven track record for success.  I am willing to provide any needed references and will follow through with this project.  Even if just a portion of the money is raised, I am already committed to this project and will find a way to make it succeed.  Our planet's children are our world's greatest hope.  They face challenges far greater than any previous generation.  Only through education can we make a real difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

I also coordinate an International Children's Art Auction each spring at my school.  We receive art from children around the world, along with donations from local artists.  The money we raise goes directly to funding projects.  Last year we were able to help fund the construction of a kitchen for Ugandan children.  Any donations of sellable art can help.  You can also contact the Giving Circle Inc. and volunteer.

Please spread the word about this project.   Together we can make a difference

Mohatma Gandhi once said "We must become the change we want to see in the world."  As a teacher, learning that I can change the lives of our planet's most impoverished children, and teaching others that they can do the same has given my life value.  Our children must be educated to be able to become our planet's next (and better) generation of global leaders.  Together, we can make this happen.

Please help spread the word about this project.

Peace,

Bill Reilly
story_txt:
This project helps some of the poorest children on our planet. It takes a village to educate our planet's children.  Short Summary
On the morning of September 11, 2001, I found myself and 12 of my students on a ship in New York harbor approximately 2000 feet from the World Trade Center when it was attacked.  This terrible experience convinced me that we need to reach across our world, not with guns and bombs, but with education and peace.  I began a project called the Global Coalition for Peace, Education and Cultural Awareness:
http://bcsd.k12.ny.us/middle/global/global.htm
This project connects students and teachers around our planet.  Our schools have collaborated to assist local volunteers from New York's capital region to build schools in Africa and Belize.  I have a 12 year proven track record of sending hundreds of impoverished children to school and funding the construction of more than five schools.  This coming year, in July, 2014, I want to personally travel to Uganda to help rebuild a broken down school and train teachers in several schools.  I want to supply the schools with technology and teaching materials that will enable them to provide some of our planet's most impoverished children with a worthwhile education.


What We Need & What You Get
I will be traveling with a valid registered non-profit, The Giving Circle Inc., 
http://www.thegivingcircle.org/
which has a proven track record of building schools and creating sustainable projects in Uganda.  The Ugandan government has a supportive working relationship with The Giving Circle Inc..
My original asking goal is $10,000, but my ultimate goal is $60,000.
 
The funds will purchase laptop computers, projectors, a generator, solar panels, books, maps, videos and an assortment of teaching materials to provide for two schools that already have a proven working relationship with the Giving Circle.   I will spend my time there training teachers in their utilization and classroom tools. I will travel to Uganda during July, 2014.
If I can raise more money - up to an additional $50,000, it will go to reconstruct a broken down school in the Jinja District of Uganda.   
 
The Impact
Uganda's children are some of the most impoverished on our planet.  There are over 2 million orphans.  By educating Uganda's children, we are creating a sustainable path toward improvement for both individuals and the nation.
I have a proven track record for success.  I am willing to provide any needed references and will follow through with this project.  Even if just a portion of the money is raised, I am already committed to this project and will find a way to make it succeed.  Our planet's children are our world's greatest hope.  They face challenges far greater than any previous generation.  Only through education can we make a real difference.
Other Ways You Can Help
I also coordinate an International Children's Art Auction each spring at my school.  We receive art from children around the world, along with donations from local artists.  The money we raise goes directly to funding projects.  Last year we were able to help fund the construction of a kitchen for Ugandan children.  Any donations of sellable art can help.  You can also contact the Giving Circle Inc. and volunteer.
Please spread the word about this project.   Together we can make a difference
Mohatma Gandhi once said "We must become the change we want to see in the world."  As a teacher, learning that I can change the lives of our planet's most impoverished children, and teaching others that they can do the same has given my life value.  Our children must be educated to be able to become our planet's next (and better) generation of global leaders.  Together, we can make this happen.
Please help spread the word about this project.
Peace,
Bill Reilly

story:
Update!

På mindre än 24 h klarade vi målet!!!! Allt som skänks utöver nu kommer gå till boende och matkonstnader under lägret - så det går jättebra att fortsätta bidra - men vi är i hamn och jag kommer köpa biljett när de släpps. 
STORT STORT TACK till alla som bidragit - stort som smått! Ni gjorde det här möjligt! 
-------

HEJ!

Jag är en kodentusiastisk teknikbloggare som utöver studier, extrajobb och små frilansuppdrag driver teknifik.se som har som ambition att utbilda, informera och inspirera om teknik på ett kul och kreativt sätt.

I September 2016 anordnas det fantastiska kodlägret "100 Tjejer kodar" i Barcelona och jag skulle hemskt gärna vilja åka dit för att bli bättre på att koda och blogga om mina upplevelser. 

På en studentbudget är det dock svårt att ha råd med biljetten. Early bird-priset är 5040 SEK, dessa biljetter släpps torsdag 17 mars klockan 12.00. Tidigare läger har sålt ut på 2 minuter. Fler biljetter kommer släppas senare men då kommer även biljettpriset gå upp. Utöver detta tillkommer flygresa och boende. 

Jag behöver din hjälp för att finansiera:

  • Biljett
  • Flygresa
  • Boendekonstnader

Nu hoppas jag att DU som Teknifik-läsare eller bara allmänt peppig och snäll person skulle vilja vara med och hjälpa mig finansiera den här resan. I utbyte kommer du få läsa spännande och roliga inlägg från Barcelona på teknifik.se plus bidra till min fortbildning som kodare - vilket i förlängningen kan göra Teknifik som blogg ännu bättre.

Stort tack!

/Elin Häggberg

story:
Short Summary

My name is Mark McDonald. I am a father of three sons, a firefighter/EMT for the last eighteen years, and a high school science teacher since 2001. In the wake of the tragedy in New Town and after partaking in lock down drills this last year and answering questions from my students about the what ifs, I decided there needed to be a better way for teachers and responders to protect children and so I decided to build ActiveShelter. A demonstration of the app can be viewed by following the link below.

http://fox17online.com/2014/02/20/former-teache...

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking for $50,000.00 USD. This funding will allow me to complete the iOS development, complete the Android platform conversion, and work on implementation and deployment. It will also assist in future updates to the application where features like geolocation and student accountability will become standard.

There are perks for contributing which are outlined below. In addition to those, you will have the gratification of knowing that you are helping to equip your child's, grandchild's, niece's, or nephew's teachers with the latest in school safety. If you are a teacher as I am, you will also know that you are helping to develop a tool for yourself that can enable you to be active in the event of an emergency situation within your building and not render you a victim any longer.

The Impact

ActiveShelter is the first of its kind. This is the only communication tool in existence specifically designed to assist law enforcement and emergency responders as they respond to a threat in our nation's schools. This application has the power to give responders vital pre-arrival information from inside a facility to direct them specifically to  the area of the threat. This will save children's lives and potentially even help limit the number of violent attacks that take place in our nation's schools. ActiveSelter is the newest and most comprehensive application to empower teacher, assist law enforcement, and save the lives of our children.

Other Ways You Can Help

If a financial contribution is not something that you can offer I would ask that you please help me spread the word. Talk to your local school administrators and board members. Advise them of this project. Encourage them to investigate this application further and bring it to your community.

story:
Change a Life. Send a Needy Child to Camp

How can summer camp help a child in need?

Our mission is to provide a once in a lifetime experience to young children who are both disadvantaged, and at-risk.

Non-profit summer camps like the Saint Augustine Lighthouse and Museum serve to keep these kids safe, supervised, and academically engaged between school years.

The camp features themed adventures, projects, and field trips that challenge their skills and build their enthusiasm for science, engineering, math and art. It promotes teamwork and self-confidence, and gives these children a glimpse of possibility, while forging memories that will last a lifetime.

Since starting the Steve Senecal Lighthouse Scholarship Program, Sertoma has been able to raise tuition to give nearly 300 children the chance to be part of experiences they thought only more fortunate children could enjoy. And despite financial hardship, they have each been recognized by their teachers and principals for their academic potential.

This year, our goal is 40 students.  And we’re asking for $8,000 to do it.  $200/per child will cover their tuition, a nutritious lunch, and transportation.  But no matter what we raise, our pledge is to see that every penny that you donate goes toward sending as many kids as we can to camp. 

As for our bona fides…St. Augustine’s Sertoma Club is a group of twenty committed, energetic people who spend our time trying to catch the neediest in our community who fall between the cracks.  We’ve started a computer learning center, music room, and garden in the poorest part of our county; funded an elementary school’s delinquent lunch program; or we’ve simply paid someone’s mortgage or for their medicine because they’d fallen on hard times.  Those, and many more projects, are our bona fides.

Will you help us?  Will you help us show these kids how far they can go when they go with others who truly care?  Please give what you can. Or tell others about us.  Give us a shout out on your social media pages.  Help us create a groundswell.

Each week-long session focuses on a different theme, with plenty of hands-on, interactive adventures and field trips that allow children to immerse themselves in history, while learning science, math and art.

Through scholarship donations from caring people like you, bright, at-risk students can enjoy the summer of a lifetime.

Thank you in advance for your support. 

What We Need & What You Get

This year, our goal is 40 students.  And we’re asking for $8,000 to do it.  $200/per child will cover their tuition, a nutritious lunch, and transportation.  But no matter what we raise, our pledge is to see that every penny that you donate goes toward sending as many kids as we can to camp.  And for you, check out our perks.

The Impact

  1. Provides a safe, supervised environment for at-risk children.
  2. Students get a healthy meal and snack every day.
  3. Fun, physical activities help children stay active, learn teamwork, and build self-confidence.
  4. Activities enhance students’ mental health through time spent learning about Florida’s natural environment.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word by forwarding this message to family and friends. You can also help by posting this link to all of your favorite social media sites. Together we can do this.

story:
Short Summary

I've been teaching Social Studies at Balboa High School in San Francisco for 10 years now. I have a passion for teaching, which many of my students have pointed out to me over the years. We laugh a lot in my classes.

Specifically I am the director of the Law Academy, a two year, humanities-based pathway. I teach the Junior Pre-Law class, and the Senior American Democracy and Economics classes. The kids travel as a cohort to their social studies, lit and pathway elective classes. We have a very large alumni, and we're very proud of the work we've done.

The summer between Junior and Senior year I place our kids in internships at law offices (public, private and non-profit). It's an amazing experience, that they can take to any career.

In 2007 I purchased a MacBook Pro and a Promethean Interactive Whiteboard, through a grant that I wrote. I use this computer every day for PowerPoint and Keynote presentations, video, student presentations, music, and more. It's safe to say that this computer is like another limb. This computer has limped along for a few years now. I've replaced the entire logic board and the screen, as well as run regular diagnostics every few weeks as needed. It's on it's very last legs.

Over the years my presentations have evolved from your typical word-heavy approach, to image heavy, making the kids think deeper, and ask better questions. I've seen their own presentations be more lively year after year. 

There's nothing worse than attempting to open up a presentation for class and the dreaded rainbow spiral of doom doesn't stop spinning!

What We Need & What You Get

I need $2500 to purchase a brand new 13" MacBook Pro 2.6GHz with Retina display.

I will also purchase an external hard drive, and a hard cover for it.

I'll also purchase a remote control so I can walk the room and still utilize the computer.

If I don't reach the goal I'll use what I get to make more repairs on the existing MacBook Pro. Let's hope it doesn't come to that.

The Impact

At my school I'm considered one of the GO TO people when it comes to technology. I've hosted many professional developments in my classroom for my peers. They come to me regarding the creation of PowerPoint's or Keynote, as well as Interactive Whiteboard activities.

I teach the kids how to create powerful presentations, as well as debates. They too will utilize this new computer. By learning how to use modern technology this will guarantee they will rise above the current crop of young talent making their way into the workforce.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, will you please help spread the word far and wide? Indiegogo has a share function that you can use to let your friends and family know about this campaign.

Thanks for all your efforts.

Michael Rosenberg

story:
Why we are asking for funding..

I have been making these videos for about 2 years now.  We have well over 200 FREE tutorials on YouTube as of now.  We have nearly 15 thousand subscribers and over 2,5 million views.  Over the last year, changes with the internet affected my ability to keep pushing as much free content up on the web.
Since I started doing these videos, I was able to spend less time working on development jobs and more time building training videos. Last year I was able to use the YouTube funding to basically cut my work day in half. I spent half my time doing videos and the other half doing development work for clients.
With the popularity of extensions like AdBlock, I have seen an approx. 90% decline in ad revenue since this time last year.  Other tools that allow viewers to illegally download my videos from YouTube and watch them ad free has hurt us as well.
I have the option to limit my future work to subscription based paid websites in order to recoup some of these losses and allow me to allocate the time to make content.  However, I want everyone to have the ability to learn from these videos and would like to raise enough money to keep putting my content on YouTube for all (or most of) the world to watch.
Not to mention most of the paid video websites take 30-75% of the course cost and put it in their own pocket. So us instuctors barely see a profit.
Here is info on our most recent and (possibly most popular) series...

Learn 7 Web Development Languages/Concepts in 1 easy to follow project-based video series!

  1. HTML - HyperText Markup Language: The main language for creating websites.
  2. CSS - Cascading Style Sheets: Define the look and feel of a website.
  3. Javascript -  Used to allow users to interact with a website.
  4. JQuery - Make user interaction with Javascript much easier!
  5. Ajax - Asynchronous Javascript & XML: Interact with data and elements without reloading a webpage.
  6. PHP - PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor:  Create dynamic and database driven websites.
  7. MySQL - My SQL:  One of the most widely used open-source database management systems.


About the 2014 Dynamic Series

The videos are within an ongoing project-based series titled: "Developing a Dynamic Website".  The series started in December of 2013.  Viewers follow me through the steps of building a dynamic website and Content Management System from start to finish.  

What is a Dynamic Website?

Have you ever wondered how websites are able allow a user to register, create profiles, and store personal information? Or, how about an online community with forums and blogs?  Maybe an eCommerce website to load, market, and sell your own products? Well, dynamic websites make that possible!

At the core, dynamic websites can store information in a database and then display it on or even use it to manipulate a webpage.  Possible examples of such data could include: user information, image/photo information, settings, text, even code (which is how this very project summary is being saved and displayed write now!).


Other Series and topics:

We have other on going series as well. I am currently working on creating a brand new (and current) version of our most popular series "Building a Website From Start to Finish".

Building a Website Series:

Our first version of this series was released just before great tools like CSS3 and HTML5 were available for all browsers.  So in that series we use tools like Adobe's Photoshop and Illustrator to layout and design the website.
Now days with CSS3 we can almost eliminate the need to use any graphic design tools.  Along with teaching this newer approach to web design, I will be including lessons on Javascript & JQuery.
This series will then bump right up to the more advanced 2014 Dynamic Website Series.  So those who want to get deeper into the programming side of the web can keep on learning!

New Reference Series:

Another new set of videos I have been releasing is what I call my reference series.  The previously mentioned series focus on project related topics (like making a whole website).  The reference series focuses on individual topics in web design and development.  Almost like a "Book on Video".
We break down languages like PHP, HTML, CSS (etc) into individual topics such as "Arrays", "Databases", "Variables", etc.
This is hope for those who are visual learners can use our free videos rather than reading boring reference manuals/websites.

Where your funding goes...

First and foremost we need some better equipment.  In March of 2014 the workstation that I use to make the videos died on me.  This year I decided to start making all new videos in 1080 resolution (previous in 720).  Making the videos without a good machine is painfully slow.  The machine I am using now is awesome for web development but terrible for audio/video editing.
Other funding helps keep our lights on!  We need to keep our hosting up and running and other bills paid.  To put it simply, the more funding that we receive the less time I need to spend making income elsewhere.  More time = more videos and other resources! 
The current goal is set to accomplish getting a new video editing workstation and allow me to spend the next 2-3 months focusing on videos and not on finding other jobs.  If we meet and exceed the goal I will keep putting 100% focus on videos for as long as the funding lasts! 

Thank You!

Thanks everyone!  I have had a blast these last two years.  I have met many of you both online and during one on one training sessions. I have learned so much about other countries and cultures in the process.
I love making these videos and teaching one on one.  I want to keep on doing it!
(go to thedigitalcraft.com for more info on private sessions)

About the 2014 Dynamic SeriesThe videos are within an ongoing project-based series titled: "Developing a Dynamic Website".  The series started in December of 2013.  Viewers follow me through the steps of building a dynamic website and Content Management System from start to finish.  What is a Dynamic Website?Have you ever wondered how websites are able allow a user to register, create profiles, and store personal information? Or, how about an online community with forums and blogs?  Maybe an eCommerce website to load, market, and sell your own products? Well, dynamic websites make that possible!At the core, dynamic websites can store information in a database and then display it on or even use it to manipulate a webpage.  Possible examples of such data could include: user information, image/photo information, settings, text, even code (which is how this very project summary is being saved and displayed write now!).Other Series and topics:We have other on going series as well. I am currently working on creating a brand new (and current) version of our most popular series "Building a Website From Start to Finish".Building a Website Series:Our first version of this series was released just before great tools like CSS3 and HTML5 were available for all browsers.  So in that series we use tools like Adobe's Photoshop and Illustrator to layout and design the website.Now days with CSS3 we can almost eliminate the need to use any graphic design tools.  Along with teaching this newer approach to web design, I will be including lessons on Javascript & JQuery.This series will then bump right up to the more advanced 2014 Dynamic Website Series.  So those who want to get deeper into the programming side of the web can keep on learning!
New Reference Series:
Another new set of videos I have been releasing is what I call my reference series.  The previously mentioned series focus on project related topics (like making a whole website).  The reference series focuses on individual topics in web design and development.  Almost like a "Book on Video".
We break down languages like PHP, HTML, CSS (etc) into individual topics such as "Arrays", "Databases", "Variables", etc.
This is hope for those who are visual learners can use our free videos rather than reading boring reference manuals/websites.
Where your funding goes...
First and foremost we need some better equipment.  In March of 2014 the workstation that I use to make the videos died on me.  This year I decided to start making all new videos in 1080 resolution (previous in 720).  Making the videos without a good machine is painfully slow.  The machine I am using now is awesome for web development but terrible for audio/video editing.
Other funding helps keep our lights on!  We need to keep our hosting up and running and other bills paid.  To put it simply, the more funding that we receive the less time I need to spend making income elsewhere.  More time = more videos and other resources! 
The current goal is set to accomplish getting a new video editing workstation and allow me to spend the next 2-3 months focusing on videos and not on finding other jobs.  If we meet and exceed the goal I will keep putting 100% focus on videos for as long as the funding lasts! 
Thank You!
Thanks everyone!  I have had a blast these last two years.  I have met many of you both online and during one on one training sessions. I have learned so much about other countries and cultures in the process.
I love making these videos and teaching one on one.  I want to keep on doing it!
(go to thedigitalcraft.com for more info on private sessions)

story:
Our Story

The opportunity of a lifetime..that is what the In Zone Project has proven to be. In January 2011, founder of the In Zone Project and Director of the United Maori Mission, Terrance Wallace saw his vision become a reality.


The vision was to have young Maori and Pacific Island boys from around New Zealand be given the opportunity to attend one of New Zealand's most prestigious schools, Auckland Grammar School for boys. In order for this to happen the boys would live 'in zone' at one of the United Maori Mission hostels. 


As part of their stay at the hostel, the boys were required to participate in leadership and mentoring programs provided. ANZ bank partnered with the project to provide a financial literacy program and the boys were also given instruction in basic social and life skills, providing them with a foundation toward becoming valuable members of society and authors of their own success stories. Please visit our website for more information about our success.


The obvious success of the In Zone project led to an anticipated expansion in for 2012. 50 boys have been interviewed and selected to live 'In Zone'.


The reason for the URGENT appeal is because the doors to the property that was to be home to these 50 boys have been suddenly and unexpectedly shut!


As a result we are required to do some major renovations to an existing alternative property. That's where you come in.


We need both financial support as well as hands on deck if you live locally.


The boys arrive on the 19th of January 2012. They need a 'home' to come to.


The Impact

Within the first year the majority of the In Zone boys excelled academically, school year ending December 2011. One particular student made history having been promoted a total of eight levels over the school year.  At the annual prize giving, we were excited to witness two of our boys receive academic awards and another two awards for sporting achievements. Quite an accomplishment considering the school has 2500 boys attending!


The In Zone boys inspired the entire third form (year 9)made up of 500 youth to learn and perform a traditional Maori Haka for the first time in the school's history.


In October 2011, the In Zone boys were asked to participate in the Rugby World Cup welcoming ceremony as well as the very first reunion for the 1987 All Blacks rugby team.


These and many other accomplishments have greatly impacted, not only the lives of the boys but also their families and communities. More profound is the way they have proven that, given the opportunity they can maximize their potential.


If the hostel's required renovations are not completed the license will not be awarded and the building will be deemed unfit to live in. The In Zone project has no other alternative property. We have the will to succeed just like the boys in the In Zone Project and we believe that this project worth fighting for.



What We Need & What You Get


We need upward of $30,000 to see the hostel's material and labour costs covered. All funds received will be used towards renovations of some kind. The campaign will not cease if the goal is not met through this site we will continue to search for funds until the project is completed so your donation will not be in vain. We will be putting up progress footage as the weeks go on.



Other Ways You Can Help

All hands on deck! - If you are able to help with  on site labour ie. cleaning, stripping paint, pulling out carpet, washing windows, setting furniture etc or if you are a professional in any area of building, carpentry, plumbing, electrical or related trade please contact us via email twallace@umm.org.nz for location and time details.


Spread the word! - Please tell all you family and friends about the In Zone project and the critical situation. Post our appeal video on any social networks or blogs to get the word out!

story:
Hello! We're Scott & Marriya Wright and we're currently in the process of adopting two children internationally - an infant from Armenia and a teenager from Bulgaria. There are approximately 147 million orphans in the world and while we know we can't change the world, we're trying to change the world for two of them.

Anyone who's been through the adoption process knows how very expensive one adoption can be, let alone two. Combined, the two adoptions will cost us approximately $75,000 after all the fees and costs associated with the adoptions and the travel and accomations. We've hosted many fundraisers and continue to do so. We figured starting a campaign on IndiGoGo couldn't hurt because it's possible that one of you has a heart for orphans and for adoption and may be willing to contribute. EVERY dollar helps, and if you don't have any money to contribute, please keep our adoptions in your prayers.

For more information about our cause and to read our blog, you can check out our website at wrightadoptionfund.us. There is also a "support us" link where you can purchase a t-shirt  (a large part of the proceeds benefit our cause). To legitimize our cause, check out Hopscotch Adoptions as it is our adoption agency for both pending adoptions.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read our campaign! Please consider helping us bring our children home by contributing to our cause!

story:
We need your help! Beczak has dramatically reduced its weekend and public programs, and cut staff by more than half. We need your donation to help us stay afloat!

Beczak Environmental Education Center has been in existence in Yonkers, New York for over 20 years and has continually run children and family programs that encourage all to learn about and care for the beautiful Hudson River. Beczak is part of the Hudson River Valley Environmental Education Institute, a very small 501(c)3 non-profit which focuses attention on protecting and teaching about local urban environment of the Lower Hudson Valley region.

This center provides a community gathering place for approximately 20,000 visitors annually to discover, explore and enjoy Hudson River wonders. We educate approximately 10,000 local schoolchildren each year, and that many individuals and families, with the shared goal of improving environmental awareness and understanding of practices which protect our natural world.

The location of an environmental center in such an urban setting plays a vital role in the local community. We offer a variety of free family events such as Summerfest - a daylong event featuring free seining and kayaking along with eco-friendly arts and crafts. In addition, Beczak runs multiple "Catch of the Day" seining programs every for children on school trips, for boy and girl scouts and as a birthday party, which involves catching fish in a 30-foot seine net, and then allowing children, with the help of education staff, to look and and touch the animals that are caught. Beczak also operates a winter, spring and summer camp for children that focuses primarily on cultivating an appreciation for nature and science using live animal specimens, hands-on learning and a whole lot of a getting messy. All of the programs offered help engage the youth of the Lower Hudson Valley and expose them to situations and experiences they might never see again.

We also offer two programs for adults each month. RiverTalks: Smart Conversation about the Hudson, gives oportunities to hear from, and talk to, adventurers, scientists, naturalists and writers. In October we'll host both Tom Lake, editor of Hudson River Almanac, and Jon Turk, who, National Geographic calls "one of the top ten adventure atheletes of 2012."  And for entertainmentl, we host Urban H2O, rocking roots concerts with local and regional talents. This November we welcome Sloan Wainwright to our riverfront space!

We encourage you to come visit Beczak! Inside you will find many tanks filled with critters that were caught right on our waterfront location by children. If you have been to Beczak, or have had a positive experience sending a child to Beczak, or enjoyed a presentation or concert, please consider donating. We want to be around to inspire all ages to learn about the Hudson River and all its creatures for a long time, but this won't be possible without your help! Any contribution, no matter how small will protect and sustain our preserve, living collections and property while providing educational and recreational opportunities loved by the whole community.

Your contribution won’t just keep us afloat…it will help us sail into the future. 

"The students were able to make personal connections to the outside environment and learn about a great opportunity to explore nature within an obtainable distance...the hands on aspect was truly amazing" - Lisa Suraci, 3rd grade teacher, Cedar Place School -Yonkers NY

"Beczak was the coolest place that I ever saw." - Jeremy Oritz, age 5

"Student are able to have an opportunity to learn about the Hudson River which is in their hometown." - Maggie Moneill, 3rd grade teacher, Cedar Place School - Yonkers NY

"Thank you for letting us go to Beczak. I liked Beczak a lot! Thank you, thank! We learned a lot about the Hudson River" - Anais Perez, age 6

"I liked Beczak because I learned about the different kinds of fish in the Hudson River. I saw a big eel and crabs. I can't wait to go to Beczak again!" - Melissa, age 8

"I had a really good time on our class trip! I really liked going in the water and picking up the fish and looking at different animals. I learned a lot of new facts, I would like to learn more about some things. I really had fun!" - Kylie, Greenville Elementary, fourth grade

"We all enjoyed the friendly and informative presentation. It gave us all - young and old - something to think about as we go about our daily lives" - St. John's Church -Yonkers NY.

story:
Konbit - n. (Creole) Community coming together for a common purpose or goal.

Mizik - n. (Creole) Music.

Konbit Mizik is a not-for-profit recording studio & music school in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.  We incorporated as a NYS not-for-profit corporation about a year ago, and are waiting for approval from the IRS for 501(c)3 tax-exempt status.  Most of our operations to date have been venturing into some of the most disadvantaged parts of Haiti, recording underground artists and youth while providing instruction on music theory, audio recording, and video production.  

Our long-term vision is to create a brick and mortar home with state-of-the-art equipment, proficient instructors, and respectful & responsible staff and students, which can serve as the home for an exchange program for professors, students, and musicians from around the world.  In the meantime, we will continue to record Hait's most talented and vulnerable youth, produce music videos and concerts, and develop music curricula and programs in communities throughout Port-au-Prince and across the country.

Konbit Mizik is a movement of smart, talented, and caring individuals from all spectra who believe that, in our increasingly-interconnected global community, it is important to celebrate our common values and acknowledge our collective ability to work, teach, learn, play music and rebuild Haiti together.

Konbit Mizik issues a receipt for your donation with our taxpayer ID number and we require all funds expended be reviewed by John F. Payne Associates, Inc., assuring complete transparency for our donors.  A multi-lingual accounting staff reviews, categorizes, and authorizes every dollar spent.

 

BUDGET (WHERE YOUR $ IS GOING)

Here is our budget for 2012-13 to bring Konbit Mizik one step closer to realizing our dream of viable music education and commercial music production for Haiti's most marginalized youth. 

HAITI EXPENSES (Annual)

Rent - 8,000

Generator (plus inverter, battery, diesel) - 5,450

EDH (Electricite de Haiti) - 900

H2O - 650

Internet and Phones - 900

Haitian Salaries - (Project Director, Outreach Director, Committee Chair) - 2400

Transportation - 1,000

STUDIO

Audio Equipment Apple iMacs (3) with Logic Pro music software - 4000

Portable MPCs with cords (3) - 1,250

MiDi Keyboards (3) - 1,500

Studio microphones (2 sets) - 750

Miscellaneous (cords, surge protectors, soundproofing, fans) - 2000 

CONCERTS/TOURS

Concert Production (6) (Sound system rental, stage construction, security, police, etc) - 3000

Visas for artists (2) - 320

US Transportation costs for artists (flights, auto rental, gas) - 2000

ADMINISTRATIVE

Accountant fees (Quickbooks, IRS tax form preparation, fees) - 1500

International calling (Skype) - 120 

Citibank fees - 228

Tunecore fees (3 new releases, 3 prev. releases) - 300

Library of Congress Copyright fees (3 new releases) - 105

Miscellaneous admin - 400

MISC

Container Shipping - 3,000

IndeGoGo Fees - $1,591

TOTAL:  $41,364

story:
Hello, I'm Lara. Above you can see me planting a tree on my previous trip to Israel. During my eleven-day trip to Israel last February, I planted an acorn of interest, but now I desire to return for a longer stay to see whether that acorn will bury deep roots and grow into a tree. My initial visit instilled in me a strong desire to learn more about this country and my heritage, and ten months there will serve to further me on this quest. This is why I am participating in a ten-month MASA-affiliated program through the volunteering organization Tikkun Olam in Tel Aviv-Jaffa. I study different perspectives on Israeli-Arab relations while living amongst the populations I serve. Volunteering opportunities include working at Arab-Jewish community centers, English tutoring and more. During my stay I will also take Hebrew lessons, tour the country and take lessos on Israeli culture and Jewish identity. Through the intense process of immersing myself in the coexistence movement in Israel, I expect to develop a greater sense of self and sense of purpose in the world. Learn more about the program here: http://tikkunolamisrael.org/

As this is a volunteering program, MASA and Tikkun Olam try to keep it affordable, but there are still considerable costs involved. With the cost of the program, plane tickets, food and other incidentals, it adds up to thousands. Any amount you can contribute would be greatly appreciated. Even if you do not feel you can contribute at this time, I would love it if you share this page with friends who might be interested.

I have always loved learning about different cultures and meeting foreign people on their own terms to gain a well-rounded and complex worldview. The opportunity to engage with Israeli and Arab populations on their own turf will provide me with unique and invaluable insight into the ongoing conflict and the concurrent efforts toward coexistence. I truly believe in the Jewish tenet dictating that it is each person’s duty to repair the world ("tikkun olam"). While our global and local communities are slowly progressing toward acceptance and inclusion of all kinds, it takes strong people diligently holding the line to ensure society does not backslide into hatred, prejudice and violence. I have the will and the powerful desire to dedicate myself to facilitating peace and understanding among individuals and their surroundings at large. All people are inherently equal, regardless of sex, race, or ability, and I strive to put an end to domination ideologies and oppressive systems.

Thank you for visiting my page!

story:
Who is Spectrum?

Spectrum is the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga's LGBTQ+ organization! 

We work to provide a positive and affirming safe-space for LGBTQ+ college students and allies in Chattanooga, TN. We are also engaged in activism efforts to ensure that UTC will one day be as LGBTQ+ friendly as we are. 

We have grown exponentially in the last couple of years and our old budgeting systems are not cutting it. We are now one of the largest organizations on campus (excluding Greeklife and Religious organizations) but we do not receive adequate SGA-funding comparable to similarly-sized organizations. 

In part, we were able to grow so large due to a gift-grand which funded Spectrum from 2013 until about now. 

With that funding, Spectrum has been able to institute all sorts of new programming including the invitation of speakers on campus such as Everyone is Gay in fall of last year. 

Pictured: The Spectrum Executive Board with Everyone is Gay!

We have also have worked to bring safe queer sex education through our allies at Chattanooga CARES. In partnership with the UTC Counseling Center, Spectrum also created a peer counseling group focused on LGBTQ+ college students called 'Talk It Out'.

These programs stand alongside our Rainbow Shield protests of homophobic conservative speakers, our ability to assist UTC students attending LGBTQ+ conferences, our trip to confront homophobic politicians on the Senate Education Committee in Nashville, and many other events and programs. 

We are proud to have been able to bring so much, in such a short time, to UTC's campus. 

Now, in order to maintain our momentum, we would like to ask your assistance for our 2014/2015 operative costs.

Pictured: Spectrum's Rainbow Shield


What Does Spectrum Need?

We don't need too much! Here is a breakdown of what we will need going into the next semester

  • A Printer/Copier: Spectrum has too long been at the mercy of the Lupton Library printing costs, particularly for the cost for color images. We need to get a large amount of brochures and other rhetoric into the UTC general population. If we were to have our own printer (to be kept on campus in a space provided by an ally) then this would make the printing process much easy. Estimated cost: $150
  • A Professionally-made Banner: A banner with our Spectrum logo which would be used for our booth at the UTC Org Fairs and our events throughout the year such as National Coming Out Day. Estimated cost: $150-200 dollars
  • Spectrum Swag: We'd like to go into the 2014/2015 year with a bunch of Spectrum pens, notepads, and buttons and other things to hand out to students who attend our meetings. Estimated cost: $300 dollars
  • Other Operative Costs: These money will be put into Spectrum's bank account to be spent on miscellaneous things to provide for the Spectrum organization fairs and first Fall 2014 meetings. This would include posters and other items. In the past, extra things have been mostly restricted to skittles and starbursts but a larger budget will enable us to think big in the years to come! Estimated cost: $150-200

Your Impact:

Spectrum members come from a lot of places. Small-town Tennessee is often not the best place to be queer or even any other sort of different. Students come to our meetings and see our booths and, you can tell, the supportive space which Spectrum provides has made a world of difference in their lives.

Students flee situations of violence and situations of oppression to come into our campus community and, in that campus community, Spectrum has been able provide for students as safely and affirming as possible. 

We want to keep doing that! If you are able to donate towards an operative budget, it allows our organization to reach out even further to UTC students across the campus. It allows us to get bigger and better quality. By donating to the operative budget, we are able to devote what other funding we can manage toward new programming with the resident housing groups, wider community groups, and off-campus speakers.

We would like to thank you for anything that you can contribute! We find our work with Spectrum to be some of the most rewarding work in our college careers. We hope you find contributing to the organization equally as rewarding!

We are also engaged in activism efforts to ensure that UTC will one day be as LGBTQ+ friendly as we are. We have grown exponentially in the last couple of years and our old budgeting systems are not cutting it. story:
Short Summary

My first exposure to classical guitar was during a guitar lesson when my teacher played for me a short prelude by Bach (BWV 999).  I was so moved by the the composer's work that I decided in that moment to devote my life to the study of the classical guitar and its repertoire; I had found my calling.  Since then I have overcome the challenges of starting a classical instrument at the age of seventeen and have matured through my undergraduate (Temple University) and graduate studies (The Hartt School).  My graduate experience was especially positive in which my musicianship and technique developed substantially.  What I learned from my time at Hartt enabled me to realize my dreams and begin a career as a concert performer and teacher of the classical guitar.  Two years after completing my Master's, I was invited back by the Hartt School to embark on a Doctorate!  Despite being offered a humble scholarship, I accepted the offer to take advantage of the opportunity to broaden my musical knowledge and refine my guitar playing.  Your contribution will be invaluable in supporting my education endeavors and growth as a musician & performer. 

Lets Get Specific

Tuition for one year after my financial awards comes to a total of $13,380.  Funds I raise during this campaign will go toward the tuition costs mentioned above.  Additional funds will go toward my second year of study. 

I'm offering a number of perks that include my performance and teaching services.  I look forward to working with or performing for you!

The Impact

Supporting this campaign is supporting my life and work as an artist.  If you appreciate my work as a performer and/or teacher and feel that it has value, then please consider showing your support.  More broadly, I am one of a relatively small number of people who is devoting my career to the study, performance and teaching of classical music, a 500 year tradition that so beautifully details the human experience.  If you value this tradition and want to see it thrive through this generation and into the next, please consider showing your support.

story:
Help Children With Dyslexia  

Since September 15th 2006, Giving in Action has done whatever possible to help better the community in the cities around Atlanta, Georgia. From hosting Homeless food drives to creating a Raising Readers Program, Giving in Action does all that it can to help keep a smile on the faces of those who need help with issues they have to face every day. 

We are currently focusing on the Raising Readers Program. The Program will offer professional development and mentoring to children. These children will receive a collection of high quality books selected according to their appeal and age. We hope to buy the Lexia Learning software, which will help children with recognizing letters. This program will help children from low income families and eventually help adults with the same reading problems as well. The parents of these children are very anxious to get help for their children.

Our Goal

Giving in Actions wants to improve students academic performance by the programs eight week conclusion. The program hopes to insure that 75% of the students will gain interest in reading, far beyond the current 25%. The organization also plans on improving the attention span of students by a minimum of 35%. Giving in Action wants 100% of the students, parents, teachers and volunteers to be satisfied with the program by the time it ends.

So we ask that you please give whatever you can to help us gain the necessary funds for the software and materials that we need. Remember that helping our children is important. After all they really are our future.

For more information on helping with this campaign please visit www.givinginactioninc.com

story:
Short Summary

Send this giant nerd to Uganda to support LGBTQ+ rights and provide classroom assistance in Mukono, Uganda! 

I am a student in the UK, working towards a Literature and Philosophy degree, with the hope of becoming a teacher. I strongly believe that education, communication and support are incredibly important in combating prejudice and hatred, and unfortunately for LGBTQ+ people in Uganda, prejudice, fear and hatred have led to the "Kill the Gays" bill to pass through parliament. That LGBTQ+ people are facing 14 year prison sentences, and HIV+ LGBTQ+ people are facing death is terrifying, and the result, primarily, of fear. 

HIV/AIDS has cost Uganda so much, and the misinformation spread by homophobic groups has caused LGBTQ+ people to be persecuted and blamed for the spread of this disease. I will be working to increase access to information, and providing education on HIV/AIDS that shows how it is not spread by LGBTQ+ people, and helping talk about ways that the spread can be prevented and controlled. After a lot of agonising and concern for my own safety as a Bisexual woman, and then worrying that I was being selfish, I e-mailed @CitizenRadio for advice, and they answered in this episode: 

http://wearecitizenradio.com/2014/01/09/20140109-jay-carneys-beard-maniac-mail-surprise-theres-still-violence-in-iraq/ 

at around the 38 minute mark! (I'd recommend listening to the whole thing, and every other episode because they are beautiful and progressive and wonderful and independent and they won't lead you to war!) 

I am going to be volunteering with the Global Volunteer Network, and this is the project: 

http://www.globalvolunteernetwork.org/uganda/projects/mukono-teaching-project

I will be teaching English and Health, and will be helping the next generation of Ugandan Citizens access a different outlook on HIV/AIDS and LGBTQ+ rights. 

What I Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • I have already paid my deposit, and will be saving most of the $3000 cost of volunteering plus flights myself, this is just to give people a platform to support me!
  • By donating you get to use your privilege (like I am using mine) to support LGBTQ+ people in Uganda. 
  • If I hit half my goal I will also be shaving my head - and donating my hair to http://www.littleprincesses.org.uk/ - a UK based charity which makes real hair wigs for children suffering from hair loss. 
  • This fundraising is to help pay for the cost of volunteering with Global Volunteer Network, anything you can donate brings me closer to Uganda! Even if I don't meet my goal, anything contributed will help with the cost. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand not being able to afford to donate, it would really help me out if you could share this campaign, and also throw any questions/ criticisms at me on twitter (@elliesheep93) so I can go out there with as much information and so I can be as sensitive as possible in my work - I don't want to "white saviour complex" this, I want to be helpful and supportive!

story:
IOWSP IN SHORT



  • This is a story about a group of passionate young ski racers ski  from small ski federations around the world going to international ski racing together. 

    .

  • As athletes of small national teams those young athletes have the right to go represent their country in World Ski Championship and Winter Olympic Games, wether they are still not professional. They are trying to raise the money to afford part of the expenses to make the experience to ski the major professional ski circuit  (FIS Europacup and FIS Wordcup) and make their road to the next Olympic Games in Pyeonchang, South Corea, in 2018


  • With your help you'll give these girls and boys the chance to build their experience and improve their career to become professional athletes and go to race in the Olympic Games 


What We Need & What You Get

We need 29000$ to help the group to afford part of the expenses during the racing season.  16000$ for food and accomodation (40$ a day for 50days  accomodation for 8 people), 5500$ for car rental, 3500 for airfares and extra-luggage fees 1500$ for ski accessories and replacement tools  and 2500€ for petrol.

The rest of the organization and budget (race and training materials, lift tickets, and trainer's fee are provided by our sponsors or the athlete's federations themselves )


    For your donation we provide unique winter perks!

    •  membership of our ski association (INTERNATIONAL WINTER SPORTS  PROJECT with our unique site in Mayrhofen-Austria) 
    •  IOWSP t'shirt
    • sport sunglasses
    •  a real downhill ski racing suite homologated by the International Ski Federation (FIS)
    •  accomodation, food, acceditation and skipass to come to see one race of our boys around the Alps
    •  one of the trainings of our girls and boys around the Alps (3 days-2 night)
    • a weekly training camp with full board, skipass and training fee payed
    • accreditation as a member of orur team to see the world ski championships in Vail-Beaver creek (COL) in February 2015

    The Impact

    With your donation YOU CREATE PROFESSIONAL ATHLETES!!! :

    • Sport is a school of life. Wintersports are a lifetime experience as they require to be tough, organized, quick and focused 
    • As trainers, we have a past successful experience with a project like this held by the  International Ski Federation, over 200 athletes trained over 16 years, 10 World ski Championships and 6 Winter Olympic games editons partecipated.
    • Since we went private and we build International Wintersport Project Association, our athletes partecipated to two World Ski Championship and one Winter Olympic Games edition, with the sensational 24th place in the Olympic slalom by Alex Barbu (ROU) in Sochi 2014

    Risks & Challenges

     Sometimes athletes injury during the season...or they ave to face school problems or even some bad moments when they don't see a immediate success in their career: we are her to help them and to try to make their life better

    • With our over 15 years experience as international ski trainers around the world (Australia, Argentina, Italy, Austria)
    • Giving them a quiet place to stay in our college based in South Tyrol, school support, psychological, medical, athletic help thanks to our staff and....YOUR SUPPORT!!!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Of course finantial help is the most direct way you can help us, but there are other ways to make your help count for us: 

    •  get the word out, "spread the voice"  about our campaign.
    •  use the Indiegogo share tools to shout out the voice about us!

story:
Hi, my name is Chris Lloyd. You might remember me from certain art projects like Everyday Goalie, or Dear PM, a 15-year correspondence project with the Prime Minister of Canada, or perhaps as the former conservative party candidate here in Papineau. I infiltrated the conservative party riding association for 3 years. That campaign was an attempt to construct a satirical conservative persona, and to use Harper's own election strategies against him. 

I truly believe Canadians need to shake up the political system. Expensive and ineffective party politics is killing active democracy in this country. First-past-the-post gives us terribly skewed representation. So I'm here as a citizen of Papineau, as an artist and activist, to listen to my family, friends and neighbours to bring a fresh, independent voice to Ottawa. Even if you can't vote in Papineau, you can still help fund my campaign. 

IMPORTANT: For your donation, you could receive up to 75% tax-credit! But remember that you cannot give more than $1500 to any one federal political candidate. Keep it in mind if you're donating to other candidates.

__________________________________________________________________________

Bonjour, mon nom est Chris Lloyd ! Vous connaissez peut-être certains de mes projets artistiques tels EveryDay Goalie, le gardien de but du Canada, ou Dear PM, une correspondance unilatérale quotidienne avec le Premier ministre du Canada depuis 15 ans! Au printemps 2015, j'ai été candidat conservateur dans la circonscription de Papineau, point culminant de 3 années d'infiltration du parti avant d'être démasqué.

Pour obtenir de vrais résultats électoraux, nous devons transformer notre système politique vers la représentation proportionnelle! À titre de résident de Papineau, d’artiste et d’activiste, j’offre à mes concitoyens l’opportunité d’envoyer une voix nouvelle et indépendante à Ottawa. 

Merci de soutenir ma campagne en contribuant à cette levée de fonds!

IMPORTANT: Vous pourriez recevoir un crédit d'impôt aussi élevé que 75% pour votre contribution. Mais attention, le montant global de vos contributions est limité à  1 500$ au total! Pensez-y si vous contribuez à d'autres campagnes.

story:
Truth Telling Series is a multimedia organizing and education project focused on exposing the familial impact of state violence. We are collecting and sharing the stories of individuals who are impacted by various types of state violence and repression. Many of these cases relate to police brutality, false arrests, imprisonment, and confessions gained through torture. This is coupled with higher prison terms given by judges and disproportionate rates of drug and death penalty cases all targeted at people of color in the United States.
 
In the video above, you are introduced to leaders in the movement for justice and recognition of structural racism in our system. This structural racism allows for Black and Latino/a individuals (among others) to be incarcerated at much higher rates than whites. Statistics show us that 1 in 10 black men will have contact with the criminal justice system in the US during their lifetime.
 
According to the US Bureau of Justice Statistics, 40 percent of the total prison population comprise of black individuals and approximately 20 percent are Latino/a. This means that 60% of the prison population, if not more, are black and brown people. Keep this extra piece of data in mind - black Americans comprise of 13% of the US population and Latinos/as are 16% of the total population, according to the 2010 Census.
 
What does this mean? This means that people of color are disproportionately impacted by the racist practices of the criminal justice system. From the strategies used by police officers, the politicians public safety rhetoric, and the daily rise of men and women of color being locked up and not rehabilitated, we can see this disparity having real impacts on our community.
 
According to the Southern Human Rights Center, "The statistics are stark, but by now familiar: the United States has less than 5% of the world’s people, yet accounts for 25% of the world’s prisoners; the incarceration rate in the United States is seven times higher than the rate in Western Europe; more than 1 in 100 adults are behind bars today."
 
As Constance Malcolm stated, "we need all sides of the story." We know that institutions have greater access to the media, financial resources, and popular credibility due to their status and power. Because of this we only hear one side of the story. We read or hear, Officials say or Police Spokesperson said. Who speaks for the people who are falsely accused? Who speaks for the people who are unlawfully killed? Who speaks for the innocent who are only considered guilty due to bias and fear?
 
The status and power of the state distorts how we feel about their actions - especially when it has to do with low-income communities and communities of color. Mass incarceration has recently been brought to light by Michelle Alexander (2010) in The New Jim Crow. Historically, we have been blessed with the wisdom of Angela Davis, other activists, and intellectuals who have been able to translate this collective struggle of oppression in the United States.
 
To contribute to this debate, and more importantly to help families across the US obtain justice, we will document the stories of the state's abuse of power. Whether it is mass incarceration, unjust policies that discriminate against marginalized groups, and police violence - families sit at the intersections of reality and hope because their stories present solutions. These solutions need to be heard.
 
How will we spend the money raised?
 
We will use be funds to interview up to 20 families around the US who have experienced state violence. These stories (in multimedia formats) will be freely shared with each family as tools to help them win justice for their cases. We will use these stories to create curriculum to host discussions and trainings amongst human service professionals across the country (Flint & Detroit, MI; Oakland, CA; Camden, NJ; Chicago, IL; NYC; New Orleans, LA; & St. Louis, MO). 
 
Minimum Project Budget
$2000 - Travel expenses (by train)
$2000 - Additional equipment (mic, tripod, additional video camera, digital camera (for Photos), software)
$1000 - Editing consultant (Tracey Quezada Productions)
$5000 - Resources and training for families to use multimedia material for their efforts to get justice for their individual cases.
 
 
Learn more at www.truthtellingseries.org.
 
 
NOTE: This work is in honor of the children and parents who struggle with the loss of their families members to community and state violence.
story_txt:
Truth Telling Series is a multimedia organizing and education project focused on exposing the familial impact of state violence. We are collecting and sharing the stories of individuals who are impacted by various types of state violence and repression. Many of these cases relate to police brutality, false arrests, imprisonment, and confessions gained through torture. This is coupled with higher prison terms given by judges and disproportionate rates of drug and death penalty cases all targeted at people of color in the United States.
 
In the video above, you are introduced to leaders in the movement for justice and recognition of structural racism in our system. This structural racism allows for Black and Latino/a individuals (among others) to be incarcerated at much higher rates than whites. Statistics show us that 1 in 10 black men will have contact with the criminal justice system in the US during their lifetime.

This means that 60% of the prison population, if not more, are black and brown people. story:
Life Alchemist. Creatrix. Femininity Evocoteur. Kindler of Things Wild and Wise Namaste has spent her life  seeking means of stroking, feeding and sustaining the Femininity as a source of Power and Sustenance. Embracing education both Auto-didactic and formal, she has been called the “bodhisattva of femininity” by her clients. Birth Mother to 4, Bonus mom to 4 more and wife of one Amazing kick-arse Man, Namaste has studied many methods of Healing and Life Transformation.  She is a Law of Attraction Practitioner, Ordained Minster, Doula, Oracle and Reiki Practitioner. The Founder of SOFT – The School of Feminine Transformation, a system of Empowered, Embodied, Enthusiastic Feminine Living, Namaste believes that living life embracing our authentic feminine selves is living life ecstatically. Her work is holistic bringing various modalities and ideas to bear as she witnesses and inspires you to step within yourself to Greatness. Some toys on this playground include: Law of Attraction and other Cosmic Laws, EFT, Oxytocin Awakening, NLP, Chakra clearing and charging, Menstrual mysteries, OM’ing, Muscle Testing, Intuitive Health Choices,  Tantra and other forms of Sacred Sex, and much much more!

At this time Namaste has an amazing opportunity to go to a deep and profound Training which will enable her to power-up her skills, add additional tools to her repetoire and offer MORE to the women she is called to reach. This will help Namaste bring the ideas, transformative teachings and inspirations to women bringing into reality - women as keepers of hearth and home, women as containers for Purpose and as Actualizers of Vision, Women as dynamic facets of the Divine.

When Namaste asked the Universe to open doors to enable her to take this Training this idea of crowd funding presented itself. What a wonderful opportunity for connection and collaboration! Whether you are a man or a woman, every bit donated is energy sent into the Universe saying YES! You believe in women's empowerment in all its Highest and Best forms and you believe in Namastes vision and purpose for Actualized Feminine Women. This type of energetic exchange benefits not only this Great Work - but you as well!!

What We Need & What You Get

Namaste needs $3000 to attend this Training. The money includes the training itself as well as transportation costs to get to the location. Any surplus monies raised will help Namaste provide spaces in her Classes and Seminars for women who could not otherwise afford to attend.

When you donate you receive an opportunity to work with Namaste and experience for yourself what this training has added to her Work and it's impactful nature.

Even if we DON'T raise the full amount - the money raised will go towards education and a scholarship for one very Blessed person to attend a one day Seminar with Namaste.

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Even if you CAN'T Donate monetarily you can still help!!

Send positive vibes, prayers and juju to help make this a reality!

Share this campaign in your social network by using all of the Indiegogo share tools!
