story:
Update (June 5, 2015)

Thanks to all the amazing support we received, we were able to expand the program from Portland to Seattle and Vancouver, Canada, over the last two years. We've launched a new Indiegogo campaign to take us to the next level. Help us reach more girls in more locations, and get some cool perks too!
---

Join Us In Launching App Camp For Girls!

We hit our original target of $50,000 in just three days. We are now aiming for $100,000, so that we can bring the awesome AC4G program to more girls in more locations by next summer.

Update (July 12, 2013)

App Camp For Girls was featured in The New Yorker today in an article titled Making Apps, Not Friendship Bracelets. It's a great overview of what we are doing and why it's important.

We've posted our first camper testimonial too. Aysa describes what makes App Camp For Girls awesome!

It's great seeing everyone come together to support this program. Only 4 days remain--make sure to invite your friends to join us too and get the word out in this final stretch.

Update (July 9, 2013)

See App Camp in action! We posted a new campaign video here, with footage from the first week of camp. And we were also featured on KATU News, in a great feature with reporter Valerie Hurst. 

For a firsthand account of volunteering, listen to designer and App Camp volunteer Christa Mrgan on The Talk Show with John Gruber. Towards the end of the show, she describes her experience working with the girls on interface and icon design. We are looking forward to having Christa back in August!

Update (July 3, 2013)

We just finished an amazing week! Twelve smart, creative girls participated in the App Camp “beta” session. We wanted to test out the program, and these girls agreed to be “guinea pigs” in exchange for waived camp tuition. (Read our latest Indiegogo update for more details!)

The girls loved it! “It’s a fun camp where you get to learn so much, meet amazing people, and build friendship and confidence.”

And so did their parents. “My daughter had a terrific time and was so inspired! Your camp has solidified her interest in a career as a computer programmer.”

We are also very excited to be closing in on $75,000 in donations! Our stretch goal is $100,000. With the additional funds, we will accelerate our plans and expand the program beyond Portland in Summer 2014.

Help us decide. When we make our new goal of $100,000, where should App Camp For Girls go next? Let us know in your comments!

-----

Why Apps? Why Girls?

App Camp for Girls wants to address the gender imbalance among software developers by giving girls the chance to learn how to build apps, to be inspired by women instructors, and to get exposure to software development as a career. Our goal is to grow our non-profit organization into a national force, with programs in multiple cities, helping thousands of girls.

We are launching this summer in Portland, Oregon. This summer, we'll be holding two sessions with girls 12-14 so that we can build and refine our curriculum. With experience and an established program, we'll move forward over the coming year with plans to expand the camp for Summer 2014 to accommodate more girls and a bigger age group, and to build the organization to reach beyond Portland to other cities.

Where did we get this idea?

Have you ever attended a tech conference and wondered, "Where are all the women?" That was founder Jean MacDonald's question. She attends an annual developer gathering with over 5000 attendees every year, and only a few hundred of them are women. Instead of feeling cranky about it, she tried to think of a positive way to address the imbalance.

As a volunteer and former board member at the Rock 'n' Roll Camp for Girls, Jean knew that amazing things happen when women mentors help girls see themselves in roles they had never imagined before. The camp started in Portland 12 years ago, and today there are girls rock camps around the world. App Camp For Girls is inspired by this model.

What have we done so far?

In March, we held a one-day "alpha" camp with a small group to test out our plan to build an app with the girls in a short amount of time. It was a huge success. 

The highlight of the program for the girls was using the finished app on the iPhone. The feeling of accomplishment was clearly visible on their faces.

We are doing a "beta" camp (at no charge) June 24-28 with 12 girls to build on the success of the alpha camp and extend the program to a full week. Even with minimal outreach, we received beta camp applications from over 30 girls. We know the demand and need is there, and we know we have a program that is both engaging and inspiring. Our August regular session is scheduled to have 20 campers, and we already have girls signing up.

Update: Our first "beta" session was a huge success. Check out our pitch video above to see the camp in action. We are focused now on making August even better!

What happens at App Camp?

The schedule at App Camp For Girls is equal parts geeky and fun. It's summer camp, after all! Girls are divided in to project teams, and the teams are led by a woman iOS developer with help from other women who are designers, testers, support specialists, and others.

The weeklong session covers the process from brainstorming an app idea to marketing the finished app. Girls will learn how to sketch out and storyboard their app ideas. The project team leaders will take the refined app storyboards and show the girls how apps are built in Xcode. The girls will have an opportunity for hands-on time with Xcode Storyboards and will learn how to customize the content of their app.

In addition to developing their apps, the girls get to design icons and write App Store descriptions, while figuring out who their target market is. On the last day of camp, the teams will pitch their apps to a panel of women angel investors, giving them a chance to receive valuable feedback and learn more about the business side of app development.

Each day, we'll also have some physical activities with teachers coming in to do yoga, hula hooping, and self defense. Weather permitting (it is Oregon, of course), we can take advantage of the playground at TaborSpace where the camp is held and go on hikes in nearby Mt. Tabor Park. There will also be arts-and-crafts, button making, decorating iPhone cases and designing iPhone wallpaper.

The camp will provide an iPod touch for each girl to use. This will make it easy for the girls to learn by example, looking at current apps and how they work. The finished apps from each project team will be loaded on to all the iPod touches so the girls can see their apps on the device and get that sense of pride and excitement that comes with deploying your first app.

What will the funds be used for?

Our goal is to raise enough money to fund the first 12 months of building a non-profit nationwide program. We have the costs of launching the Summer 2013 App Camp with 32 girls over two sessions (June and August), as well as the costs of running the camp, expanding the program and doing outreach for the next 12 months. Some of the expenses include:

  • iPod touches
  • MacBooks, backup drives and other accessories
  • venue rental
  • classroom equipment and projector
  • volunteer stipends
  • scholarships
  • design tools and art supplies
  • software: CRM, finance, presentation
  • website hosting
  • accounting and legal services
  • printing and t-shirts
  • snacks and lunches

Update: We hit our target of $50,000 in just three days. We are now working toward our stretch goal of $100,000. The response to App Camp For Girls has been just amazing, and we often hear the question: "When can you bring App Camp to our city?" With the additional funding, we'll be able to bring the program to more girls in more cities by Summer 2014.

How can you help?

First and foremost, we welcome your dollars! There are hard costs associated both with launching and seeding a fruitful, long-term venture like this. (Did we mention we were thinking big? Lots of lost ground to make up for as far as creating gender balance and opportunity!)

Second, we'd love your help getting the word out about App Camp for Girls—both this fundraiser and the project in general. We can't be everywhere and we don't know everyone who'll want to be involved—yet, anyway—so we really need your help. Sharing on Facebook, Twitter, G+ or your favorite online or real-life networks of choice increases our chances of getting more girls in more camps making more apps. 

To facilitate this, Friend of AC4G and functional muse Dyana Valentine generously pre-rolled some <140-character messages for your tweeting convenience:

Think app-building is a boy-thing? Don't click here: http://bit.ly/app-camp

Think girls+summer=lemonade stands and tan lines? Think again! http://bit.ly/app-camp

Help 32 girls kick APP this summer! http://bit.ly/app-camp

Want to support girls in tech? Put your $ where your heart is: http://bit.ly/app-camp

Integrating software development, one girl at a time: http://bit.ly/app-camp

Girls+tech+lady smarty pants mentors= a better world. Support @AppCamp4Girls http://bit.ly/app-camp

Our thanks...

... to you for supporting our campaign and spreading the word, and to many fine people who have helped us get this far:

Natalie Osten and Kelly Guimont: volunteer counselors and co-organizers extraordinaire!

Our colleagues have very generously supported by making it possible for us to focus time and attention to the project. We are lucky to work with such great developers:
- Greg Scown & Philip Goward of Smile 
- Dave Teare, Roustem Karimov & Jeff Shiner of 1Password/AgileBits
- Evan DeLaney of Fish Hook

Josh Barrett of CreateLegal provides us legal services and much wise advice.

Thompson Morrison and Chris Brooks at the TechStart Educational Foundation stepped into the crucial role of non-profit fiscal sponsor, sharing their deep experience and expertise in tech education programming.

Julie Mills of DesignPony designed our awesome logo, buttons, flyers; she makes us look good.

Colleen Wainwright, aka Communicatrix, offered indispensable support and generously shared the expertise she gained from her own WriteGirl/50-for-50 campaign.

Curtis Settino of Canoofle did an amazing job producing our fundraising video, while providing a lot of smart advice on the process.

The Doubleclicks curated the Clever Girl Mixtape perk, gathering together delightful and nerdy musicians Marian Call, Molly Lewis, Sarah Donner, and Kirby Krackle to support App Camp For Girls.

Artist Rosie Augustine loved the idea of creating a unique Ada Lovelace collage portrait, adding a touch of elegance to our perk offerings. Check out all of Rosie's unique mixed media artwork, and you'll get an idea of what she will do with the Ada portrait.

LeAnn Boucher and Aaron Hillegass at Big Nerd Ranch generously arranged a donation of copies of the excellent and popular iOS Programming: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide.

Kirschen Seah happily pitched in to organize and curate our companion blog App Stories, featuring interviews with our favorite developers about their first apps. 

Beth Wooten, Molly Gray and all the staff and campers at Rock 'n' Roll Camp for Girls: without your example, there would be no App Camp For Girls!

---
Please note: when you donate, your receipt will say "TECHSTART". TechStart Education Foundation, a registered 501(c)(3) organization, is the fiscal sponsor of App Camp For Girls, a non-profit corporation in the State of Oregon. Donations to App Camp For Girls via TechStart are tax-deductible.

Girls+tech+lady smarty pants mentors= a better world. Support @AppCamp4Girls http://bit.ly/app-camp

Our thanks...
... to you for supporting our campaign and spreading the word, and to many fine people who have helped us get this far:
Natalie Osten and Kelly Guimont: volunteer counselors and co-organizers extraordinaire!
Our colleagues have very generously supported by making it possible for us to focus time and attention to the project. We are lucky to work with such great developers:- Greg Scown & Philip Goward of Smile - Dave Teare, Roustem Karimov & Jeff Shiner of 1Password/AgileBits- Evan DeLaney of Fish Hook
Josh Barrett of CreateLegal provides us legal services and much wise advice.
Thompson Morrison and Chris Brooks at the TechStart Educational Foundation stepped into the crucial role of non-profit fiscal sponsor, sharing their deep experience and expertise in tech education programming.
Julie Mills of DesignPony designed our awesome logo, buttons, flyers; she makes us look good.
Colleen Wainwright, aka Communicatrix, offered indispensable support and generously shared the expertise she gained from her own WriteGirl/50-for-50 campaign.
Curtis Settino of Canoofle did an amazing job producing our fundraising video, while providing a lot of smart advice on the process.
The Doubleclicks curated the Clever Girl Mixtape perk, gathering together delightful and nerdy musicians Marian Call, Molly Lewis, Sarah Donner, and Kirby Krackle to support App Camp For Girls.
Artist Rosie Augustine loved the idea of creating a unique Ada Lovelace collage portrait, adding a touch of elegance to our perk offerings. Check out all of Rosie's unique mixed media artwork, and you'll get an idea of what she will do with the Ada portrait.
LeAnn Boucher and Aaron Hillegass at Big Nerd Ranch generously arranged a donation of copies of the excellent and popular iOS Programming: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide.
Kirschen Seah happily pitched in to organize and curate our companion blog App Stories, featuring interviews with our favorite developers about their first apps. 
Beth Wooten, Molly Gray and all the staff and campers at Rock 'n' Roll Camp for Girls: without your example, there would be no App Camp For Girls!
---Please note: when you donate, your receipt will say "TECHSTART". TechStart Education Foundation, a registered 501(c)(3) organization, is the fiscal sponsor of App Camp For Girls, a non-profit corporation in the State of Oregon. Donations to App Camp For Girls via TechStart are tax-deductible.

story:
Summary:

I am Teresa Gray, an undergraduate student at Western Oregon University; studying Criminal Justice with a minor in Homeland Security. In June 2014, I will be graduating with Honors and a Bachelor of Science degree. I am a fourth dan black belt in taekwondo and referee at most local tournaments; I am also a first lieutenant in the Civil Air Patrol, where my main job is to teach about drug resistance, and I also participate in emergency service activities-such a search and rescue.

It would be an amazing experience for me to be able to study criminal justice abroad at Bond University on the Gold Coast, Australia. Since applying for this opportunity, I often find myself day dreaming about all the things I could learn: about myself, Australia, another culture, and a foreign criminal justice system. It is no longer enough for me to someday visit the land down under; I need to learn everything about it- live it, breath it, explore it, study in it- the type of learning only a study abroad program could provide.

By supporting my endeavor, you will be helping me have an experience of a lifetime. Anyone who has ever studied abroad will tell you how it changed their life and was the best experience of their life. Fund my opportunity to change my life!

 

What I Need & What You Get:

This experience of a lifetime is very expensive but with your help I can make this daydream a reality. I will have to pay: $18,000 to the third party provider, CISabroad, which will pay for tuition and fees, housing, medical and accident insurance, academic/financial aid counseling, CISabroad Culture and Adventure Program, CISabroad support services before, during and after the program, assistance with travel arrangement, pre-departure/onsite orientation, airport pickup, official Bond University transcript, and carbon offset of travel and Green Travel Guide; personal expenses include $3,500 for meals, books and supplies, an International Student Identification Card, and other miscellaneous expenses; Visa fees of $565; Airfare and local transportation $2,500; Western Oregon University gets $580 for an application fee, administration fees, and Capstone Project Tuition (1 credit course); Passport with photo was $145. Keep in mind that this is a 15.5 week program in which I will be studying at a top rate university.

For your donation you can receive a cleaning cloth for your glasses or electronic devices, an origami crane, a Drug Demand Reduction carabineer key chain with an explanation of the program or a coupon for Dragon Financial, Inc. (DFI) services. www.dragonfinancial.com If you do not own your own business, DFI also accepts individual people/couples as clients. If you do not live in Oregon, that’s fine, DFI has a few out-of-state clients as well. Just tell them what you need, they will find a way to provide it.

If I do not reach my goal and am not able to study abroad, I will be sure to only use the money raised for educational purposes, such as tuition and textbooks. Don’t worry, you are just funding my education and that is always a good cause to support.

 

The Impact:

I am a very hard worker, dedicated, loyal, and do not do anything without giving it everything. I put a lot of hard work into my education and my life. By contributing to my education and life experiences, you are contributing to the WORLD. The impact I will make (and have already made) on the world will be positive and beneficial. I have found that I can make a bigger difference by knowing how others do things and how that can relate, improve, and benefit what we do. This opportunity will help me in many aspects of my career goals; and help me impact the world with my great mind and spirit.

 

More Ways You Can Help:

Please spread the word to as many people as you can-nothing works better than word of mouth. You know how amazing I am and the difference I can make in this world, so go tell the WORLD about me! Tell your family, friends, neighbors, enemies, distance relatives, co-workers, team members, and even strangers you meet on the street.

Don’t forget to use the Idiegogo share tools. Also be sure to comment to help me become a featured campaign.

 

Thank you for your time and contributions!

story:
Update:Because of your amazing support we have exceeded our goal! Thank you so much.Knowing there's all these wonderful people supporting us, we want to take this to the next level and keep on campaigning!Please help us create an amazing experience for these children and spread the word about the project. Let the kids play!! Love TA

 The TA project is a group of young Japanese professionals living in Osaka. We're not captain planet and we're not perfect. But we are united with the passion of wanting to help these children in Fukushima and to make a difference.

 

The Story

Did you know children in Kori-machi Fukushima are only allowed to play outside for 1hour because of the risk of radiation?

 And this is only one of the many side effects caused by the Nuclear Plant Melt Down in Fukushima. Well and truly the lives of people in Fukushima have been turned upside down.

 Not only have children lost their homes, family and friends. Everyday they have to stress about radiation levels in the food they eat, the water they drink and the environment they play in.

No child should ever have to go through this!!

Let’s do something for these kids!!

 

The Impact

The TA project is inviting children from Fukushima for a 4day camp in Osaka from August 17th to 20th.

This is how we’re going to help.......

 Help the wider community

This is not just for the children, but for the hard working parents who are trying to survive, keep their children safe and fight against a nuclear free country all at the same time.

Help by giving them hope

The media might have stopped giving them attention but we want them to show them the world still cares.

Help by giving them back their childhood.

For the past 15months they haven’t had much time to ENJOY life and have FUN.

Help by giving them courage

Heck we’re not perfect but we want to be good role models for these kids. Teach them how to be strong and show them how to deal with difficult times.

 

We need your help

We’re not planning on putting on some extravagant Puff Daddy style party. But we want to put on a camp where the children feel inspired. We want to give them courage, hope, love, memories and the opportunity for them to be kids again.

Although we’ve been working our butts off raising funds through events, flea markets,music events and donation boxes, we REALLY need a hand.

TA is an ongoing project, this camp is not a one off but we want to invite children from Fukushima every year for these camps!!

 

Who are the TAproject?

TA stands for Tanoshiku Asobou. Translated into English it means ‘Let’s play and have fun’.

We’re a group of young Japanese professional living in Osaka who are united with the passion of wanting to help these children. Some of us have lived overseas and have seen the power of how communities get together and help each other. Earlier this year, a few of us went to Fukushima and saw the devastation and knew we couldn’t just turn a blind eye.  

Please help us show these kids and Japan, what we’re doing is possible and what awesome people are out there in the world!!!

 

The TA Project aims to....

1) Create a memorable experience for these amazing children.

2) Raise more awareness around the world about the crisis that still lives on in Fukushima.

3) Inspire other young Japanese people to start taking action and change the world we live in. We want to show them that this is possible!

 

This is an article about us on the Deep Kyoto blog

http://www.deepkyoto.com/?p=7749

If you can read Japanese please check us out here on Facebook

https://www.facebook.com/pages/TA-Project/264322230327615

Check us out here

http://ameblo.jp/taproject

 

We need money for 

-Round trip Bullet train tickets from Fukushima to Osaka

-To hire out the camp venue

-Food (These are growing kids, we can’t just feed them carrot sticks!!)

-Activities (We have so much planned!! They can kiss goodbye their Nintendo DSs)

 

How else can you help?

You really want to help but money is a bit tight?

You can still help us by spreading the word. PLEASE PLEAE PLEASE

You can help us by sending us and the children words of encouragement. Fuzzy warm words are the best!!

 Or you can help us by telling your mum to donate us some money;)

 Thank you so much for your time and kindness.

 

Perks

Check out the perks on to your right.

Perks, perks, perks galore. We are so grateful for your support and even just taking the time to see what we’re all about. You are our super hero!!!

The kind and awesome artists who contributed their work

Frank Liew

After spending many of his creative years in New Zealand, Frank currently resides in Hong Kong where he works as a creative director. Known to many New Zealanders as that master mind behind the notorious boutique ‘Qubic’, Frank also writes for Hypebeast and is an influential figure in the New Zealand and beyond. Frank is also an amazing photographer and always manages to capture magical moments from around the world. The picture he donated is a shot of Tokyo from the hills in Aoyama.

http://hypebeast.com/blog/frankliew/

 

Tom Gould 

Tom Gould is a New Zealand born director and photographer, based between Auckland and New York City.As a teenager, Gould was influenced and inspired by the cultural movements founded in New York City. In 2009 Gould travelled to New York and began documenting the city streets and the environment he was so heavily influenced by as a teenager.As a photographer, Gould aims to capture the underlying beauty in every situation, while portraying the raw honesty of life he encounters.

http://tomgouldshoots.com/ 

 

Anna Delany

Dividing her time between New Zealand and New York, Anna Delany experiences the world through her a lens, documenting the subtleties of everyday life. 

Her exploration of gritty street life exposes insights into humanity: recording our stories and documenting the second of our lives. Her images captures both fleeting moments in time, and gradual dilapidation of urban decay, each photograph with its own story to share.

 Anna Delany’s image radiates the respect which she feels for the subjects, reminding us that no one photographs something they want to forget.

http://www.annadelany.com/

 

David Buchler

Buchler completed his BA(Fine Art) Honours degree majoring in Printmaking and Art History at the University of Natal (South Africa) in 2004. He undertook a 6 month scholarship at Kansai Gaidai University in Japan in 2002 to study sumi-e and Japanese Art History.
In 2006 he studied in the drawing and comic department at Högskolan i Gävle in Sweden. Subsequently he has received an MA degree from the University of KwaZulu-Natal (South Africa) in 2010.
He mostly works in installation, printmaking and video.

Buchler has participated in numerous group and solo exhibitions in South Africa.

Currently he has been living and working in Kyoto City, Japan for 3 years.

http://collectingspace.blogspot.jp/

 

Rebekah Atkins

Owner of the design company ‘Rise Creative’ in New Zealand, Rebekah has worked with top clients including Sony music, Samsung and New Zealand Fashion week.

Rise Creative is a design and communication studio founded by Rebekah Atkins (NZ), Nathalie Drujon (Paris) + Neil Grundy (London). Their experience in Europe + New York gave form to their distinctive design approach.

http://www.risecreative.co.nz/

story: Hi I'm Zach. I'm a potter, home-brewer, gaming (table & computer) enthusiast, and new teacher. I specialize in history for middle and high school students.This is a plea from a just graduated, soon to be educator, who is low on funds and needing to be ready to jump into the job market as soon as possible. Part of that being ready requires certain technology like a reliable laptop able to be used in the classroom. What I am looking at is a reasonable laptop for only $899. The laptop in question is new enough to be functional for years after the purchase and be utilized in the classroom setting as not only a means to build, keep track, and execute curriculum but also play the part of multimedia player and any other graphically demanding learning piece. You might say this cause does not affect you but considering my focus on working in public schools and the goal of teaching for many many years, technically you could argue that having this tool to better prep and execute lessons benefits society as a whole. Your contribution now could mean better jobs for my students who learned more in my class, only to graduate and obtain a higher playing job to support your social security pay. Heck, think of this as an investment more than charity. So if you want the future generation to be able to distinguish communism from socialism and not end every argument with "like Hitler", please donate now!

story:
Short Summary

We are a team of girls from the UK - We worked on a competition entry for Technovation Challenge based in the US.

Unfortunately we did not make it into the finals, although we got an Honorable Mention for being in the top 20 entries (out of 115)

We have decided to develop the app ourselves (see linked video for our idea)

We will get the opportunity to pitch our App idea to a VP at Cisco HQ - invaluable feedback opportunity.

We have been working with mentors from Cisco who have invited us to go to Cisco HQ in San Jose! Very exciting - we have some of the money and further money pledged - but we could always do with some more to ensure we can all go!

We will spend 5 nights in the USA - visiting sights such as the Golden Gate Bridge, Cisco HQ and possibly even Twitter HQ.

This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for the us and this experience will have a positive impact on our lives in the future.

We have been invited to Manchester University to speak at a teacher training session for Apps for Good on the 2nd May - which is an honour for us.

What We Need & What You Get

We still need funding to pay towards accommodation and meals whilst in San Francisco/San Jose

Still options for TechGirlsUK Certificate, Blog posts and tweets in your honour!

Plus a unclaimed TechGirlsUK Goodie bag :)

The Impact

  • This project has already had a major impact of the girls involved in the project and has raised the profile of the competition within the school for future female coders.

     

  • Please feel free to read the blog of our journey so far - http://technovationchallenge.wordpress.com/2013/03/20/working-with-women-in-industry-to-inspire-girls-into-csitstem-careers/

 

  • Their website will hopefully go live by the end of April http://www.techgirlsuk.co.uk

 

Other Ways You Can Help
 
If you can not contribute, all is not lost! Please share with friends and colleagues.

 

Thanks for your time and consideration.

story:
I want to share with you a very exciting ministry work I will be starting in August next year and asking you to consider how you may be able to support me in this work. I will begin serving with a Catholic Youth Ministry called NET Ministries (NET) which is a ministry directed towards secondary school students, third level students and young working people. 
During the past six years NET has served many dioceses throughout Ireland, positively impacting on the lives of some 30 000 young people. One of the distinguishing features of a NET team is that it is made up of young (18-30 year old) people. It is young Catholics who take up the challenge of presenting the Catholic faith to others in a way that is meaningful to them and helps them to see its relevance in their daily lives. 
Young people today are becoming complacent, and many young Catholics are leaving the Catholic Church to go to other churches that they find more inviting. Catholic youth need Good News. They need to hear it from their Church and they need to see its reality experienced and lived out in the lives of their peers. The Second Vatican Council states that ‘young people ought to be the first apostles to the young’ which is what NET Ministries is all about. 
Following five weeks of training, the teams embark on ten months of ministry to the youth of Ireland. Teams present the Gospel message in a clear manner, challenging young people to place God first in their lives and help them develop concrete ways they can grow in their faith. Young people need to hear a clear proclamation of the Gospel. They need to know that God loves them and cares about their lives. They need to know that the Church needs them and that they need the Church. 
That is what I am committed to share. But I need your support! I seek your support in the form of prayer. I need people praying for me to give me the courage and strength necessary for this exciting ministry. I also invite you to support me financially. I am committed to raising 6,000 dollars, prior to beginning my work with NET Ministries. While this amount does not cover the full expenditure during my time with NET the total cost is approx. 16,000 dollars. it is a very valuable investment in a better future for thousands of young people. This money will be used to provide me with a personal stipend, training in youth evangelization, formation in Christian character, countless opportunities to share my faith, food, accommodation, medical cover, pastoral supervision, ministry supplies and over 5 weeks training intensives. Each of my teammates will also be raising the same amount. 
As part of being on my support team I look forward to keeping you informed about the impact your support is having and give you peace of mind by showing that many young people will experience the Good News, and thousands of Catholic youth will become more engaged in their church and community life. 
Please prayerfully consider supporting me and the ministry with prayer and financial support. If you are willing to donate, please get in contact with me so I can send you as much information as possible on everything going on! Your support gives the ‘green light’ for my Ministry work with NET.
 
 
I would welcome any questions you have, you can e-mail me at TMccolgan001@student.franciscan.edu.




If you skipped the long letter I just posted above this, here's the abbreviated version!
I am going to Ireland for the year, August 16th, 2013- May 30th, 2014 to serve with NET ministries, a wonderful ministry where I can either be placed on a team that travels, ALL OF IRELAND (INSANE) or stay in one parish area for the year (ALSO BALLER) I must raise 6,000 dollars before I leave! INSANE. In total I must raise 16,000. (SHOOOOT.) Number 1) I ASK FOR YOU TO PRAY FOR ME PLEASE!! And if you have any intentions please let me know!
 
ANY QUESTIONS THEN PLEASE FEEL FREE TO E-MAIL ME!

E-mail: TMcColgan001@student.franciscan.edu


Please share this with anyone and everyone you know! 

peace and blessings!
story_txt:
I want to share with you a very exciting ministry work I will be starting in August next year and asking you to consider how you may be able to support me in this work. I will begin serving with a Catholic Youth Ministry called NET Ministries (NET) which is a ministry directed towards secondary school students, third level students and young working people. During the past six years NET has served many dioceses throughout Ireland, positively impacting on the lives of some 30 000 young people. One of the distinguishing features of a NET team is that it is made up of young (18-30 year old) people. It is young Catholics who take up the challenge of presenting the Catholic faith to others in a way that is meaningful to them and helps them to see its relevance in their daily lives. Young people today are becoming complacent, and many young Catholics are leaving the Catholic Church to go to other churches that they find more inviting. Catholic youth need Good News. They need to hear it from their Church and they need to see its reality experienced and lived out in the lives of their peers. The Second Vatican Council states that ‘young people ought to be the first apostles to the young’ which is what NET Ministries is all about. Following five weeks of training, the teams embark on ten months of ministry to the youth of Ireland. Teams present the Gospel message in a clear manner, challenging young people to place God first in their lives and help them develop concrete ways they can grow in their faith. Young people need to hear a clear proclamation of the Gospel. They need to know that God loves them and cares about their lives. They need to know that the Church needs them and that they need the Church. That is what I am committed to share. But I need your support! I seek your support in the form of prayer. story:
Hello!

My name is Jenny and I am a junior in high school. Alex is my brother. I have made it my mission to help Alex raise part of the funds for his trip to Japan. Alex is your average 7th grade boy. His perfect afternoon would consist of watching his favorite animes and playing Street Fighter. He likes video games, anime, trading cards, and all things technology. And on top of everything, he has a great interest in Asian culture.

When Alex expressed interest in traveling to Japan with his school through the annual Kawakami - Watsonville Sister City trip, I was thrilled. Our mom and I were delightedly surprised to see Alex aspire to go on such a trip. It makes sense because many of the things he likes originate in Japan. He talks a lot about Japanese culture and often says Japanese phrases to me that I don't understand.

Alex will be visiting Tokyo and Kawakami village, a Japanese amusement park, and various other sightseeing places. In Kawakami, Alex will be staying with a host family and will be attending the local middle school. Alex has studied Japanese customs and plans to take Japanese language classes taught by a KWSCA volunteer. He is very enthusiastic about his trip to Japan and is willing to go the extra mile to make sure he is prepared.

The KWSCA holds meetings for the group of amazing students traveling to Japan every month. Our mother has to work, so she cannot attend some meetings. I take Alex to the meetings in her place, since our father is disabled and would have difficulty coming. I really want Alex to be able to go on this trip because I want to prove to him that nothing can hold him back from doing things he wants to do. It is something that I have lived by for most of my life and I would like to pass this message down to him; that anything is possible if you have enough determination.

The trip costs about $1100 give or take a hundred or two, depending on plane ticket prices and hotel choices. We have already paid the $100 deposit and the first $300 installment. Alex will be participating in all other fundraising oppertunities offered by the KWSCA including a pancake breakfast and a car wash. $500 would cover half of the roundtrip ticket. Any other money from the other fundraisers would go towards bus fare, meals, entry fees to recreational places, and the other costs associated with the trip. 

I truly hope that you consider contributing to Alex's trip to Japan. If you have any questions feel free to drop a comment and I will answer back as soon as possible. The KWSCA is a non-profit, so your donation may be tax refundable if you wish. Thank you for reading and please share this page with a friend!

story:
LampLight Artists 2014 Overview

The media clip that is presented for this campaign gives you an idea of what I will be doing this summer. My role is to be a member of a four-member group and travel to different churches along the East coast of the United States. I will be using my gifts in the performing arts to encourage children to use their talents to glorify God in their own ways. 

      My name is Alicia Vossler. I am a junior in the children & family ministry program at Lancaster Bible College in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. God has gifted me with the passion to work with children as a lifelong career. The jobs I have held in the past all consisted of me teaching children various life skills. 

      The performing arts has always been a part of my life since I was a toddler. I have  trained with dance schools in both the United States and China since I was age five/six years old. I was never given the privilege to learn how to use my gift of dance in a Christian setting like young children are being given today. 

      My first experience teaching children the performing arts was when I was in middle school. My former dance teacher asked me if I would like to be her dance assistant and I gladly accepted the opportunity. Ever since she opened the doors up for me to help her teach dance, I have found myself surrounded by the performing arts to this day. I have not only learned about teaching children how to dance, but have also gained experience in showing God's glory through music. 

      This summer program that I am participating in is really helping me pursue my lifelong desire to encourage children to use their God-given talents for God's purposes in life rather than just for themselves. There are many talented artists that have solely used their gifts to bring glory to them rather to the God who gave them the talents that have helped them build their career. I know that by financially contributing to my summer program, you are helping children to learn how to show God's glory through their artistic gifts. 

       The financial contributions I am requesting from you is to help me be able to get trained and prepared to do my responsibility of teaching children how to use their artistic gifts in a godly way. I know that I am asking a good sum, but I promise that you will be constantly updated on the happenings of the program as the summer progresses. These contributions will be one way that you can get involved in being a part of God's plan for the world. 

What Is Requested

  • I need exactly $700.00 by June 4, 2014 to go towards my training for my program. My training will help me become a better teacher to the children I will work with in addition to getting to know three other people who will become a part of my summer team. These funds will also help cover the cost of my transportation to the organization's home base, which is located in West Virginia, food, and housing. 
  • Everyone sees me as a very energetic friendly person. The majority of my classmates at college find me to be full of humor when I try not to be. They say that my humor helps lighten the stress that they feel before a major project is assigned. 
  • If the contributions were to go over the $700.00 requested, they would go towards my stipend I will receive at the end of the summer according to my program director, Mr. Del Morgan. 

The Impact

  • This program is very valuable since it involves children experiencing how the performing arts is very effective in Christian ministry. 
  • Many of my previous students I worked with have found interests they are pursuing to this day. I tutored two Chinese children as a middle schooler and now both of the children will be graduating seniors from schools in the United States by the end of 2016. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Prayer is a huge basis for successful missions work. The Apostle Paul has asked people to pray continually for him and his team members that they will be given the strength to pray for them on their mission to do God's work (II Thessalonians 3:1-5). 
  • Feel free to share this summer program with your friends and family so that they can all be a part of praying for people, like me, who are doing programs like this. The more people who know about this program and who I am, the more success this program will be for the children I will teach.

story:
“After nourishment, shelter and companionship, stories are the thing we need most in the world.” 
― Philip Pullman

Welcome to Smart Stories! Smart Stories is the creation of two teachers who take the roles of Rufus and Reginald Write, travelling brothers who aim to preserve and protect stories and in doing so support children and teachers by inspiring a love of crafting them.

Aims:

  1. Inspire a love of stories by creating free story writing videos and resources to be used in schools.
  2. Visit schools to provide workshops for children and teachers - giving them 'A Reason to Write'.
  3. Become ambassadors for the importance of children's literacy and and for the power of stories to improve lives.

    Our free video resources are a mixture of modelling, explanation and tips, presented by Rufus and Reginald in an engaging and exciting way. They are shared via our YouTube channel and have worksheets linked to be used by children to expand their understanding. Our channel also collects playlists of writing stimuli from around the internet, based on different themes. We also support and share resources and ideas about children's literacy on our Facebook page.  

    Our flexible writing workshops revolve around the use of film, green screen, costume, drama, and sound recording. We provide the first steps into an imagined world, carefully resourced to give children the necessary experience to develop their own stories. Across a single day, the children can plan, write, star in, narrate, and provide sound effects for their own short film. Each section of the workshop focuses on improving their writing, widening their vocabulary, inspiring a love for stories and giving them a reason to write.  We know of no other companies that offer this service. 

    As qualified teachers we understand what schools, children and other teachers need for high quality education.  

    We have both been inventing and shaping exciting characters in our classrooms for a few years. Reginald and Rufus Write are special. They are brilliant at enthusing children to learn. Combining these characters with our knowledge of the new curriculum, enthusiasm for storytelling, use of technology and numerous props and costumes make for an explosive learning experience.  
    We are Smart Stories, and we are hugely excited about the opportunity to enthuse children and inspire a love of writing. With your help we plan to purchase the resources we need to visit schools and provide children with a 'Reason to Write'.

    “Stories can conquer fear, you know. They can make the heart bigger.” 
    ― Ben Okri

    Many children find writing challenging. They may not see writing as important or  useful for their lives. They can lack experience to fuel imagination which means they may not remain captivated by sustained writing. Two thirds of 100 primary school teachers we spoke to, told us their children struggle to use their imagination and come up with ideas. We strive to support children to develop these skills through our work. 

    This is important because literacy and story writing;

    • opens children's eyes to new people, places, or new ways of thinking which they might not otherwise encounter
    • gives children a safe space to explore their own emotions and reactions to the world around them
    • creates a positive attitude to creativity and less fear of failure
    • creates satisfaction in being able to manipulate language to craft something beautiful or to express an idea 
    • enables children to communicate more confidently and clearly in written and verbal ways.

      We want to transform creative writing from a daunting task into something children look forward to and take pleasure and satisfaction from throughout their lives. Through acting out and physically taking part in their own stories we give children a clear incentive to experiment with new ideas and test language outside of their comfort zone.

      We have already put our own funds into purchasing some of the core resources for our workshops. However we need your contributions to be able to launch our workshops so we can begin supporting children and teachers in story writing. This will go towards funding, among other things:

      • Creating free resources for schools that promote of the importance of children's literacy 
      • Props and writing resources
      • Costumes for children to immerse themselves in a role
      • Portable green screen equipment and lighting
      • Video and sound recording devices 
      • Technology for green screen and video editing
      • Data storage
      • Transportation for school visits
      If we were to raise more than £10,000 we would use the extra contributions to enable us to expand immediately into new themes for children to base their stories around, which you can read more about below.


      Costume designs created by Laura Wisner for our initial pirate themed workshop.

       “There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.” ― Maya Angelou

      1. Who are you?

      We are qualified primary school teachers with over 10 years combined classroom experience. We have shared knowledge of teaching all ages, from Reception to Year 6. Our passion is working with children and finding ways to make writing exciting.

      2. Who are your workshops suitable for?

      Our workshops are adaptable to all primary key stages, although our current resources are for Key Stage 1 and 2. We plan to cover an increasing variety of story genres with a view to expanding into older or younger age groups as we establish ourselves. 

      As well as schools, we will to be available for holiday clubs, libraries, parties and literacy festivals.

      4. What will happen in a typical workshop?

      All parts of the workshop will have a strong focus on story and character development, the enjoyment of literacy, and strengthening confidence in exploring language. Children will spend a full day creating, writing, and filming their own stories.

      A visit from Rufus and Reginald, for one class, includes:

      • Modelling of story narration and acting
      • Experimenting with the process of story planning
      • Acting out their story with a green screen, props and costumes
      • Recording sound effects for their story
      • Writing and recording narration for their film
      • A lot of fun!

      After the workshop the children’s work will be taken away and edited together into a final piece, and made available to the school for the children to watch.

      5. How does this fit in with the curriculum or what is currently being taught?

      Our workshop is not designed to be just a one-off session – weeks of work could be taught leading up to this event, with the workshop providing the culmination and evidence of their learning. Alternatively children can use their film as a springboard to continue writing with their teacher, which we can support with further resources. For details about links to the curriculum, click here.

      6. What genres and topics do you cover?

      We will be running our workshop based on theme, rather than genre. Our first theme will be 'Pirates!' which is easily adapted to suit various genres; adventure, fantasy, mystery, and contains opportunities to use interesting vocabulary, characters and settings. We are happy to tailor visits to teachers requests as much as possible.

      Once established, we will be able to expand to new themes to broaden the learning experience for children. Potential ideas include animals, futuristic/space, or medieval/fantasy themes.

      Some of our Smart Stories equipment, character and logo design.

      We have to be frank - we aren't making a cool product that we can give you. Our aims are to allow children to discover the value of stories and writing, and to open the path for children to discover the importance of literacy. Your contributions will allow us to inspire change in children's lives in the ways we have described above.

      However, we have created some perks to thank you for getting behind children's literacy and for helping to create the next generation of writers.

      £5 perk: Our sincere and eternal gratitude for supporting children's literacy. Thanks. You're a good egg.

      £10 perk: Video credit thanks. We'd like to make it known that you've helped us support children, so we will put your name in the credits of a video. Thank you.

      £15 perk: Spoken video thanks. We'd like to make it known that you've helped us support children, so we will name you in a video as a personal thank you.

      £20 perk: A set of 18 unique, limited edition stickers, with artwork created by the wonderful Phebe Dwyer. 35mm, ideal for using to support children's literacy in school or at home! P&P included. We'll also thank you in the credits of a video. 
      (200 available)

      £25 perk: A3 poster with bespoke artwork by Phebe Dwyer which celebrates the power of literacy and encourages a creative attitude to story writing. You can see sneak-peeks of the artwork in the titles on this page. P&P included. We'll also thank you in the credits of a video. 
      (100 available)



      £35 perk: Both the poster and the stickers! P&P included. We'll also thank you in the credits of a video. 
      (100 available)



      £40 perk: 10% discount voucher for a Smart Stories Workshop for you or your child's school (excluding travel costs). We'll also thank you or your school at the end of a video.
      (50 available)
      £60 perk: Poster, stickers and 10% discount for a Smart Stories Workshop. 
      (25 available)

      £100 perk: Personalised video request! We will create a personalised video on a story writing area of your choice to use with your class or own children. This could be the start of teaching a new topic, or could be our responses to children's work. This will be shared via our YouTube Channel. Any ideas will be considered! (Poster, stickers and 10% discount included.) 
      (8 available)


      £200 perk: Video Star! You, or an individual of your choice, can meet the Write Brothers and be part of a Smart Stories story writing video! (Poster, stickers and 10% discount included.) 
      (4 available)


      £400 perk: Smart Stories Party! The Write Brothers will come to an agreed location  run a Story themed party activity for up to 15 children. Your child will have a film starring all their friends, and be allowed to keep a costume! Suitable for birthdays in 2015! (Poster, and stickers also included) 
      (4 available)


      £1000 perk: Guardian of Stories. If you donate £1000, you will receive a handwritten letter of thanks, plus we will name you as a major donor to Smart Stories on the website. We will also invite your ideas as to how Smart Stories could be taken forward in the future. (Poster, stickers and 10% discount included.) 
      (10 available)


      "The shortest distance between two people is a story.” 
      ― Patti Digh

      If you share one story today, we'd like it to be ours. Not that cute cat picture your cousin posted. We are asked so often to share things that do not really matter or do not make a difference - but we believe this does. We would be hugely grateful if you could help us get the word out and talk about our campaign. 

      Twitter: @smartstoriesUK

      Facebook: SmartStories

      Website: smartstories.co.uk

      Youtube: smartstoriesUK


      Share and subscribe: watch the Write Brothers in action...

enables children to communicate more confidently and clearly in written and verbal ways.

 We have already put our own funds into purchasing some of the core resources for our workshops. However we need your contributions to be able to launch our workshops so we can begin supporting children and teachers in story writing. This will go towards funding, among other things:

Creating free resources for schools that promote of the importance of children's literacy 
Props and writing resources
Costumes for children to immerse themselves in a role
Portable green screen equipment and lighting
Video and sound recording devices 
Technology for green screen and video editing
Data storage
Transportation for school visits


If we were to raise more than £10,000 we would use the extra contributions to enable us to expand immediately into new themes for children to base their stories around, which you can read more about below.




Costume designs created by Laura Wisner for our initial pirate themed workshop.



 “There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.” ― Maya Angelou

1. Who are you?
We are qualified primary school teachers with over 10 years combined classroom experience. We have shared knowledge of teaching all ages, from Reception to Year 6. Our passion is working with children and finding ways to make writing exciting.
2. Who are your workshops suitable for?
Our workshops are adaptable to all primary key stages, although our current resources are for Key Stage 1 and 2. We plan to cover an increasing variety of story genres with a view to expanding into older or younger age groups as we establish ourselves. 

As well as schools, we will to be available for holiday clubs, libraries, parties and literacy festivals.

4. What will happen in a typical workshop?
All parts of the workshop will have a strong focus on story and character development, the enjoyment of literacy, and strengthening confidence in exploring language. Children will spend a full day creating, writing, and filming their own stories.
A visit from Rufus and Reginald, for one class, includes:

Modelling of story narration and acting
Experimenting with the process of story planning
Acting out their story with a green screen, props and costumes
Recording sound effects for their story
Writing and recording narration for their film
A lot of fun!

After the workshop the children’s work will be taken away and edited together into a final piece, and made available to the school for the children to watch.
5. How does this fit in with the curriculum or what is currently being taught?
Our workshop is not designed to be just a one-off session – weeks of work could be taught leading up to this event, with the workshop providing the culmination and evidence of their learning. Alternatively children can use their film as a springboard to continue writing with their teacher, which we can support with further resources. For details about links to the curriculum, click here.

6. What genres and topics do you cover?
We will be running our workshop based on theme, rather than genre. Our first theme will be 'Pirates!' which is easily adapted to suit various genres; adventure, fantasy, mystery, and contains opportunities to use interesting vocabulary, characters and settings. We are happy to tailor visits to teachers requests as much as possible.Once established, we will be able to expand to new themes to broaden the learning experience for children. Potential ideas include animals, futuristic/space, or medieval/fantasy themes.



Some of our Smart Stories equipment, character and logo design.

We have to be frank - we aren't making a cool product that we can give you. Our aims are to allow children to discover the value of stories and writing, and to open the path for children to discover the importance of literacy. Your contributions will allow us to inspire change in children's lives in the ways we have described above.

However, we have created some perks to thank you for getting behind children's literacy and for helping to create the next generation of writers.
£5 perk: Our sincere and eternal gratitude for supporting children's literacy. Thanks. You're a good egg.
£10 perk: Video credit thanks. We'd like to make it known that you've helped us support children, so we will put your name in the credits of a video. Thank you.
£15 perk: Spoken video thanks. We'd like to make it known that you've helped us support children, so we will name you in a video as a personal thank you.
£20 perk: A set of 18 unique, limited edition stickers, with artwork created by the wonderful Phebe Dwyer. 35mm, ideal for using to support children's literacy in school or at home! P&P included. We'll also thank you in the credits of a video. (200 available)


£25 perk: A3 poster with bespoke artwork by Phebe Dwyer which celebrates the power of literacy and encourages a creative attitude to story writing. You can see sneak-peeks of the artwork in the titles on this page. P&P included. We'll also thank you in the credits of a video. (100 available)



£35 perk: Both the poster and the stickers! P&P included. We'll also thank you in the credits of a video. (100 available)


£40 perk: 10% discount voucher for a Smart Stories Workshop for you or your child's school (excluding travel costs). We'll also thank you or your school at the end of a video. (50 available)

£60 perk: Poster, stickers and 10% discount for a Smart Stories Workshop. (25 available)
£100 perk: Personalised video request! We will create a personalised video on a story writing area of your choice to use with your class or own children. This could be the start of teaching a new topic, or could be our responses to children's work. This will be shared via our YouTube Channel. Any ideas will be considered! (Poster, stickers and 10% discount included.) (8 available)


£200 perk: Video Star! You, or an individual of your choice, can meet the Write Brothers and be part of a Smart Stories story writing video! (Poster, stickers and 10% discount included.) (4 available)



£400 perk: Smart Stories Party! The Write Brothers will come to an agreed location  run a Story themed party activity for up to 15 children. Your child will have a film starring all their friends, and be allowed to keep a costume! Suitable for birthdays in 2015! (Poster, and stickers also included) (4 available)

£1000 perk: Guardian of Stories. If you donate £1000, you will receive a handwritten letter of thanks, plus we will name you as a major donor to Smart Stories on the website. We will also invite your ideas as to how Smart Stories could be taken forward in the future. (Poster, stickers and 10% discount included.) (10 available)








"The shortest distance between two people is a story.” ― Patti Digh
 If you share one story today, we'd like it to be ours. Not that cute cat picture your cousin posted. We are asked so often to share things that do not really matter or do not make a difference - but we believe this does. We would be hugely grateful if you could help us get the word out and talk about our campaign. 
Twitter: @smartstoriesUK
Facebook: SmartStories
Website: smartstories.co.uk
Youtube: smartstoriesUK

Share and subscribe: watch the Write Brothers in action...

story:
"Individually, we are one drop. Together, we are an ocean."


Summary

My name is Alexandra Hewardt and I will be launching HelpingHandCrowd.com, an online fundraising community helping families and friends fund costly medical care for their loved ones. Between now and and July 15 2014, we are reaching out to incredible people like you to help us raise $10,000 through indigogo to build this community and save many patients from medical care bills distress. All funds will go to support in building this community and launching it so that we can start helping those in need.

How is Helping Hand Crowd different from other fundraising communities?

Our online fundraising community ensures that raised funds are used for their intended purpose. Donor confidence and payment transparency is crucial. When you raise money through Helping Hand Crowd, donors are assured that the contributions will go directly to their medical providers.

My personal story

On December 17th of 2013 I fell ill with a brain abscess, an infection of the brain, and had two surgeries to relieve the pressure. Many of the things I had taken for granted on daily basis, were suddenly taken away from me. I was completely paralyzed on my left side, unable to walk, and had slurry speech. For the next 10 days after the surgery I was unable to take care of myself. My husband Mike and the team of nurses had to do everything for me. They fed me, bathed me, and dressed me.

Before the surgery, I was looking so much forward celebrating the holidays with my family, moving to a new home and decorating it. Within a week, I started experiencing weakness on my left side, could not turn in bed as my body would not hold me up and I even spilled wine at a friend’s house during dinner on their white carpet. I experienced severe neck and shoulder pain that would not go away, and at times I felt confused, disoriented. 3 days prior going to ER I felt nausea and experienced severe vomiting. Before I went to the ER, I knew something was seriously wrong, yet I tried to tell myself it would go away by itself. I looked so much forward to the new coming year but instead, I ended up spending 21 days in a hospital bed. I truly felt that everything I had known had been ripped away from me.

After the surgery, the doctors said it would take about 3 to 4 months to do everything I used to be able to do before surgery, yet I was very fearful of whether they were telling me the truth or just trying to keep my spirits high. I started reading about brain abscesses, and I learned how rare they are, and how one can sustain possible residual deficiencies long after the surgery. I was fearful and heartbroken, even though the doctors kept telling me I would be fine.

About a week after my surgery, I became very frustrated about my left arm and legs still being paralyzed. Frustrated and desperate, I lifted my left arm with my right, and threw it towards my stomach. It was then when I saw my thumb reacting, slightly moving, a twitch. I was so excited by the small victory that I Skyped my friends to show them. From hereon I decided to start believing that I would heal again. It would take some time, but I was going to put up a fight if any obstacles arose. Nomatter what would come my way, I would beat it.

During my stay in the hospital I met many wonderful people, both patients and their relatives, who were not as fortunate as I was with their rehabilitation. Many of them had been denied in-patient rehab by their insurance companies, many of them did not have insurance, many were afraid of how they would handle their medical bills after being discharged from the hospital. Their stories moved me deeply and I knew I had to do something about the situation. I felt it was unjust that some get better care than others, and could only imagine the stress they must have felt just thinking about the mounting bills during a time when a stress-free environment was necessary. It was then when I decided to start this project and now YOU can help me to realize it. I know many of you feel the same way, and together we can make a difference, one life at a time! Let’s do it!

How you can help

Our success is dependent on you, my fellow Helping Hand Crowd Champions. There are a number of ways you can participate in the successful launch of HelpingHandCrowd.com. I’m asking you to stand up in the Crowd and join our team as a Champion and as a Backer. You can become a Backer by helping us raise funds to cover start-up expenses to build our site platform. You can become a Helping Hand Crowd Champion by doing whatever you can to build public awareness including:

-  Sharing this campaign link  http://igg.me/at/helpinghandcrowd on your Facebook page, Twitter or any other social media platform you may be part of

-  Become a Helping Hand Crowd Champion by taking a selfie, post this link http://igg.me/at/helpinghandcrowd to our campaign on your Facebook page

Please, if you can, make a financial contribution and help us help others. Together we can make great impact in other peoples’ lives. Let’s do it!

 Thank you for your support! Now, let's get to work and change peoples' lives!

Kind regards,


FACEBOOK: 

Step 1: Cut and paste this text into your post on your wall: "Become a Helping Hand Crowd Champion! Share this post on your own FB page with the link and your own helping hand selfie! Thank you for your support! http://igg.me/at/helpinghandcrowd" 

Step 2: Attach a selfie into the post including the palm of your hands. See example below.



TWITTER:

Step 1: Create new tweet post

Step 2: Cut and paste following text into the tweet: "Stand up in the crowd and help families and their loved ones pay their costly medical bills. http://igg.me/at/helpinghandcrowd"

Step 3: Attach a selfie into the post including the palm of your hands. See example below.

Join us on Facebook or Twitter.

Thank you for your support! http://igg.me/at/helpinghandcrowd" Step 2: Attach a selfie into the post including the palm of your hands. story:
What is The DUDE. be nice Project?

The DUDE. be nice project is a platform, launched by the mission driven apparel brand DUDE. be nice (learn more below), to inspire young people to build a positive community by rallying together to recognize a person or group in a fun, creative, and meaningful way.  With your support, we're committed to working with as many schools, students, and organizations to create these special moments, cultivating a culture of kindness and appreciation.

Why it Matters?

I started my career in Journalism and I remember the moment I decided it wasn't the career for me.  Our News Director walked in the newsroom excited as a kid about to eat his first slice of cake and asked, "What do we got today guys...car crash? Anybody die?"  We were hoping and searching for tragedy to ensure the best ratings.  I asked myself, do I want to live to tell these types of stories or live to tell encouraging ones? The DUDE. be nice Project is committed to working with young people to create positive stories that are sharable across social media.

Everyone is trying to figure out how to be happy.  We know through recent studies in Positive Psychology by top universities that one of the keys to a person's own happiness is constantly seeking opportunities to make someone else smile and feel appreciated.  The DUDE. be nice Project is a platform to get young people hooked on this "helper's high" and of course make recipients feel appreciated.

Who is DUDE. be nice?

We're a lifestyle apparel brand based in Ventura, CA (Check Us Out).  We realized there are a lot of brands out there that don't stand for much and we wanted to be different.  So, we created a brand that's relevant enough for young people to wear and isn't "anti" something, but FOR "being nice."  The DUDE. be nice Project is an initiative that makes our brand come to life.  Check out the vid below to learn more.


Above And Beyond Our Goal

Any funding beyond our goal will go towards enhancing this year's projects and/or projects in the 2015/16 school year.

Risks & Challenges

A significant portion of our sales already go towards the DUDE. be nice Project.  However, we are a start-up company doing our best to maintain a viable business and we need extra support to meet our goal to work with at least one school or organization per month to create a DUDE. be nice Project.  Additionally, we ask schools to help offset our costs to make these special moments possible by purchasing custom DBN gear, which limits our reach to schools that can afford this expense.  We are committed to using this platform to build positive communities on campuses across the country with no strings attached.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We already put a portion of our sales towards the DUDE. be nice Project, so anytime you buy our gear here you're supporting this campaign.  If that doesn't work for you, we'd appreciate you simply making some noise about our campaign through your social media channels - and you can use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
I’m going to Cambodia!

Thanks to the amazing staff at Shaker Heights High School, I have the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to go on a service trip to Cambodia. 

My social studies teacher at my high school (and world traveler on the side) Ms. Ahrens has set up an incredible trip for a lucky dozen people for one week over this spring break. She has been to Cambodia several times before, and has been inspired by her experiences to teach the Human Rights and Conflicts course at my high school and to set up this program. Through her knowledge of the country, she has created an itinerary for us specific to what she felt would best highlight what makes the country so special to her.

At the heart of the trip are two goals: service and culture immersion.

We will be traveling to two major cities: Phnom Phen and Siem Reap, both beautiful and buzzing with culture. There, we will be exploring the major things that the cities have to offer: restaurants, local artisan’s shops, and lots of markets, most notably, Siem Reap’s world-famous Night Market. 

We will also visiting some of Cambodia’s most important historical sites, such as the Killing Fields and the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum. It is important that we understand the roots of the culture and the turmoil of the country’s past to be able to understand where it is today. Other sites we will be exploring include Siem Reap’s temples and Angkor Wat, perhaps the most famous in Southeast Asia. 

Later, we will travel to Prek Toal, the floating village where we will be doing our service work and doing home stays for two nights. The service includes building badly-needed structures, repairing anything that needs fixing, helping the villagers fish, cook, clean, etc. We will also be building water purification systems so that the villagers have access to clean water. When we are not building, we will be interacting with the villagers and their children, playing and giving lessons in english and math, and seeing how they live their everyday lives.

Ever since I first heard about the trip, I knew that this was the right one for me. I was also offered the opportunity to go with the Shaker Heights choir and orchestra to tour in Austria and Hungary this upcoming spring. As amazing as I’m sure that trip would be (staying in over-the-top hotels, being bussed from place to place, having lots of time to shop for souvenirs, etc.), I turned it down because I felt that the trip to Cambodia would be more rewarding. As Ms. Ahrens keeps stressing, “we are learning to be travelers, not tourists”.

The tour company that we are using is Rustic Pathways, an extremely trustworthy company that specializes in both adventure and service-based trips in the less-developed parts of Asia and Africa. 

An itinerary and overview of the trip in their words is here:

http://rusticpathways.com/programs/floating-village-service-expedition-2/

Why contribute?

I have been babysitting and doing odd jobs as much as possible since the summer to help pay for the trip. A major component of this trip is the idea of making sacrifices for something that is truly worthwhile, and weighing what we really need vs. what we want in the moment. In the spirit of the trip, the group has been fundraising like crazy and motivating each other toward our common goal. 

I have raised a good deal of the funds that I need in this way, but I can’t do it alone. 

The cost of the trip is about $3200, which covers the airfare, service fees, hotel rooms, and most meals. I wholeheartedly believe that every sacrifice I have made thus far has been worth it, and am still working hard toward my goal. 

With your support, I can turn this trip into a reality.

If possible, please share this page so that it gets as much exposure as it can. Every little bit counts.

Perks!

When I return from Cambodia, I will share my experiences by creating a blog where I will post photos and recount stories from my time there. I will be regularly updating the blog with stories detailing how the trip is impacting my life back home, as I’m certain it will.

Thank you for your consideration!
