story:
About the Catholic Schools of Fairbanks

"I don't just teach Calculus, I teach character."  - Principal Patrick Riggs, head Math instructor.
In the heart of Alaska, you'll find the Catholic Schools of Fairbanks, a pre-K through 12th grade educational community with a foundation in Christ.

The Catholic Schools of Fairbanks is devoted to promoting academic excellence and nurturing a welcoming, compassionate Catholic community.

Catholic Schools of Fairbanks  is rooted in the traditions of our founders, the Sisters of Providence and the Society of Jesus, who opened Immaculate Conception School in 1946.  The Catholic Schools of Fairbanks was formally endorsed by the Oregon Province of the Society of Jesus in 2013. 

Since then, the school has grown to 430 students ranging from PreK through 12. 

For more history, visit http://www.catholic-schools.org/about.html.

Our Fundraising Goal & Perks

Our goal is to raise $20,000 to assist with teacher salaries. Every little bit counts. 

  • Being a small school in a mission Diocese, we are not able to pay the same salaries as public schools.  We are blessed to have dedicated teachers who believe in the mission of the schools. Our board is actively trying to reduce the gap between the salaries we offer and public school salaries.
  • From a "shout out" on Facebook to a microwave or door dedicated in your name, we have wonderful "thank yous."  Take for instance the homemade peppermint bark (perfect for this holiday season) or a Christmas tree ornament.

The Impact

The Catholic Schools of Fairbanks offers not only a solid education but also an education founded on Jesus. 

From stories of children thriving in higher education and in life beyond schooling, to students becoming so excited about Christ that they start bringing their parents to Church (resulting in multiple new families become baptized each year), the impact of these schools reaches deep into the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

If money is tight and you are unable to contribute, help us by spreading the getting the word about our campaign. Thank you!
story_txt:
About the Catholic Schools of Fairbanks
"I don't just teach Calculus, I teach character."  - Principal Patrick Riggs, head Math instructor.In the heart of Alaska, you'll find the Catholic Schools of Fairbanks, a pre-K through 12th grade educational community with a foundation in Christ.The Catholic Schools of Fairbanks is devoted to promoting
 academic excellence and nurturing a welcoming, compassionate Catholic 
community. Catholic Schools of Fairbanks  is rooted in the traditions of our founders, the Sisters of 
Providence and the Society of Jesus, who opened Immaculate Conception 
School in 1946.  The Catholic Schools of Fairbanks was formally endorsed
 by the Oregon Province of the Society of Jesus in 2013.  Since then, the school has grown to 430 students ranging from PreK through 12.  For more history, visit http://www.catholic-schools.org/about.html.
Our Fundraising Goal & Perks
Our goal is to raise $20,000 to assist with teacher salaries. Every little bit counts. 



Being a small school in a mission Diocese, we are not able to pay the same salaries as public schools.  We are blessed to have dedicated teachers who believe in the mission of the schools. Our board is actively trying to reduce the gap between the salaries we offer and public school salaries.
 From a "shout out" on Facebook to a microwave or door dedicated in your name, we have wonderful "thank yous."  Take for instance the homemade peppermint bark (perfect for this holiday season) or a Christmas tree ornament.

  


The Impact
The Catholic Schools of Fairbanks offers not only a solid education but also an education founded on Jesus.  
From stories of children thriving in higher education and in life beyond schooling, to students becoming so excited about Christ that they start bringing their parents to Church (resulting in multiple new families become baptized each year), the impact of these schools reaches deep into the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

 If money is tight and you are unable to contribute, help us by spreading the getting the word about our campaign. Thank you!

story:
English follows, scroll down..


Sakalakawel est une école communautaire dans la zone de Oban à Jacmel.
Ensemble avec des citoyens engagés de la communauté de Oban, ainsi qu'avec la participation venant de tous les coins du pays pour profiter de l'occasion pour une formation en construction écologique inspirée de Earthship Biotecture, nous poursuivons la construction d'un amphithéâtre culturel multi disciplinaire autosuffisant en eau et en électricité, et fait à base de matériaux recyclés.

Mais ce n'est pas tout! Cette construction servira de terrain de formation pour les membres d'une association Haitienne en construction (ATECO). Ensemble, Vladimir Bely (formateur/superviseur de chantier devenu expert en construction écologique), moi même et ATECO formons maintenant une branche de construction alternative pour répondre à la demande grandissante au pays d'Haïti.

La forme de l'immeuble est inspiré d'un modèle Earthship appelé 'La Fleur' qui a été construite 2 fois en Afrique. Nous avons simplifié ce modèle pour lui donner 2 salles de classe, 2 salles de toilette, et une scène de spectacle. C'est finalement un amphithéâtre creusé directement dans la montagne. Les gradins seront creusés à la mains en équipe dans la montagne, donnant une vue sur la scène, et sur la mer de Jacmel.

Une grande quantité de matériaux seront ramassés dans les rues, dans les ravins et sur les plages pour êtres recyclés dans la construction. Pneus, styromousse, bouteilles plastiques, et de verre.

Le terrain utilisé est familiale et appartient à Dieudonné Cyprien, un pilier de sa communauté et dans la continuation de notre école communautaire portant le nom de Sakalakawel. Il dirige l'équipe de soccer de Sakalakawel, et supervise les activités et programmes.

La construction a commencée en Février et Mars de 2014. La mise à niveau et creusage du sol ont été fait. Les murs ont commencés à êtres construits. Les prochains mois de constructions seront Février et Mars de 2015.

N'oubliez pas de consulter l'onglet 'Galerie' dans le haut de la page pour voir les photos et et nos autres vidéos!



Ce dont nous avons besoin:


Les fonds ramassés serviront à l'achat des outils, des matériaux, et aux dépenses de logistiques en transport de matériaux recyclés ainsi que pour la création d'une infrastructure adéquate à la formation d'ATECO et des autres participants venant d'autres zones du pays. 


La construction de Sakalakawel avance au rythme de l'énergie mise par ses participants et contributeurs. Si les objectifs financiers ne sont pas atteints, la construction se poursuivra avec les moyens disponibles et continuera à plus long terme.

Nous espérons récolter suffisamment de fonds pour compléter une des deux classes/toilettes, une des deux cellules botaniques créant une autonomie en eau, la scène de spectacle, et les gradins.

De cette façon l'école pourra reprendre ses activités dès Avril 2014. Le local anciennement utilisé  était loué et a été interrompu en Janvier 2014 dû à une hausse de loyer.

Cette campagne est une recherche de fonds sur le côté Canadien et c'est moi même (Marita Mariasine) qui sera responsable de les mettre au service du projet de manière efficace, et de façon à stimuler l'économie locale par la même occasion.

Sakalakawel est un pilier dans le mouvement de la construction écologique en Haïti, et crée des avenues dans la décentralisation de l'eau et d'électricité. 

Il continuera d'être un endroit où la communauté puisse se réunir, créer, apprendre, grandir. Une fois cette étape de la construction achevée, Sakalakawel sera un amphithéâtre qui pourra recevoir jusqu'à 400 personnes assises pour assister à des évènements communautaires, des échanges artistiques multidisciplinaires, et sera pour la communauté un point centrale pouvant transmettre des valeurs pour plusieurs générations à venir par ses nombreuses activités.


    Défis

    Sakalakawel ayant présentement comme infrastructure physique un bâtiment en construction sur un terrain vierge, nous ne somme malheureusement pas encore prêts pour accueillir la foule de gens de l'extérieur du pays souhaitant bénéficier de cette formation en Biotecture et cette expérience unique. Certains arrangements spéciaux peuvent êtres pris.

    Nous mettons toute l'énergie possible pour créer un site de formation et de campement communautaire pour les Haïtiens venant d'autres zones du pays qui nécessiteront  de se loger, baigner et cuisiner  près du site de construction. 


    D'autres façons d'aider

    Il est facile de contribuer à la construction de Sakalakawel!

    Faites un don en cliquant sur le bouton de cette page prévu à cet effet!

    Passez le mot sur cet évènement extraordinaire! Partagez en grand dans tous vos réseaux en utilisant l'outil de partage Indiegogo, sur FB et dans vos réseaux et attirez l'attention sur ce projet unique..

    Merci!!

    Pour de plus amples renseignements consultez http://ayitiini.wordpress.com/

    Cordialement,

    Marita Mariasine



    English


    Sakalakawel is a community school in Oban, just outside of Jacmel. Together with the committed citizens of the community of Oban, and participation coming from the four corners of the country to take advantage of the opportunity in a building training inspired by Earthship Biotecture, we carry on with the construction of a multi-disciplinary cultural amphitheatre which will be self-sufficient in water and electricity. It's base will be made mostly of recycled materials.


    But that’s not all! This construction will also serve as a training ground for members of the Haitian building association, ATECO. Together, Vladimir Bely (Haitian trainer/site supervisor who has become an expert in eco-building), myself and ATECO now form a branch of alternative building to respond to the growing demand in Haiti.

    The shape of the building is inspired by an Earthship model (the Flower design) which has been built twice in Africa. We simplified this model to give it 2 classrooms, 2 bathrooms and a performance stage. It is an amphitheater, dug directly into the mountain. The benches will be dug by hand into the hill of the mountain, giving a view of the stage, and the sea Jacmel.

    A large quantity of materials will be gathered from the streets, ravines and beaches to be recycled and used for the build, like tires, plastic and glass bottles, Styrofoam..

    The land used is family-owned and belongs to Dieudonné Cyprien, a pillar in his community and in the continuation of our community school which bears the name of Sakalakawel. He directs the Sakalakawel soccer team, and supervises programs and activities.

    Construction started in February and March of 2014. We dug and leveled the ground, and started building the walls. The next building months will be February and March of 2015.

    Don’t forget to consult the photos and videos by clicking on the ‘Galerie’ tab at the top of this page!


    What we need

    The collected funds will buy tools, construction materials, pay for transporting recycled materials as well as expenses linked to the creation of an infrastructure that will provide adequate training for ATECO and participants coming from other zones of the country.

    The building of Sakalakawel will move forward at the pace of the energy put into it by its participants and collaborators. If the financial objectives are not met, the construction will go on with the ressources available on a longer-term basis

    We hope to gather enough funds to complete one of the two classrooms/bathrooms, one of the two botanical cells (which will create an autonomous water supply), the performance stage, and the benches.

    This will allow the school to resume its activities from April 2014. The previous space used was rented and was interrupted last January 2014 due to an increase in rent.

    This campaign is a search for funds on the Canadian side. I (Marita Mariasine) will be responsible for efficiently allocating these funds to the project, in a way that also contributes to the local economy.

    Sakalakawel is a cornerstone in the sustainable building movement in Haiti and is creating local avenues for the decentralization of water and electricity.

    It will continue to be a place where the community can meet, create, learn and grow. Once this stage of the build is achieved, Sakalakawel will be an amphitheatre able to seat 400 people attending community events and multidisciplinary artistic exchanges! It will be and already is a central point where the community can impart values and knowledge for several generations to come, through its numerous activities.


    Challenges

    Sakalakawel currently displays as its physical infrastructure a building under construction on a virgin piece of land. Because of this we are unfortunately not yet ready to host large groups of people coming from outside the country wishing to benefit from this training in Biotecture and this unique experience. Certain special arrangements can be made.

    We are putting all the energy we can into creating a training site and community camp site for Haitians coming from other zones of the country, who require a place to sleep, bathe and cook, near the work site.


    Ways to help

    It is easy to contribute to the Sakalakawel build!

    Make a donation by clicking the donate button on this page!

    Spread the word about this extraordinary event! Share the information in all your networks by using the Indiegogo share tool and on FB in order to attract attention to this unique project..

    Thank you!!

    For more information check out http://ayitiini.wordpress.com/

    Kind regards,

    Marita Mariasine

story:
UPDATE:

So far, the tally of books that will be given to YOUTH, after fees and perks, is 225. This happens because of the many amazing people who got behind this project! 
Because of the amazing response from the youth who have already gotten the book, and the generous support surrounding this effort, I have decided to opt in for Indiegogo's option to make this an "In-Demand" page, which will keep it open for ongoing contributions. 
The more books we can give to YOUTH the greater the impact will be!

Short Summary

Thank you for taking the time to view GIVE 1 GET 1! 

I am Ricky Roberts III; author of five books, national speaker, and the founder of You Are Valued (YAV): a movement of valuing others that has reached 16 different countries and 34 states through community outreach, involvement, discussion, and inspiration.

This campaign is inspired by the 1000’s of young people that I have the privilege to speak with in a variety of settings and programs on a yearly basis.

What I Need & What You Get

I want to GIVE copies of my latest book, “Just for Youth”, to at least 100 youth (middle and high school age) that would not get them otherwise.  

 

Touching on everything from pursuing dreams, to being compassionate, to being true to one's self, "Just for Youth" will inspire young people to be their best in all aspects of life.  This book is packed with engaging content, accompanied by questions at the end of each section, that facilitate conversation and reflection.  

By GIVING to this campaign you will GET a signed copy of my latest book, “Just for Youth” (or more depending on your perk) and help make it possible for me to GIVE at least 100 (I hope even more) copies to youth. 

If the goal is exceeded, even more young people will benefit!

The Impact

As a contributor to this campaign, you will be putting a book of inspiration into the hands of young people who would not get them otherwise. 

 

 

 

 

By GIVING to our youth, you will be a part of offering them the inspiration, hope, guidance, and direction that could potentially change their life forever. Not to mention, you will be GETTING your own signed copy of “Just for Youth” to keep or give away (or more depending on the perk you pick).  If you just want to make it possible for me to GIVE books, there are perks for that, too.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the campaign with your friends, family, and colleagues. 

The more people that contribute to, and share this campaign, the more lives that will be changed!

On behalf of the many youth that will be impacted by your support, I thank you so much for making a difference.

*** Perks will be sent after the campaign ends. ***

story:
What is an interactive library for English language learners (ELL)?    

                               


Interactive: a hybrid of Little Free Library and interactive reading concepts, our library not only will function as an ELL resource but also will come to life as a conversation space for students and a resource for volunteer-based interactive reading events led by students in our vibrant non-profit community. To learn more about my previous experience in the U.S. with an interactive reading lab and Little Free Library (LFL), you may email me personally for file attachments to past conference presentations on my work in Louisville, KY, USA. You may also click on the following link sponsored by Project Literacy:

http://magazine.good.is/articles/project-literacy-little-libraries

Though our library initially will not adopt the "take one, leave one" concept of a Little Free Library, we hope that eventually our project will develop in this direction. For now, the key elements of LFL that we will adopt are peer-chosen texts, a comment space for peer feedback, and accessibility.

Accessible: rather than hosting a collection of unspecified-level English literature—which often can intimidate or overwhelm language learners—, our library will host level-specific texts from ELL-specific collections such as the Kapadokya ELT series. If we exceed our fundraising goal, then we would also like to supplement our fiction texts with TOEFL preparation materials, Turkish-English dictionaries, and other practice materials. A unique feature of our library is that it will be mobile, a feature that will enhance accessibility for students and open more possibilities for using our library as a campus and community resource.

                                                                               


Critical: a prerequisite of library use by students is the completion of a reading comprehension pretest on www.readtheory.org in order to assess proficiency level and, thus, direct students toward appropriate texts. Hopefully, this library will encourage students to utilize the website in order to boost reading levels in order to navigate new levels of library texts. Moreover, monthly interactive reading events involving the presentation of a selected text by students will highlight the unique benefits of learning English through sharing literature.

                                           


Other details:

Purchasing the texts-- A small collection (40) of Kapadokya ELT fiction, ranging from Stage 1 (beginner) to Stage 6 (advanced), recently has been purchased. However, due to the relative lack of English language literature here in Gaziantep,  the remainder of library texts will be purchased in Ankara during February and March 2016.

Sustaining the library--Professional feedback via participation at Konya Necmettin Erbakan University's 14th Annual Conference on Sustainability, Development, and Culture in May 2016 as well as the development of community partnerships will provide concrete ideas regarding how our library might adopt creative methods for sustaining its contents and functioning.


Why Gaziantep?

Given the increasing multiculturalism of our classrooms and communities here in Gaziantep, the importance of English language learning for mediation, peace-building, and international literacy is heightened. Your donation directly will contribute to developing a learning environment that forefronts the vitality of English in one of Turkey's most rapidly diversifying regions.

reading lab and Little Free Library (LFL), you may email me personally for file attachments to past conference presentations on my work in Louisville, KY, USA. You may also click on the following link sponsored by Project Literacy: http://magazine.good.is/articles/project-literacy-little-librariesThough our library initially will not adopt the "take one, leave one" concept of a Little Free Library, we hope that eventually our project will develop in this direction. For now, the key elements of LFL that we will adopt are peer-chosen texts, a comment space for peer feedback, and accessibility.
Accessible: rather than hosting a collection of
unspecified-level English literature—which often can intimidate or overwhelm
language learners—, our library will host level-specific texts from ELL-specific collections such as the
Kapadokya ELT series. If we exceed our fundraising goal, then we would also
like to supplement our fiction texts with TOEFL preparation materials,
Turkish-English dictionaries, and other practice materials. A unique feature of our library is that it will be mobile, a feature that will enhance accessibility for students and open more possibilities for using our library as a campus and community resource.                                                                                 
Critical: a prerequisite of
library use by students is the completion of a reading comprehension pretest on www.readtheory.org in order to assess
proficiency level and, thus, direct students toward appropriate texts.
Hopefully, this library will encourage students to utilize the website in order
to boost reading levels in order to navigate new levels of library texts. Moreover, monthly interactive reading events involving the presentation of a selected text by students will highlight the unique benefits of learning English through sharing literature.                                            
Other
details: 
Purchasing
the texts-- A small collection (40) of
Kapadokya ELT fiction, ranging from Stage 1 (beginner) to Stage 6 (advanced), recently has been purchased.
However, due to the relative lack of English language literature here in Gaziantep,  the remainder of library texts will be purchased in Ankara during February and March 2016. 
Sustaining
the library--Professional
feedback via participation at Konya Necmettin Erbakan University's 14th Annual Conference on Sustainability, Development, and Culture in May 2016 as well as the development of community partnerships will provide concrete ideas regarding how our library might adopt creative methods for sustaining its contents and functioning.Why Gaziantep?Given the increasing multiculturalism of our classrooms and communities here in Gaziantep, the importance of English language learning for mediation, peace-building, and international literacy is heightened. Your donation directly will contribute to developing a learning environment that forefronts the vitality of English in one of Turkey's most rapidly diversifying regions.

story:
The teaching resource for the 21st century

http://videotelling.com/


This book is the result of one man’s love for storytelling, his passion for teaching, and his obsession with YouTube. Jamie Keddie is an educator who, for the last decade, has been curating online videos and creating stories around them. His stories involve everything from curious pigs to sneezing baby pandas; from exploding watermelons to mystery objects falling from the sky; from internet addiction to online dishonesty, and (of course) internet cats.
 



Jamie Keddie is well-known for his ideas on video and storytelling. He has shared his expertise and insights with educators in over 40 countries. He gives plenary talks at international conferences and delivers practical workshops for teachers. Jamie is an established Oxford University Press author ("Images", 2009; "Online Video", 2014) and the founder of Lessonstream – the free resource site which is popular for its creative teaching ideas.
 


It seemed natural for Jamie to compile his video stories in a book for other teachers to enjoy with their own students. In December 2015, he launched this Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign to finance Videotelling – his first indie book publishing project. Thanks to his enthusiastic community, the campaign was an immediate hit.
 


In just three weeks, Jamie raised almost £9000. This allowed him to hire the best team of professionals to bring Videotelling to light. The result is nothing less than the perfect resource for the 21st century classroom. Videotelling is more than a book of stories. It is a refreshingly original approach to video and a novel way for anyone to tell a story.


 

About the book

  • 45 interactive stories to engage “screenagers” and other 21st century students.
  • Each story based on the narrative of an online video (viral videos, adverts, short films, etc.).
  • An accompanying website (videotelling.com) with links to all videos.
  • Ideas for linking stories to curricular subjects (art, science, citizenship, media studies, etc.).
  • Beautifully illustrated and designed for a great reading experience.
  • A useful appendix with practical advice and tips for teachers (storytelling techniques, technology issues, etc.).
  • Perfect for primary, secondary, and English language teachers.

What’s in it for teachers?

  • 45 video-based lesson plans to teach a wide range of subjects.
  • A teaching resource for waking up even the quietest students in your classroom.
  • Step-by-step instructions to get students listening, thinking, collaborating, communicating, problem solving, and making videos of their own.
  • Tons of inspiration to create your own Videotelling lessons and activities.
  • A handy guide to help you develop your own storytelling skills.
     


 

What other teachers are saying

“This book will make you look forward to your Monday morning lessons.”
Marga Homar, English language teacher

“In Videotelling, Jamie leaves his classroom door wide open – you experience his stories as his students would.”
Nick Bilbrough, storyteller and author

“A brilliantly practical series of lessons to liven up any classroom.”
Ben Goldstein, author of “Language Learning with Digital Video”
 

When will it be available?

Videotelling is currently available as an ebook from videotelling.com. The paperback will be out in Spring 2017.

story:
Who We Are

     Foremost, we would like to thank you for visiting our start-up campaign. We are a group of four students from The University of Tennessee, Knoxville who have taken on the task of raising money for JA BizTown of East Tennessee. All the donations we receive from this campaign will go directly to help JA BizTown by allowing three classrooms to spend a day there. Our group has decided to raise a goal of $1,500. This amount of money could help send three elementary/sixth grade classrooms through the JA BizTown Our Community program.

What is JA Biztown?       

Junior Achievement of East Tennessee is a non-profit organization whose goal is to "inspire and prepare young people to succeed in a global economy" (http://www.jaeasttennessee.org/about/).

Located in Clinton, Tennessee JA BizTown of East Tennessee is expected to impact the lives of over 8,500; 4th, 5th, or 6th grade students in 2018 alone. Before the kids get to go to the BizTown facility though, they must go through a five week classroom program where leaders from JA BizTown teach the instructors of each classroom exactly what the students need to learn before spending a day at the facility. The students are taught tasks such as: taxes, how to vote, and how businesses and governments can help shape a community.

Why are We Raising Money?

While BizTown is a great experience for kids, many schools and school districts can not afford to have this experience without the help of funding. As a full non-profit, BizTown uses major sponsors such as Chick-fil-a, Pilot, and Clayton Investments along with smaller donations given from campaigns like this to help keep JA of East Tennessee successfully running. It is important that JA BizTown stays running because this brings hope and excitement for the students futures. Some children will never be able to experience a day in BizTown. The donations that we receive will allow JA BizTown to help provide scholarships for the schools that cannot afford to pay. The cost per each school is $500.00 total. So by helping us raise $1,500.00, we will be helping three schools.

Who Do We Plan on Reaching?

The other part of JA is that it relies on support from the general public. This includes anyone from teachers, to politicians, to parents who want to see their students/children succeed in the future. We are hoping for an impact to this audience because we feel they will believe in the lives of their children's futures. This support helps JA BizTown provide a wonderful learning experience for children who can greatly benefit from the real world experience. This is what drives JA BizTown, real world experiences.  

What is JA BizTown like?

The facility is set with many real world, well-known companies outlining a large area. The students are then hired through the classroom program they go through before coming to BizTown and they spend the day working for these companies. They allow the children to work many different jobs. These vary from Chick Fil A, to City Hall, to the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Another aspect of this program is by teaching the children use of salaries. The students work for their paychecks and get paid twice a day. Each company has different salaries. The students are allowed to use them during their break at lunch and go to different companies and purchase items with the money they have made. For example, some items such as, cookies, sunglasses, stuffed animals, or JA BizTown t-shirts.

How will we be rewarding donors?  

These wonderful programs are what allow JA Biztown to be successful in teaching real world experiences while providing a fun and safe environment. They are only able to achieve such a goal with help from donations. That’s why we decided to provide certain perks to accommodate different sizes of donations. For instance if you donate one dollar you will get a shoutout with a virtual high-five, if you donate five dollars you will be rewarded with a JA BizTown pen, and if you’re just so generous to give twenty-five dollars you will be rewarded with a JA BizTown t-shirt. We are wanting to create neat incentives to give with our donors so they remember what they donated and what they received from us.

We would all like to thank you for your consideration in donating to our Campaign. If you have specific questions for us or for JA Biztown, please contact: Travis Aikman, taikman@vols.utk.edu or Callie Archer, JA BizTown President: callie@jaeasttennessee.org.

story:
Peppercorns is a small early learning center setup by a passionate group of local expat parents to provide a safe & fun learning environment for baby groups, kindergarden & preschool chilldren. The school is currently self funded, and has been running for 3 years.

The school has recently moved to a larger location, and have recently employed a Dutch teacher and a local Cambodian teacher/aid, and have plans to grow  depending on the amount of funds.  

We are currently raising funds to:

- complete renovations on the new property, and to make the grounds child safe

- build a large playground built from locally sourced wood, recyled materials tyres etc.  

- create a large sand pit, and purchase related toys & equipment

- purchase art & craft materials

The learning center is the first of a kind in the area, and will hopefully expand to accomodate more and more sponsored (ie low to no cost) positions for local village children.

The school will also be running a fund raising event  - a school fete - during the Cambodian Water Festival which will run between the 27-30th November 2012, and will be targetting expat familes from Phnom Penh (The capital) - to our region during the holiday.

I'm hoping that with the funds received from all my generous friends & the fete, we'll be able to create something special that will be enjoyed by kids for years to come.

story:
Well, the fantastic news is that my son Taylor, age 8, was accepted into the new specialized school. The challenging news is that I need to find a way to pay for it. I don't have $16,000 laying around, but am truly hoping for a miracle. Taylor is VERY delayed in speech and other areas. The school is uniquely qualified to address the many issues he faces. He NEEDS this to develop in to a more independent young adult, and going to this school NOW will greatly reduce the need for more expensive assisted living later in life.

 

Taylor has a dual diagnosis of Down Syndrome AND Autism with Sensory issues as well.

story:
The Story

I have always wanted to make a difference in the world, and going on a humanitarian trip was always a dream of mine. It has taken me a long time to get to this point, but I finally have an opportunity of a lifetime to go volunteer with HELP International in Tanzania for 10 weeks this summer. The HELP model facilitates substantive development programs overseas that change the lives of not only the community members with whom we work, but also the lives of our volunteers, interns, and In-Country Directors. We work in programs that encompass project development, capacity building, cultural immersion, community education, entrepreneurship, and public health. But I can't get there without your help.

How You Can Help

Help me reach my goal of raising $2,100 by:

  • Donating $5, $10, $25, $50, $100, or whatever you can! 100% of your donation will go towards the program costs. 
  • Even if you can't donate, spreading the word about this important work that HELP International does by sharing this link on Facebook, Twitter, or via email. Any action is better than inaction!
  • Look up my site (www.makeadifference2013.com) to receive updates on how your contribution is making a difference in Tanzania!   

Your Impact

This summer, from June 1 to August 17, I will be working to improve the lives of Tanzanians in Arusha and its surrounding area. Alongside 15-20 volunteers and local community members, I will be working on sustainable development projects that include:

·       Educating Tanzania - Education is the key to overcoming challenges in life, and without it those challenges remain or progress to epidemic proportions.  Tanzania is full of natural resources, that when utilized correctly, can greatly benefit communities. We will educate through community workshops of self-sustaining solutions that will provide clean drinking water, nutritious food, and sanitary environments more free of common diseases.

·       Community empowerment through business classes - A program that teaches basic business principles to the men and women of Arusha, empowering them to start their own businesses and successfully provide for their families.

·       Creating self-sustaining Orphanages – Many orphanages go without many of the necessities of life. And others are supported by outside sources hindering their potential and not solving the long term problem.  We as volunteers will help orphanages draw upon their talents and resource to help them set up a system to become self-sustaining in providing for all their needs. 

Any small donation will help improve the lives of Tanzanians, who, everyday, live without the basic necessities of life that most people in the world take advantage of. Clean water, food, a means to be able to provide for your family, and parents to love and provide for you, are just some of the things that HELP International aims to improve. Your donations will go directly towards sustainable development projects that Tanzanians will continue to use even after our brief four months in-country. 

Thank you for your support!

story:
Our Story

For the last five years, the Palestinian Circus School has been training children and youth in the West Bank in juggling, trapeze, acrobatics, clowning, and other circus arts. We began as volunteers with 10 students and very limited resources. Today, we train over 160 students a week and the number keeps growing. Our dream to build a professional circus school in Palestine is taking shape.

The school has recently received the donation of a 150-year-old house in the beautiful town of Birzeit. After months of work cleaning and renovating the abandoned building, we moved out of the basement office and training space we were renting from another school and opened the doors to our own office and initial training space in November. Now we need your help to complete the first suitable training facility we have ever had--a metal structure that is 17 meters wide and 9 meters high, big enough for our students to practice the most difficult circus arts safely. When finished, our building will be a community center with space for artists of all kinds to train and perform, and will allow us to take our first steps towards creating an internationally recognized professional circus school.

Impact

Circus? In Palestine? Is that really what Palestine needs? That was the most common question we faced in the beginning. By now, those familiar with the work of PCS are convinced, saying, Yes! A circus in Palestine!

The effect of the Israeli military occupation has been very difficult for young Palestinians, particularly since 2000. They witness their homes being unlawfully demolished, experience personal humiliation at checkpoints, suffer physical abuse and arbitrary detention and many carry the grief of having loved ones killed by the Israeli military. Moreover, they face the harsh reality of mounting responsibility in a tough economy with growing unemployment rates.

We are responding to these challenges by teaching young Palestinians the circus pedagogy to stimulate and develop their physical, mental, artistic, emotional, social and cognitive abilities. We are  convinced that circus will offer youth in Palestine and around the Middle East a brighter future.

Our building itself will also have an impact of it's own. It's a light, airy two-story house full of noise and life, with juggling batons scattered on the floor and trapezes hanging from the ceiling. We're working hard to renovate the building with integrity, ensuring that it's environmentally friendly and that our school fits into a larger plan to reinvigorate the town center of Birzeit.


What We Need & What You Get

The $25,000 we hope to raise here on Indie GoGo will kick off our fundraising for the addition to our building. If we surpass this goal, every dollar we raise will go toward the total cost of the building and circus equipment. If you join our campaign, we'd like to thank you with an assortment of prizes from t-shirts to a unique piece of Palestinian embroidery. Every donation helps us get closer to our goal.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word about our campaign. Share this campaign by e-mail or Facebook, and,  if you're in the area, come out and see our shows!

story:
Girls Rock Camp Vancouver:

“Girls Rock Camp Vancouver is a non-profit society that builds self esteem in female youth through music creation and performance. By providing workshops and technical training, we create leadership opportunities, cultivate a supportive community of peers and mentors, and encourage social change and the development of life skills.”

 Our 2013 Summer Session marked our fifth anniversary!

What Happens At Camp?

We provide a supportive space for 30-35 female youth to help build self-esteem through music creation and performance. Throughout the week, campers learn a key instrument and are coached through the experience of playing within a band setting. Campers also attend workshops with talented female mentors in subjects such as Songwriting, Self-Defense, Image and Identity, Zine-Making, Screen-Printing and Gear Education including gear set up and maintenance.
 
Also happening at camp are performances by experienced female musicians, on-site conflict management for bands, and one on one instrument instruction sessions with the youth.
 
We are a social justice based organization and achieve some of our goals through:
  • a low barrier, sliding scale tuition rate so families and guardians can choose what they can afford. No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.
  • providing delicious and nutritious warm lunches to campers and volunteers as well as snacks, every day.

The week finishes with the ultimate experience of playing a live show at the multi-purpose Rio Theatre, in front of an audience of family, friends and screaming fans.

We are a member of the GRCA, an international coalition of Rock Camps.

Why are we fundraising?

Girls Rock Camp Vancouver's 2013 Summer Camp session filled within a week. Our waitlist filled a day after that, it always does.

As we finish out fifth year of programming we feel the obvious need for stable, affordable, year round programming and (hopefully), another camp session each year.

We are 100% volunteer driven and our unpaid organizing crew spends thousands of hours a year striving to make this the funnest, most rewarding experience for both campers and volunteers. To be honest, we're a bit tired and we need your help taking the edge off of worrying about cash flow, and running into financial barriers when trying to move forward with partnerships and programs.

Money raised will help us to:
  • Build a new website so we can maximize efficiency and communications.
  • Provide capital so that we can invest in community partnerships immediately, without worrying about how we will pay for it. This will allow us to reach as many youth as possible in the lower mainland.
  • Continue providing full meals during camp.
  • Continue to be a low-barrier camp with a completely sliding scale tuition fee.

*Please note that while we are a registered non-profit society in British Columbia, we are NOT a registered charity and cannot issue tax receipts.

Perks!

  • For $20 we'll send you a thank you card and a really big tote bag with the 2013 logo, designed by Lindsey Hampton! Plus, we'll thank you on our site.
  • For $50, Aili Meutzner will do a drawing of your cat's aura. Intriguing! Also, we'll send you a card and thank you on our site.
  • For $100 you'll get a pair of Oakley Garage Rock sunglasses, a card from us, and a thanks on the site. They're worth $155 and we only have one pair! (Donated kindly by the Watch It! store) 
  • For $100 you'll get a Fruitz watch in the "grape" colour scheme, a card from us, and a thanks on the site. It's worth $225 and we only have one!   (Donated kindly by the Watch It! store) 
  • For $60 you get a Kroma 10 piece 60ml artist's acrylic set! Made in Vancouver. And you get a card and an internet thank you.
  • For $40 you get the most amazing fuzzy zebra print guitar strap from Andrea of Nu Sensae. It is the coolest. And it will make your bass extra punk. Plus you get the card and internet thank you.

Here are some exciting NEW things!:

  • For $20 you get a 2013 GRCV T-shirt! Like the tote bags but on a white fruit of the loom tshirt instead! We have: youth medium and large, adult small, medium, and large. Logo by the very talented Lindsey Hampton. 
  • For $40 you get a cassette tape of the 2013 GRCV Showcase. It's amazing. It'll blow your mind. Put together by our friend Emily Morgan. Plus a thank you card and a thanks on our site!
  • For $80 you will get a very limited edition single-sided hand-poured mono 45 rpm record of the 2012 hit GRCV song by Hobgoblin titled "Lost It". Only 5 ever! You can watch this cool video of it being made and listen to it (and buy, if you are so inclined) on our bandcamp page. The quality of each will vary. Emily Morgan is amazing and MADE THESE BY HAND!
  • For $100 you will get a double-sided lathe-cut mono 45 rpm record. Quality is much better than the hand-poured, but they're a lot more delicate.  It's Hobgoblin - Lost It b/w City Rockers - Walking Around The City. You can listen to both of these on our bandcamp page. Only eight of these available and they are BEAUTIFUL. Again, HAND MADE by Emily Morgan.

 

 

Cassettes of the 2013 GRCV Showcase!

 

 Pictured here: Kroma Artist's Acrylics set, Oakley glasses, GIANT tote bag, raddest bass strap ever, raddest 7" record ever, purplest watch ever.

story:
We Are Starting A Movement.

Help us, Project Green Room, mobilize college students across the country to demand action by our elected officials to fix the debt & deficit. By educating and engaging students in a fun & non-partisan way, we can make this happen. 

About Us:

PGR, a non-partisan 501(c)(4), was founded in 2013 by two college students at Miami University in order to educate and engage apathetic college students on the fiscal issues such as debt, deficit, and tax reform. Specifically advocating for fiscal responsibility. PGR is bridging the gap between apathetic young voters and the political process. Educating students across the nation in ways that are captivating, relatable, and fun, PGR  demonstrates how fiscal responsibility can positively impact our future.

Project Green Room is a catalyst for college students to get involved on these issues and a vehicle to advance our generation's ideas into reality. By staying indifferent on the social issues, we make it easier for college students to engage on these issues without having to sift through party lines. Through social media, engaging speakers, events such as happy hours, online marketing, and grassroots efforts, PGR will guide a generation's political will to fix the fiscal problems we face.

We were recently featured in USA Today: http://www.usatodayeducate.com/staging/index.php/ccp/miami-university-students-launch-nonprofit-to-engage-college-students-in-fiscal-policy

Your money will go to:

  • All costs associated to events such as speaker fees, venue costs, and promotional materials.
  • Advertising on social media, the internet, and grassroots tactics all cost money but are all very affective ways we can make a difference. As college students we know where to advertise and the type of content that will be poignant and effective.
  • All costs associated with spreading to as many college campuses as possible. Paying campus directors stipends in order to hire the best students possible, promotional & outreach costs associated to this specific goal, research costs, etc.
  • Media production, such as videos and info graphics used to educate students.
  • Operational costs that keep the lights on such as hosting of the website, annual legal & regulatory fees, fees for accounting & database software, petty cash uses that may occur spontaneously, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please like us on facebook, facebook.com/projectgreenroom, and follow us on twitter, @projectgrnroom. Please check out our website as well, projectgreenroom.org.

Please share this with everyone you know and help us reach our goal!

Inquiries: projectgrnroom@gmail.com

Disclosure: We have applied and are awaiting for 501(c)(4) non-profit status with the IRS. Contributions to 501(c)(4) non-profits are not tax deductible.

story:
Disclaimer: All images of the Funcube Dongle SDR are copyright of FUNcube Satellite project.

Who Are We?            

We are two students in Connecticut who are passionate about science, mathematics, engineering, and technology. We plan to construct an advanced software-based radio telescope, and we need your help to raise money.

Purpose

The telescope will be used to monitor and record the radio wave emissions from interstellar objects for the purpose of scientific analysis and academic application. This campaign is step one of three in an elaborate project. It consists of a prototype that will serve as a testing platform for all software systems and allow the building and testing of vital hardware to take place prior to construction of the full array. The money will go toward the receiver software and associated hardware, the three computers needed to run the software, and other recording and testing equipment.  

A Basic Theory of Operation

The following list describes what happens when this prototype receives a test signal:

1. The wire antenna captures a signal from a test source. 

2. The signal travels down a 75 ohm coaxial cable to the Funcube Dongle Pro Plus receiver (FCD+), where it is fed into its on board Low Noise Amplifier (LNA). 

3. After the LNA amplifies the signal it sends it to the Radio Frequency (RF) filter, which puts it through a number of Intermediate Frequency (IF) filters and amplifiers as pictured in the screenshot below.  

4. RF spectrum and amplitude graphs similar to the one below are generated from the output signal of the 6th IF amplifier.

5. The signal is then sent from the computer's audio card to several locations simultaneously: a central audio mixing board, an audio amplification system, an audio backup recorder, a visual audio monitor, and a digital strip chart recorder as pictured in the block diagram below.

6. The final results will be represented on a chart similar to the one below (sample data used):

What Else Can You Do?

Monetary donations are not the only way you can help. Please share the fundraiser through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and other social media platforms. Additionally, if you have helpful advice or equipment (or another reason to contact us), please email us at aoaproject@gmail.com.

story:
The Santa Teresa School Needs Your Help! 

On July 26th a group of 9 people are headed to Costa Rica on a service trip. We've partnered with the Santa Teresa school in Costa Rica to provide much needed support. 

Our mission is to inspire kids through art & physical education. The Santa Teresa school has never had the funds to include art and physical ed in their curriculum. 

We need your help to raise funds so that we can greatly impact the lives of each student.

Your support will provide:

  • School library
  • Art supplies
  • Athletic equipment

In order to accomplish our mission we need $3,000 in donations. This will provide us with enough to achieve our set goals & fund the art & physical education programs for the rest of 2013.

story:
Hi all,

On July 30, 2013, Adrienne Pagac was arrested for singing in the State Capitol of Madison, WI, and charged with Unlawful Assembly. Like fellow Solidarity Singalong Singers, Adrienne is fighting the charge! We refuse to abide by this attempt by Scott Walker's government to erode the rights and protections guaranteed by the First Amendment. 

For more information about the arrests, please read this article: http://bit.ly/137vDKV

For a video, please click here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UUIIlr5AGdg

Lawyer's fees are $100/hour. Any financial contribution you can provide would be greatly appreciated!

Finally, for more information about the Solidarity Singalong, please visit: 

https://www.facebook.com/SolidaritySingAlong

Thank you for all your help!
