story:
INNOVATION THAT GIVES REFUGEES A TICKET FOR A BETTER FUTURE

60 million people worldwide are displaced against their will. Many end up in camps and stay there on average for 12 years according to the UNHCR.

Most countries only allow temporary settlements hence no fixed buildings. That's why millions of displaced people have to survive in tents and without access to adequate schools or medical wards.

The best way to give displaced people in camps a new beginning is providing them access to adequate shelter, education and health.

In order to tackle this we needed a new approach and a new concept. International shelter experts of leading organisations, civil engineers, architects, researchers and many professionals joined us in the quest for a low-cost innovative solution.


WHAT WE NEED

We need 37K Euro (or about 41K USD) to produce a real scale model in a real environment that will be used for final evaluations and accreditation. This real scale model will be donated to a community centre for young refugees without parents or guardianship.

After 14 months of research, development, simulations, prototyping, evaluations by shelter experts and testing, we are ready to start a production line that will deliver our solution at low cost so we can make that crucial difference for many forcibly displaced people. Your contribution will help get maggie to market.

WE NEED THIS CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN BECAUSE WE WANT TO BRING THESE SHELTERS TO THE MARKET AT COST. 

RIGHT NOW!

Millions of displaced people will endure extreme cold during the winter because all they have are tents. Snow and frost is a reality in many refugee camps and can have long-term detrimental affects on health.

It’s a key reason why displaced people have a disproportionately high rate of mortality, diseases and mental illness. Almost half of all displaced people are in a state of extreme vulnerability. A number of the causes for diseases amongst refugees are preventable by providing basic protection against the elements.

EXPERTS SAY THIS IS A CRITICAL GAME-CHANGER

Until now, we've been stuck with tents because most countries do not allow permanent settlements. 

So we challenged the status quo and designed a shelter that is not permanent yet has all the virtues of a modern building. 

We did field assessments, researched climatic conditions and studied materials available near refugee camps. We listed the elements that cause discomfort, looked at the contributing factors and set measurable targets. Some of the targets are the same as school buildings in Belgium. Next, we set out to address all the shortcomings of tents, one-by-one, 30 different criteria in total.

The result is Maggie - a sturdy shelter that you can set up within a day and fill up the next day with local materials to create optimal temperatures (between 16 - 27 c°) with little or no need for additional cooling or heating.

A key advantage of the maggie shelter is that free and readily available materials like sand, organic materials or plastic waste can be used for insulation and stability. These features help keep purchase and transport costs down.


Hi, my name is Bart Peeters

I am one of the founders of the maggie-program. I have lived and worked extensively in developing countries where I coordinated large supply, educational and health programs. Equally, I coordinated disaster relief operations around the world.

When disaster strikes, we're fairly quick to provide tents and other basics. Displaced people stay in camps on average 12 years according to the UN. It's disturbing to witness those that have to survive in tents. It's hard to witness that 2/3 of the kids in camps don't even have access to any education or medical care.

This became our quest, to develop a temporary but durable and equipped shelter with the virtues of a modern school, community centre or medical ward ... and for little cost. A quest that demanded a complete different approach, innovation, abundant research and collaboration between many experts.

We paid personally 60% of the development costs and 40% was provided by a government fund. We are also blessed with the abundant support and expertise we received pro bono. We're almost there but we have one-off production costs before they can roll of the production line so we ask for help.

This is not about making money as the maggie shelter will be sold at cost. It's about that last crucial push we need to make it happen.

Every donation counts. The Crowdfunding magic is that many people give little sums to make it happen. Many thanks for your consideration.


QUALITY CONSTRUCTION AT A COST LOWER THAN THAT OF A TENT?

Tents are cheap to procure but have a short life span. With little insulation, they require extra heating or cooling. That means that a tent has higher cost of ownership than our maggie.

Research shows that refugees spend much of their modest income or savings on buying fuel or coal to warm their tent in winter. The heating of large tents costs many times the initial procurement cost over a 15 year period.


WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES

This next step is to get our maggie accredited by the leading UN & aid organisations. It is a pre-requisite to be able to secure future orders so that they can start rolling off the production line and into refugee camps.

This particular maggie shelter will be delivered to a community centre for young refugees without parents or guardianship.

Allocation of costs:

1. Five new aluminium extrusion moulds for the construction elements (one time investment)

2. Cost of materials and installation of the maggie

3. Stability, safety and users-tests by accredited engineers

4. Production of extra features such as solar & electricity components and an insulated, floating floor

5. Evaluation of this proof-of-concept version by international shelter experts from leading organizations + product brochure

Once they roll of the production line the cost for a 93 m2 school or medical ward is 14,500 Euro or 15,700 USD.


PURPOSES

The research and prototype was the results of collaboration between different shelters experts from leading organizations, researchers, civil engineers and architects. That means that we developed a solution based upon the specific needs of these organizations. We designed maggie to serve for 4 critical activities:

1. Medical wards & health posts

Refugees have a high rate of disease and mortality. Maggie creates a solid structure to support medical equipment and supplies necessary for treatment. It helps regulate temperatures to be more conducive to recovery. Hygiene is critical here, so the canvas we selected can be cleaned with the harsh products used by medical teams to prevent the spread of infection.

2. Schools

Education is often the only hope and ticket for change refugee children have. Schools also play a vital role in educating children about health and hygiene. We can deliver refurbished computers and network / solar solutions with these maggies.

3. Community Centres

Community centres have multiple purposes. Our focus is on learning adults skills so refugees can become self-reliant, earn a living and make marketable products. Skills and knowledge also give refugees an extra asset when they return to their home country and rebuild their lives.

3. Medical wards & health posts

Refugees have a high rate of disease and mortality. Many refugee camps are located in regions with extreme temperatures. 

4. Temperature-controlled warehouses

Food and drugs deteriorate when exposed to sun and heat. Our well-insulated, energy-efficient shelters are the solution - preventing damage and mould, repelling dust, insects and rodents that are attracted to the goods commonly stored here and are more secure against theft.

YOUR DONATION = TANGIBLE, LASTING IMPACT

Today, an estimated 4,5 million people live in camps. The UN quotes that every day another 42,500 new refugees arrive.

Thomas Koch / shutterstock

Less than 30% of kids in camps have access to education!

In the midst of conflict or sustained poverty, education for the victims and displaced people is often seen as secondary to the struggle for food, aid and shelter. Providing education for children and skills training for adults helps refugees get back on their feet when they return home by developing competences that allow them to build a better future. Yet experience has shown that small refugee populations receiving little support, often prove capable of developing some sort of sustainability within a reasonably short amount of time. Equally, the UN reports that refugees with an education often provide the leadership in rebuilding communities. Self-reliance is key. Educated refugees also contribute greatly to sustained peaceful coexistence between factions and the economical development of a region after conflict.

Health issues due to the cold

At temperatures below 12°C, blood tends to thicken and cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, circulatory and respiratory diseases rise sharply. Temperatures drop drastically at night in high-altitude regions. Frost, snow and storms occur even in arid and semi-arid areas. Tents provide little protection against the brutal elements of nature. Refugees rarely have access to energy sources. They burn rubbish and any organic materials they can find in the proximity of camps. It inflicts respiratory diseases, which are prominent among refugees. The scramble for organic materials has an major ecological impact on the area and often causes conflict with the local residents.

Health issues due to heat

Exposure to heat can cause cardiovascular, cerebrovascular and respiratory diseases. Heat-related illness occurs when our bodies can no longer transfer enough heat to keep us cool. Excess heat causes rashes, swelling, dehydration, exhaustion and heat-stroke. Pregnant women, newborn babies and elderly people are particularly at risk. Women in refugee camps experience worse pregnancy outcomes, including increased fetal mortality, low birth weight, premature labour, post-natal complications and infections.

The need for safety amongst refugees

The refugee population is a mosaic of individuals, each with a personal history. They reconstitute their complex societies in the refugee camps and take with them the ethnic, cultural and religious rituals and convictions of their home country. The scarce resources and challenges for survival further exacerbate the divisional tension amongst refugees. Creating safe refuges within a camp for those at risk is a demanding task, especially given the fact that hosting countries only allow for temporary settlements. Still today, tents make up the vast majority of the shelters and they provide little protection against intruders.

Peter Casaer

WE GOT THE RIGHT ATTENTION

A number of leading aid agencies have committed for the evaluation of the proof-of-concept model, further collaboration and joint-program funding. 

We also had abundant coverage in the press and national TV. Kindly visit our website for further info: www.maggie-program.org



WHY WE GOT INVOLVED

Bart Peeters worked in logistics, education,health programs and in disaster relief across Africa, Middle East and Asia for 25 years. He witnessed that tents used for medical treatment, schools and storage of vital supplies are not fit for purpose. Benjamin, Matthias & Inge - experienced civil engineers from DMOA Architects & Engineers – translated Barts idea into an innovative product. Over 30 experts from various disciplines joined in the following months to shape the maggie.

Those that shaped the maggie; civil engineers: Martijn, Inge, Kjell, Matthias, Benjamin - Architects: Hans, Maria, Dries - Technical drawings: Diego, Johan - Research, Simuations & Testing: Centextbel (Ine, Guy), University of Louvain civil engineering department, Phyb (Jelle, Wout), Paridaens Engineering, SRU Shelter research unit of the Red Cross - Companies: Vervaeke windscreen, Vermako Greenhouse Constructions, Flandria Aluminium, Argex Insulation. This campaign was largely done by volunteers: Robin, Mimi, Daniel, Frederik, Benjamin. 

maggie-program.org is a non-profit organisation registered in Belgium that has signed the good governance policy (accountability & transparency). Bart Peeters heads up the program with his experience in the humanitarian, development and disaster relief world and having managed global Public Private Partnerships with the UN and the International Federation of the Red Cross. Please contact Bart Peeters for any enquiries; bart.peeters@maggie-program.org

Interested in Corporate Sponsorship? We provide invoices for contributions and offer services such as personal acknowledgement, PR, CSR and employee engagement opportunities.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Help us with this last, crucial step to make this happen. Let's give displaced people a ticket for a new beginning. You can also help us by promoting this campaign: share it on your social media.

Help us with this last, crucial step to get accredited and be able to secure and produce our first orders.

Let's give displaced people a ticket for a new beginning. Thank you for helping to make this happen.
story_txt:
INNOVATION
THAT GIVES REFUGEES A TICKET FOR A BETTER FUTURE

60
million people worldwide are displaced against their will. Many end
up in camps and stay there on average for 12 years according to the
UNHCR.

Most
countries only allow temporary settlements hence no fixed buildings.
That's why millions of displaced people have to survive in tents and
without access to adequate schools or medical wards.

The
best way to give displaced people in camps a new beginning is
providing them access to adequate shelter, education and health. 


In
order to tackle this we needed a new approach and a new concept.
International shelter experts of leading organisations, civil
engineers, architects, researchers and many professionals joined us
in the quest for a low-cost innovative solution. 
WHAT WE NEEDWe need 37K Euro (or about 41K USD) to produce a real scale model in a real environment that will be used for final evaluations and accreditation. This real scale model will be donated to a community centre for young refugees without parents or guardianship.After 14 months of research, development, simulations, prototyping, evaluations by shelter experts and testing, we are ready to start a production line that will deliver our solution at low cost so we can make that crucial difference for many forcibly displaced people. Your contribution will help get maggie to market.WE NEED THIS CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN BECAUSE WE WANT TO BRING THESE SHELTERS TO THE MARKET AT COST. RIGHT NOW!Millions of displaced people will endure extreme cold during the winter because all they have are tents. Snow and frost is a reality in many refugee camps and can have long-term detrimental affects on health.It’s a key reason why displaced people have a disproportionately high rate of mortality, diseases and mental illness. Almost half of all displaced people are in a state of extreme vulnerability. A number of the causes for diseases amongst refugees are preventable by providing basic protection against the elements.EXPERTS SAY THIS IS A CRITICAL GAME-CHANGERUntil now, we've been stuck with tents because most countries do not allow permanent settlements. So we challenged the status quo and designed a shelter that is not permanent yet has all the virtues of a modern building. We did field assessments, researched climatic conditions and studied materials available near refugee camps. We listed the elements that cause discomfort, looked at the contributing factors and set measurable targets. Some of the targets are the same as school buildings in Belgium. Next, we set out to address all the shortcomings of tents, one-by-one, 30 different criteria in total.

The
result is Maggie - a sturdy shelter that you can set up within a day
and fill up the next day with local materials to create optimal
temperatures (between 16 - 27 c°) with little or no need for
additional cooling or heating.A
key advantage of the maggie shelter is that free and readily
available materials like sand, organic materials or plastic waste can
be used for insulation and stability. These features help keep
purchase and transport costs down. 




Hi, my name is Bart Peeters

I am one of the founders of the
maggie-program. I have lived and worked extensively in developing
countries where I coordinated large supply, educational and health
programs. Equally, I coordinated disaster relief operations around
the world. 


When disaster strikes, we're fairly
quick to provide tents and other basics. Displaced people stay in
camps on average 12 years according to the UN. It's disturbing to
witness those that have to survive in tents. It's hard to witness
that 2/3 of the kids in camps don't even have access to any education
or medical care. 


This became our quest, to develop a
temporary but durable and equipped shelter with the virtues of a
modern school, community centre or medical ward ... and for little
cost. A quest that demanded a complete different approach,
innovation, abundant research and collaboration between many experts.

We paid personally 60% of the
development costs and 40% was provided by a government fund. We are
also blessed with the abundant support and expertise we received pro
bono. We're almost there but we have one-off production costs before
they can roll of the production line so we ask for help.

This is not about making money as the
maggie shelter will be sold at cost. It's about that last crucial
push we need to make it happen.

Every donation counts. The Crowdfunding
magic is that many people give little sums to make it happen. Many
thanks for your consideration.QUALITY
CONSTRUCTION AT A COST LOWER THAN THAT OF A TENT?

Tents
are cheap to procure but have a short life span.  With little
insulation, they require extra heating or cooling. That means that a
tent has higher cost of ownership than our maggie.

Research
shows that refugees spend much of their modest income or savings on
buying fuel or coal to warm their tent in winter. The heating of
large tents costs many times the initial procurement cost over a 15
year period.WHERE YOUR MONEY GOESThis next step is to get our maggie accredited by the leading UN & aid organisations. It is a pre-requisite to be able to secure future orders so that they can start rolling off the production line and into refugee camps.This particular maggie shelter will be delivered to a community centre for young refugees without parents or guardianship.Allocation
of costs:

1. Five new aluminium extrusion moulds for the construction elements (one time investment)
2.
Cost of materials and installation of the maggie
3.
Stability, safety and users-tests by accredited engineers
4.
Production of extra features such as solar & electricity components and an
insulated, floating floor
5.
Evaluation of this proof-of-concept version by international shelter
experts from leading organizations + product brochure

Once they roll of the production line the cost for a 93 m2 school or medical ward is 14,500
Euro or 15,700 USD.

PURPOSES

The research and prototype was the results of collaboration between different shelters experts from leading organizations, researchers, civil engineers and architects. That means that we developed a solution based upon the specific needs of these organizations. We
designed maggie to serve for 4 critical activities:

1.
Medical wards & health posts
Refugees
have a high rate of disease and mortality. Maggie creates a solid
structure to support medical equipment and supplies necessary for
treatment. It helps regulate temperatures to be more conducive to
recovery. Hygiene is critical here, so the canvas we selected can be
cleaned with the harsh products used by medical teams to prevent the
spread of infection.

2. Schools
Education
is often the only hope and ticket for change refugee children have.
Schools also play a vital role in educating children about health and
hygiene. We can deliver refurbished computers and network / solar solutions with these maggies.

3. Community
Centres
Community
centres have multiple purposes. Our focus is on learning adults
skills so refugees can become self-reliant, earn a living and make
marketable products. Skills and
knowledge also give refugees an extra asset when they return to their
home country and rebuild their lives.

3. Medical
wards & health posts
Refugees
have a high rate of disease and mortality. Many refugee camps are
located in regions with extreme temperatures. 

4.
Temperature-controlled warehouses
Food
and drugs deteriorate when exposed to sun and heat. Our
well-insulated, energy-efficient shelters are the solution -
preventing damage and mould, repelling dust, insects and rodents that
are attracted to the goods commonly stored here and are more secure
against theft.YOUR DONATION = TANGIBLE, LASTING IMPACTToday, an estimated 4,5 million people live in camps. The UN quotes that every day another 42,500 new refugees arrive.Thomas Koch / shutterstock

Less
than 30% of kids in camps have access to education!

In
the midst of conflict or sustained poverty, education for the victims
and displaced people is often seen as secondary to the struggle for
food, aid and shelter. Providing education for children and skills
training for adults helps refugees get back on their feet when they
return home by developing competences that allow them to build a
better future. Yet experience has shown that small refugee
populations receiving little support, often prove capable of
developing some sort of sustainability within a reasonably short
amount of time. Equally, the UN reports that refugees with an
education often provide the leadership in rebuilding communities.
Self-reliance is key. Educated refugees also contribute greatly to
sustained peaceful coexistence between factions and the economical
development of a region after conflict.

Health
issues due to the cold
At
temperatures below 12°C, blood tends to thicken and cardiovascular,
cerebrovascular, circulatory and respiratory diseases rise sharply.
Temperatures drop drastically at night in high-altitude regions.
Frost, snow and storms occur even in arid and semi-arid areas. Tents
provide little protection against the brutal elements of nature.
Refugees rarely have access to energy sources. They burn rubbish and
any organic materials they can find in the proximity of camps. It
inflicts respiratory diseases, which are prominent among refugees.
The scramble for organic materials has an major ecological impact on
the area and often causes conflict with the local residents. 


Health
issues due to heat

Exposure
to heat can cause cardiovascular, cerebrovascular and respiratory
diseases. Heat-related illness occurs when our bodies can no longer
transfer enough heat to keep us cool. Excess heat causes rashes,
swelling, dehydration, exhaustion and heat-stroke. Pregnant women,
newborn babies and elderly people are particularly at risk. Women in
refugee camps experience worse pregnancy outcomes, including
increased fetal mortality, low birth weight, premature labour,
post-natal complications and infections.

The
need for safety amongst refugees

The
refugee population is a mosaic of individuals, each with a personal
history. They reconstitute their complex societies in the refugee
camps and take with them the ethnic, cultural and religious rituals
and convictions of their home country. The scarce resources and
challenges for survival further exacerbate the divisional tension
amongst refugees. Creating safe refuges within a camp for those at
risk is a demanding task, especially given the fact that hosting
countries only allow for temporary settlements. Still today, tents
make up the vast majority of the shelters and they provide little
protection against intruders.Peter CasaerWE GOT THE RIGHT ATTENTIONA number of leading aid agencies have committed for the evaluation of the proof-of-concept model, further collaboration and joint-program funding. We also had abundant coverage in the press and national TV. Kindly visit our website for further info: www.maggie-program.org



WHY
WE GOT INVOLVED

Bart
Peeters worked in logistics, education,health programs and in
disaster relief across Africa, Middle East and Asia for 25 years. He
witnessed that tents used for medical treatment, schools and storage
of vital supplies are not fit for purpose. Benjamin, Matthias &
Inge - experienced civil engineers from DMOA Architects &
Engineers –  translated Barts idea into an innovative product. Over
30 experts from various disciplines joined in the following months to
shape the maggie.Those that shaped the maggie; civil engineers: Martijn, Inge, Kjell, Matthias, Benjamin - Architects: Hans, Maria, Dries - Technical drawings: Diego, Johan - Research, Simuations & Testing: Centextbel (Ine, Guy), University of Louvain civil engineering department, Phyb (Jelle, Wout), Paridaens Engineering, SRU Shelter research unit of the Red Cross - Companies: Vervaeke windscreen, Vermako Greenhouse Constructions, Flandria Aluminium, Argex Insulation. This campaign was largely done by volunteers: Robin, Mimi, Daniel, Frederik, Benjamin. 

maggie-program.org
is a non-profit organisation registered in Belgium that has signed
the good governance policy (accountability & transparency). Bart
Peeters heads up the program with his experience in the humanitarian,
development and disaster relief world and having managed global
Public Private Partnerships with the UN and the International
Federation of the Red Cross. Please contact Bart Peeters for any
enquiries; bart.peeters@maggie-program.org

Interested
in Corporate Sponsorship? We provide invoices for contributions and
offer services such as personal acknowledgement, PR, CSR and employee
engagement opportunities.OTHER
WAYS TO HELP

Help
us with this last, crucial step to make this happen. Let's give
displaced people a ticket for a new beginning. You
can also help us by promoting this campaign: share it on your social media.

Help
us with this last, crucial step to get accredited and be able to
secure and produce our first orders. 


Let's
give displaced people a ticket for a new beginning. Thank
you for helping to make this happen.

story:
Don't send food; it only lasts a day.  Please send us education; it lasts a lifetime!

—Ralph Lapointe, Mayor, Ganthier, Haiti

After the earthquake in 2010, everyone wanted to help Haiti.  Maybe you, like many others, sent a donation.  But perhaps you wondered, would your contribution really make any lasting difference?  How could you be sure that your money would be used effectively and not wasted?

In Ganthier, Foundation For Peace (FFP) did not presume to tell the Haitians what they needed; we asked. The Ganthier provincial government responded that there was no vocational school in the entire region, and they desperately needed one to lift themselves out of poverty.  They were willing to donate five acres of land if FFP would build an educational complex there.  Community members have said that the educational complex is "the answer to our prayers." Many will literally walk several miles from their home to the site, just to volunteer their labor. The vocational school is aptly named "Lekòl Pwofesyonèl Men nan Men" (Hand-in-Hand Professional School).

Thanks in large part to volunteer mission teams from groups such as Konekte and Westerly Road Church, the first floor of the vocational school building is now essentially complete, but the second floor remains to be built.  Funds are needed now so that the school can be completed in 2013.  FFP is committed to finishing the construction, but if funds are not raised now then the completion date will be postponed to 2014 or later, and the students' education will be correspondingly delayed.

If you want to do more than just donate a few dollars towards temporary relief, and want to be part of a long-term solution, then supporting the construction of this school is one of the best ways we know of doing it.

What We Need

Volunteer missions teams are expected to provide about $100,000 in 2013 towards the completion of the school building. However, we need funds to pay Haitian workers to continue the construction when volunteers are not around. The estimated cost of labor for the second floor of the school building is $30,000, and that is what we are aiming to raise with the current campaign.

Ideally, we would like to raise $80,000, because then we will have funds for the other needs of the educational complex, such as solar energy and a water supply.

If we raise less than $30,000, then the amount raised will still be used to build as much of the second floor as we have funds for, but construction will stall when the money runs out, until volunteer teams arrive to resume work.

 

FAQ: Why Should I Trust FFP?

If you don't already have some healthy skepticism towards NGOs working in Haiti, then you ought to develop some!  We encourage you to ask penetrating questions of any NGO that you donate towards, including our own.

When you choose a non-governmental organization (NGO) to support, it is vital to pick one that (1) is committed to long-term development and not just short-term aid; (2) has strong accountability structures in place; (3) has enthusiastic local community support; and (4) uses funds effectively by hiring Haitians and stimulating the economy, rather than just paying foreigners to work in Haiti. FFP strongly emphasizes all four areas.

Here are some more reasons to trust FFP.

  • Every year, FFP hosts scores of volunteers, who visit Haiti personally and not only witness firsthand what FFP is doing, but also work side-by-side with Haitians on the construction site.  Accountability happens not just through paperwork but through firsthand participation.
  • FFP makes a concerted effort to hire and train Haitians whenever possible, so that salary money goes directly into the pockets of Haitians rather than of Americans working in Haiti.  While volunteers from the U.S. provide accountability and financial support, skilled Haitian laborers can accomplish the actual construction much more quickly and economically.
  • FFP has already been conducting language classes this past year, borrowing classroom space from another school. On October 13, 2012, we held an inauguration ceremony to celebrate the completion of the first-floor classrooms. Hundreds of members of the community showed up to demonstrate their support! So the school is already off to a running start.  Several organizations, such as Konekte, have already expressed interest in teaching future classes.
  • FFP has a track record of successful projects. See our website or YouTube for more information, or contact our Executive Director, Ken Culver, at <ken@foundationforpeace.org>.

 

FAQ: Do I need to create a PayPal account to donate?

No. You only need a credit card with a billing address. Go ahead and click on the "Contribute" button under "Complete your contribution via PayPal," but then just fill out the section "Pay with a credit or debit card" and uncheck the box labeled "Save this information with a PayPal account." Your credit-card payment will then be processed by PayPal without creating a PayPal account. Your contribution will be tax-deductible because FFP is a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization.

 

FAQ: Who is the girl in the photo at the top of this page?

Her name is Loudwich. Her mother died in the earthquake, and until recently, Loudwich was living in a tent in Ganthier with her aunt. Her aunt is an amazing woman who has helped with the construction of the Men Nan Men vocational school and has taught at the College Mixte Marius Carnold.

Haitians pride themselves on their resilience in the face of adversity. Imagine if you were in Loudwich’s position, an orphan living for a couple of years in a tent. Would you find anything to smile about? I don’t know about you, but I am humbled by Loudwich’s zest for life.

Supporting the Men Nan Men vocational school will help give the young people in Ganthier the job skills they need to build a better life for their children—children like Loudwich.

See our gallery for more photos of Loudwich.


FAQ: I can't donate money right now. Can I still help?

Yes! There are many other ways you can help us achieve our goals:

  • Spread the word about this campaign!  If you're on Facebook or Twitter, be sure to click the icons at the top of this page, just below the video. Just getting more people to visit this page will help us a lot.
  • Come to Haiti as a volunteer on one of our missions trips, or as an intern, and participate firsthand in rebuilding Haiti. Read more about internships on Chris's blog and Andrea's blog.
  • Volunteer in the United States by helping to pack containers of supplies to ship to Haiti, or sell craft items, or create health education materials.

 

FAQ: What are the plans for the long-term sustainability of the school?

If you have read this far,  you are probably seriously interested in development in Haiti and are aware that constructing a school building is relatively easy compared to the challenge of keeping the school running in the long term.  A building is a one-time cost but teacher salaries, school supplies, utilities, etc., are ongoing needs.  These pose significant challenges, but FFP is optimistic about long-term sustainability for the following reasons:

  • The language classes have been operating for two years already and have been sustainable with student fees alone, except for two volunteer teachers from the U.S. who have taught without pay.  So far there has been no shortage of U.S. teachers willing to teach, and partner organizations such as Konekte are committed to providing volunteers and raising funds for teacher salaries.
  • Since the opening of the first-floor classrooms, enrollment in the school has exceeded expectations.  The school is therefore getting more income than expected from student fees, allowing the school to expand and hire more teachers.
  • Once the second floor is complete, the school plans to offer classes in Haitian Creole targeted at American NGO workers in Haiti.  These classes are expected to turn a profit and to boster the financial stability of the school.

story:
http://speakupforthepoor.org/

 

 

Speak Up exists to transform the world on behalf of the poor.

Our mission is to build an international network of Justice Centers which speak up for the poor.

We seek to advocate for the poor in three inter-connected ways:

(1) HOMES: To catalyze and fund the growth of homes for girls born into brothels, rescued from trafficking, or otherwise at risk of exploitation and abuse. Our goal is to ensure that no girl anywhere in the world is forced into prostitution.

(2) EDUCATION: To run a Girls Education Program which sponsors girls in poverty to stay in school and on the path to success. Our goal is to transform the way the world thinks about poor girls, and to ensure that girls in poverty are free to live up to their fullest potential.

(3) JUSTICE: To investigate human rights abuses and do practical casework for the poor, and work with local authorities and law schools to train indigenous lawyers and advocates for the poor. Our goal is to build an international army of advocates for the poor who fight for justice through their local justice system.

Our work in pursuit of this mission will be characterized by these values:

COURAGE
We will courageously pursue our mission despite any cost, risk or opposition.

HUMILITY
We will serve the poor with humility and a spirit of servanthood, putting the needs of others before our own.

EXCELLENCE
We will speak up for the poor as a professional, first-class organization.

story:
Lichter Leven

Lichter leven; minder stress ervaren, van zorgen naar zorgeloosheid. Meer rust in je leven. Meer genieten van het leven.


Met de online cursus Lichter Leven wil ik zoveel mogelijk mensen inspireren tot het creëren van een luchtiger leven. Mijn wens is dat zoveel mogelijk mensen aanzienlijk minder stress gaan ervaren en zich juist relaxter en gelukkiger gaan voelen. 

Eerder bracht ik het boek 'Eigentijdse Wijsheden' uit. Een boek vol inspirerende gezegden op het gebied van lichter leven. Nu heb ik een complete cursus geschreven van 20 lessen, die je helpen op de weg naar zorgeloosheid. Het betreft een online te volgen cursusprogramma.

De inhoud van de cursus

Samengevat komen onderstaande onderwerpen tijdens de cursus aan bod:

  • Wat is lichter leven? Hoe kan het leven rustiger worden? Minder druk en chaotisch?
  • Stress, spanning en ontspanning. Breng jezelf weer tot rust.
  • Rust in je hoofd. Met zoveel bezig zijn dat het je duizelt. Steeds weer is de innerlijke criticus aan het woord. Maar nu is het tijd voor jou...
  • Focus en aandacht; is multitasken de uitvinding van de eeuw of is het juist een stressfactor?
  • Leven in het heden. Het leven vindt nu plaats, echt en alleen op dit moment.
  • Onthaasten; een stukje bezinning te midden van alle hectiek.
  • Verplichtingen, verwachtingen en keuzes.
  • Kiezen vanuit je hart en doen waar je gelukkig van wordt. Mooi gezegd, maar nu de praktijk...
  • Zachtheid; hoe streng zijn we voor onszelf? Op welke manieren kun je zachter zijn voor jezelf?
  • De toeschouwer; ben je de toneelspeler of het publiek? Wat betekenen die verschillende rollen?
  • Uit je eigen wereld stappen. Met frisse energie krijg je een andere kijk op de zaken...
  • Transformatie van negatief naar positief. Niet alleen qua denken, maar ook qua voelen en ervaren.
  • Meningen en oordelen; wat doet dat met ons?
  • Liefde & vergeving; verlicht je hart.
  • Een gevoel van geluk; hoe creëer je dat intense geluksgevoel.
  • Zorgeloosheid; hoe komt het dat we ons zo vaak zorgen maken en hoe kunnen we ze loslaten?
  • Leven en geleefd worden. Hoe kun je ervoor zorgen dat je niet geleefd wordt maar dat je kunt zeggen ‘ik leef!’?


Doe mee!

Om dit cursusprogramma daadwerkelijk te realiseren, wil ik je vragen me te helpen. Al vanaf € 10,- kun je meedoen! Natuurlijk krijg je daar een inspirerende reward voor! Dus kijk snel bij de rewards, kies jouw favoriet uit en doe mee.


Kosten en rewards

De kosten voor dit project bestaan uit:

- systemen voor de online leeromgeving;

- videocamera en toebehoren incl. software;

- marketingkosten.


Wat krijg je als deelnemer aan dit project?

Als deelnemer krijg je als eerste toegang tot deze unieke cursus! Natuurlijk zit daar ook een financieel voordeel aan. De prijs voor de cursus wordt € 99,-, maar jij krijgt nu al toegang voor € 50,-. 

Neem je deel voor een lager bedrag, dan ontvang je een leuke korting op de cursus en een bureaubladachtergrond voor je pc of tablet met een gezegde uit het boek 'Eigentijdse Wijsheden'. 

Neem je deel voor € 100,-, dan ontvang je 2x toegang tot de cursus, zodat je er ook nog eens iemand blij mee kunt maken. Bovendien ontvang je een exemplaar van het boek 'Eigentijdse Wijsheden' (per post thuisgestuurd) én je ontvangt een skype sessie van een half uur om nóg meer uit de cursus te halen.

Iedere deelnemer mag ervoor kiezen om op de website genoemd te worden op de speciale pagina 'mogelijk gemaakt door'. Heb je een bedrijf, dan kan hier ook je bedrijfsnaam genoemd worden.

Neem je deel voor een hoger bedrag dan € 100,-? Dan creëren we samen een reward op maat! Bedenk maar vast waar jij blij van wordt...

Wordt het doelbedrag van dit project overschreden, dan wordt van dat bedrag de tweede cursus ontwikkeld...

Steun dit project!
Deel dit project gerust in je netwerk. Je helpt me daar enorm mee!

Over mijzelf:
Nadat ik door een val van mijn paard hersenletsel opliep, kwam ik terecht in een langdurige periode van herstel. Deze periode heeft me geleerd om mezelf een spiegel voor te houden en me te ontwikkelen, tot een lichter mens ;).
De lessen die ik in deze periode leerde, vertaalde ik naar moderne gezegden en zo ontstond het boek 'Eigentijdse Wijsheden'. Ik wil graag mensen inspireren tot een luchtiger leven en zo ontstond dan ook het idee om online cursusprogramma's te ontwikkelen. Ik ben gestart met Inspired by Life en wil met dit project de eerste cursus realiseren.
story_txt:
Lichter Leven
Lichter leven; minder stress ervaren, van zorgen naar zorgeloosheid. Meer rust in je leven. Meer genieten van het leven.

Met de online cursus Lichter Leven wil ik zoveel mogelijk mensen inspireren tot het creëren van een luchtiger leven. Mijn wens is dat zoveel mogelijk mensen aanzienlijk minder stress gaan ervaren en zich juist relaxter en gelukkiger gaan voelen. 

Eerder bracht ik het boek 'Eigentijdse Wijsheden' uit. Een boek vol inspirerende gezegden op het gebied van lichter leven. Nu heb ik een complete cursus geschreven van 20 lessen, die je helpen op de weg naar zorgeloosheid. Het betreft een online te volgen cursusprogramma.




De inhoud van de cursus
Samengevat komen onderstaande onderwerpen tijdens de cursus aan bod:




Wat is lichter leven? Hoe kan het leven rustiger worden? Minder druk en chaotisch?
Stress, spanning en ontspanning. Breng jezelf weer tot rust.
Rust in je hoofd. Met zoveel bezig zijn dat het je duizelt. Steeds weer is de innerlijke criticus aan het woord. Maar nu is het tijd voor jou...
Focus en aandacht; is multitasken de uitvinding van de eeuw of is het juist een stressfactor?

Verplichtingen, verwachtingen en keuzes.

Zachtheid; hoe streng zijn we voor onszelf? Op welke manieren kun je zachter zijn voor jezelf?

Uit je eigen wereld stappen. Met frisse energie krijg je een andere kijk op de zaken...
Transformatie van negatief naar positief. Niet alleen qua denken, maar ook qua voelen en ervaren.
Meningen en oordelen; wat doet dat met ons?

Een gevoel van geluk; hoe creëer je dat intense geluksgevoel.
Zorgeloosheid; hoe komt het dat we ons zo vaak zorgen maken en hoe kunnen we ze loslaten?

Bedenk maar vast waar jij blij van wordt...Wordt het doelbedrag van dit project overschreden, dan wordt van dat bedrag de tweede cursus ontwikkeld...Steun dit project!Deel dit project gerust in je netwerk. story:
Coastside Child Development Center (CCDC) is a:

  • Private, non-profit 501(c)(3) program founded in 1978, committed to providing high-quality child care, education, social-emotional support, and early intervention services to children ages 0 to 5.
  • Program that is based on the best of child development practices whose mission is to foster healthy development of children – especially children most at risk.
  • Place of early learning and development where children can feel safe, respected, confident, curious, and eager and excited to learn.

At Coastside Child Development Center we understand that getting ready for the future begins at birth. The first 5 years lay a foundation that influences the effectiveness of all subsequent educational efforts and is a period of incredible growth in all areas of a child’s development. We also understand the importance of the balance between cognitive and literacy skills for children with comparable attention to the emotional and social development of children. We believe that all children are entitled to an environment in which they can develop to their maximum potential and we are committed to giving families access to our services regardless of background or income.

What We Need

Coastside Child Development Center will need to raise $5,000 to help pay for a new playground.

 The playground will include:

  • A climbing structure from Miracle Recreation Equipment Company

  • Shade trees
  • Shade structure
  • Therapeutic play area that will support social, self-regulation, and relaxation skills.

Your contribution will be fully tax deductible as Coastside Child Development Center is a registered 501(c)(3) organization.

story:
Humanity’s Team is an international spiritual movement dedicated to promoting the understanding and application of Oneness for the purpose of advancing a mature and compassionate global humanity. With members in over one hundred and fifty countries, Humanity’s Team (HT) - a top rated non-profit organisation undertakes its mission by developing awareness-building campaigns, educational events, transformational programs and community and global outreach. Humanity's Team is a tax-exempt organization in the United States under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. Federal Tax ID: 86-1088741. Your donation is tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The volunteer spirit…

We’re volunteers with HT as we see the dialogue on Oneness as an important opportunity for us as one human family, which values human life, to acknowledge that our governments and political frameworks do not have all the answers. We encourage religious communities to probe deeper into how Oneness utilizes faith positively and to encourage each person to be kinder, gentler, more giving and generous to their neighbours.  We are a community of global volunteers because we passionately believe in encouraging a sense of responsibility so deep and profound that it shifts and lifts all pockets of humanity to a better place of being together and that Oneness is the one missing piece in a complex jigsaw that will provide sustainable peace.

Global Oneness Day – growing multifold and making a difference

In 2010 HT held an audience with the United Nations to endorse formal recognition of a “Global Oneness Day” (G1D) to which they were invited to lead and build the infrastructure, framework and support. G1D emulates partnership between individuals, politicians and organisations to work at scale increasing knowledge and awareness of what it means to live in Oneness. The first event saw 1,000 people participate in recognizing humanity’s most innate natural relationship and 2012 only its 3rd year witnessed an exponential growth to over 25,000.  In 2013 registrations increased to over 40,000 and total participation in Global Oneness Day jumped to over 100,000 since the inaugural year in 2010.

What We Need & What You Get

For the last decade the success of Humanitys Team (HT) has been built by its members, all of whom are dedicated volunteers who participate in building a better world for current and future generations.  HT volunteers work unpaid daily to stay engaged and committed to thousands of people worldwide (our monthly estimate of volunteer contributions is equivalent to the monetary amount of $1,000,000) and we run more than fifty global projects worldwide.  Interest in our global good works on the ground to those in need of service and our focus on Oneness, has grown to attract over 100,000 with supporters in over 150 countries.

As HT grows to a more prominent place of activity and influence we are seriously in need of funding for efficient technical infrastructure, professional marketing campaigns, and the quintessential basic yet incredibly necessary resources to keep going from strength to strength. Your funding directly:

1) Helps us sustain fast growing functions of Humanity’s Team such as educational outreach, creating personal tools for development, coordination between country and global level programs and building knowledge within communities.

2) Supports volunteers to continue local outreach activities and run on the ground Oneness projects. Regular projects include HT sponsored food drives, disaster recovery to support leaders who have lost everything, humanitarian projects including distributing blankets and funds to the poor, environmental projects, global meditations and more.

3) Build the fifth Global Oneness Day on Friday 24th October 2014 and helps us spread the word about what we are doing and how it makes a difference.  We’ve cumulatively reached 100,000 people since the launch of Global Oneness Day in 2010.  Help us stretch to 100,000 new registrants in 2014.

4) Supports the evolution of a Oneness Digital Campaign to help us expand and deliver messages of Oneness to religious and faith institutions, local politicians, organizations, communities and individuals.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need all the help you can offer, HT is a decisive movement which acts, influences and shapes the face of the planet. If you are unable to financially contribute here are a few examples of how we will value your help:

- Commit your name to the Oneness Declaration and help us reach our target of 100,000 names. The declaration is super important in having a Global Oneness Day recognised in all calendars of the world - adding your name is a step toward turning this dream into a reality: http://humanitysteam.org/sai/oneness-petition/document 

- Share the above Oneness Declaration with at least five other people and networks; ask them to help spread the word about this different and important initiative.

- Say hi here on our Indiegogo dashboard and let us know you support our work; we’d love to hear from you and if you’d like to be involved with HT as a volunteer just say the word!

- As a grassroots movement our volunteers are working hard to get us heard.  Join our energy by liking and connecting with us on Facebook, following us on Twitter, sign up our newsletters, join us on our calls, use the Indiegogo tools for sharing our work, participate with us on Global Oneness Day (oh yes, we’d really love you too!)– there is so much you can do!

Lastly, we are super truly grateful for your contribution and hope you will enjoy all the fantastic perks on offer. Thank YOU so much!

story:
Nobody can choose where to be born.

If you were born in Malaysia, USA, Ecuador, Kuwait, South Korea, Equatorial Guinea or even Norway, you had no control over it. So neither does anybody else in the world.

Why should somebody be judged by his/her nationality?

This was our question too. We saw many cases of discrimination based on nationality and "education discrimination" is one of their worst. 

How did it all happen?

Since mid. 2013 and especially after the new conservative minority government formed by the Conservative Party and the Progress Party and took the office, the Norwegian authorities set practices to restrict Iranian students and skilled workers based on domestic export control laws and international sanctions against Iran. 

The universities were instructed to be very conservative about admitting Iranian students and the Norwegian Directorate of Immigration (UDI) was instructed by the authorities to refuse the visa issuance and renewal applications of many Iranian students based on the same reason, even for those who are already in Norway and have studied and worked for few months/years. A letter from the Ministry of Education and Research (here) shows that the academic institutions are explicitly warned about Iranian students. 

carton by Morteza Khosravi


Why do they do this to us?

By these decisions the Norwegian authorities and especially the Police Security Service (PST) claim to abide by UN resolutions and domestic export control law. According to these laws, they are expected to be cautions with respect to the provision of sensitive information proliferation especially regarding the WMD risk to Iran.

-Are the sanctions something new?

+No. They are more than 6 years old.

-Is Norway the only member of the United Nations?

+No.

-Is there anything in those laws concerning Iranian ordinary students abroad?

+No.

-Are the expelled students proven to be linked to any Iranian projects?

+No.

-Have they committed anything wrong? Have been tried or persecuted ever?

+No.

-Are Iranian students and graduates in Norway very keen to go back to Iran?

-No. A statistical study shows that more than 90% get a relevant job and stay in Norway.

-Are the restrictions only for specific majors like military/nuclear related fields?

+Not really. According to Norwegian media it is a long list of majors that Norwegian Security Police Service expressed concerns about:

  • Electronics 
  • Information Technology 
  • Chemistry 
  • Biology 
  • Physics 
  • Mathematics 
  • Space technology 
  • Construction 
  • Materials Science 
  • Metallurgy 
  • Mechatronics 
  • Veterinary Studies 
  • Oil and Gas
-Even mathematics is "forbidden" for Iranians?

+Yes.

-BTW, is Maryam Mirzakhani an Iranian mathematician working in the United States?

+Yes. And it is good she did not come to Norway since she might not be the first woman ever to win the prestigious Fields Medal otherwise.

Did it really happen?

Unfortunately, yes. We could not believe it in the beginning. It was so shocking that in 21st century, a student/skilled worker could be deprived from studying and in some cases expelled from a country for the sole reason of his/her nationality. But it really happened in Norway. Mahdi Ghane was expelled from Norway. His supervisor who was obviously happy with him and other Iranian researchers, was totally surprised. Mahdi got another research position in Australia. Siavash Chaeikar was also rejected by UDI for his resident permit application in Norway and then got a research position in Sweden.

What did we do to rectify the situation in Norway?

What we did was to start this campaign called SEDAI which stands for Stop Education Discrimination Against Iranians.

The campaign started in May 2014 and ever since:

  • Many academicians have protested the decision. 
  • The story has been covered in Norwegian, Swedish, Belgian, British, Iranian, American, Finnish, Spanish, Chinese and Danish media many times.
  • NTNU, the most prestigious technical university in Norway has supported the rejected students and appealed the UDI decisions.
  • Many academicians and academic institutions have supported the campaign.
  • On 12th June, 2014 a nation-wide protest was successfully organized by SEDAI all over Norway and in main academic cities; Trondheim, Oslo, Bergen, Stavanger and Narvik and also in the capital city of Finland, Helsinki.


  • On August 20th, 2014 the petition signed by around 13000 people in Norway and around the world was submitted to the Norwegian government and parliament.


What is the situation now?

Some of the students and skilled workers whose resident permit application were denied by UDI and PST due to the fear of sensitive knowledge transfer, were finally successful in their appeals, but this was not the case for all like PhD student Hamideh Kaffash who was working on reduction of CO2 emission.

Also there is no good news for those Iranian-born who are living in Norway and were deprived from the right of education explicitly due to their nationality like Mahtab Emamy. In brief, there were some good signs after the campaign but the unfair regulations targeting Iranian-born students have not been changed. 

What should we do now?

We are left with no option but to keep organizing "popular protests to make the public aware of what is going on" and to take necessary legal actions. So far everything in this campaign has been performed on cooperation spirit and volunteer-basis. But not everybody is volunteer, especially lawyers.

Who are supporting us?

Professor Noam Chomsky:

And many other prestigious academic and public figures and also academic institutions:

What do we want from you?

We would like to ask for your generous donation to:
  • organize popular protests
  • take necessary legal actions

Why 20000 USD?

This is almost 125000 NOK and is an underestimated amount based on a rough clue from some skilled lawyers in Norway. The cost for the judicial follow-up for different cases that might be funded by us together with all administration fees and the cost for organizing popular protests will exceed this. But we would like to start with funding the cases that can benefit all and potentially change the unfair regulations anyways and here is the starting point. The way it works is that SEDAI gathers all the donation and the affected people will apply for the fund directly. The more beneficial for everybody their cases are, the more chance to get funded. If there is no individual case to be supported, the unfair regulations themselves will be targeted with help of lawyers. 
According to lawyers, we may need to bring up the cases to the Norwegian Supreme Court or even European court at some points and the estimation will be a little different, but for the time being the breakdown of the costs could be as following:

1- First of all, Indiegogo (or any other similar services) will charge us for using the service by 4% of the total sum If we reach the goal, and if not 9% of the accumulated money will be taken. So it is very important and much cheaper to reach to the target which is 20000 USD now.

2- Then it is the fee for credit cards handlers, between 3-5% depending on the currency and place and also wire fee as a fixed cost. There is also fee applicable for exchange rate to other currencies than USD.

3- The fee for bringing up a case to a Norwegian court is estimated to be at least 25000 NOK per day of court. If there are more than one day, it will be multiplied by the number of days required per case and there is also a chance to merge some days in case of similarities between the files. 

4- The wage for the lawyer itself is another story. It can be easily up to 100000 NOK per case.

5- The cost for witnesses to show up in the court and all the travel expenses associated with the cases should be added separately.

What if we do not need to go to the court for individual cases?
If such good news come true that all the current cases (Kaffash, Emamy, etc) receive a proper answer and a  fair treatment, we still need to make sure that the unjustified regulations are changed and this will be funded from the donations.
Now imagine that the regulations are also changed without spending all the money accumulated. Having the consent of donors; we will donate to similar anti-discrimination activities in Norway or around the world. If a donor was not happy with that, he/she will be refunded after the applicable deduction due to transaction and administration fee. 

Support us now!

It is not easy to change decisions made by highest authorities in a country. It is also painful to lose opportunities, time and money because you are invited by university and expelled by security police, but It is even more painful to be deprived from education.
If you also think that this is unfair, help us to make a difference. Together we can change this course towards a dream zero-discrimination world.

If you were born in Malaysia, USA, Ecuador, Kuwait, South Korea, Equatorial Guinea or even Norway, you had no control over it. So neither does anybody else in the world.Why should somebody be judged by his/her nationality? 
This was our question too. We saw many cases of discrimination based on nationality and "education discrimination" is one of their worst. 

How did it all happen? Since mid. 2013 and especially after the new conservative minority government formed by the Conservative Party and the Progress Party and took the office, the Norwegian authorities set
practices to restrict Iranian students and skilled workers based on domestic
export control laws and international sanctions against Iran. 
The universities were instructed to be very
conservative about admitting Iranian students and the Norwegian Directorate of Immigration (UDI) was instructed by the authorities to refuse the visa
issuance and renewal applications of many Iranian students based on the same
reason, even for those who are already in Norway and have studied and worked for few months/years. A letter from the Ministry of Education and
Research (here)
shows that the academic institutions are explicitly warned about Iranian
students. 



carton by Morteza Khosravi




Why do they do this to us? 
By these decisions the Norwegian authorities
and especially the Police Security Service (PST) claim to abide by UN
resolutions and domestic export control law. According to these laws, they are expected to
be cautions with respect to the provision of sensitive information proliferation
especially regarding the WMD risk to Iran.
-Are the sanctions something new?
+No. They are more than 6 years old.
-Is Norway the only member of the United Nations?
+No.
-Is there anything in those laws concerning Iranian ordinary students abroad?
+No.-Are the expelled students proven to be linked to any Iranian projects?
+No.
-Have they committed anything wrong? Have been tried or persecuted ever?
+No.
-Are Iranian students and graduates in Norway very keen to go back to Iran?
-No. A statistical study shows that more than 90% get a relevant job and stay in Norway.
-Are the restrictions only for specific majors like military/nuclear related fields?
+Not really. According to Norwegian media it is a long list of majors that Norwegian
Security Police Service expressed concerns about: 



Electronics 
Information Technology 
Chemistry 
Biology 
Physics 
Mathematics 
Space technology 
Construction 
Materials Science 
Metallurgy 
Mechatronics 
Veterinary Studies 
Oil and Gas


-Even mathematics is "forbidden" for Iranians?
+Yes.
-BTW, is Maryam Mirzakhani an Iranian mathematician working in the United States?
+Yes. And it is good she did not come to Norway since she might not be the first woman ever to win the prestigious Fields Medal otherwise.
Did it really happen?
Unfortunately, yes. We could not believe it in the beginning. It was so shocking that in 21st 
century, a student/skilled worker could be deprived from studying and in some cases 
expelled from a country for the sole reason of his/her nationality. But 
it really happened in Norway. Mahdi Ghane was expelled from Norway. His supervisor who was obviously happy with him and other Iranian researchers, was totally surprised. Mahdi got another research position in Australia. Siavash Chaeikar was also rejected by UDI for his resident permit application in Norway and then got a research position in Sweden.
What did we do to rectify the situation in Norway?
What we did was to start this campaign called SEDAI which stands for Stop Education Discrimination Against Iranians.The campaign started in May 2014 and ever since:

Many academicians have protested the decision. 
The story has been covered in Norwegian, Swedish, Belgian, British, Iranian, American, Finnish, Spanish, Chinese




and Danish media many times.

NTNU, the most prestigious technical university in Norway has supported the rejected students and appealed the UDI decisions.

Many academicians and academic institutions have supported the campaign.

On 12th June, 2014 a nation-wide protest was successfully organized by SEDAI all over Norway and in main academic cities; Trondheim, Oslo, Bergen, Stavanger and Narvik and also in the capital city of Finland, Helsinki.



On August 20th, 2014 the petition signed by around 13000 people in Norway and around the world was submitted to the Norwegian government and parliament.

  

What is the situation now?

Some of the students and skilled workers whose resident permit application were denied by UDI and PST due to the fear of sensitive knowledge transfer, were finally successful in their appeals, but this was not the case for all like PhD student Hamideh Kaffash who was working on reduction of CO2 emission.
Also there is no good news for those Iranian-born who are living in Norway and were deprived from the right of education explicitly due to their nationality like Mahtab Emamy. In brief, there were some good signs after the campaign but the unfair regulations targeting Iranian-born students have not been changed.  
What should we do now?
We are left with no option but to keep organizing "popular protests to make the public aware of what is going on" and to take necessary legal actions. So far everything in this campaign has been performed on cooperation spirit and volunteer-basis. But not everybody is volunteer, especially lawyers.

Who are supporting us?
Professor Noam Chomsky:
And many other prestigious academic and public figures and also academic institutions:



What do we want from you?
We would like to ask for your generous donation to:


organize popular protests


take necessary legal actions





Why 20000 USD?
This is almost 125000 NOK and is an underestimated amount based on a rough clue from some skilled lawyers in Norway. The cost for the judicial follow-up for different cases that might be funded by us together with all administration fees and the cost for organizing popular protests will exceed this. But we would like to start with funding the cases that can benefit all and potentially change the unfair regulations anyways and here is the starting point. The way it works is that SEDAI gathers all the donation and the affected people will apply for the fund directly. The more beneficial for everybody their cases are, the more chance to get funded. If there is no individual case to be supported, the unfair regulations themselves will be targeted with help of lawyers. 
According to lawyers, we may need to bring up the cases to the Norwegian Supreme Court or even European court at some points and the estimation will be a little different, but for the time being the breakdown of the costs could be as following:

1- First of all, Indiegogo (or any other similar services) will charge us for using the service by 4% of the total sum If we reach the goal, and if not 9% of the accumulated money will be taken. So it is very important and much cheaper to reach to the target which is 20000 USD now.


2- Then it is the fee for credit cards handlers, between 3-5% depending on the currency and place and also wire fee as a fixed cost. There is also fee applicable for exchange rate to other currencies than USD.


3- The fee for bringing up a case to a Norwegian court is estimated to be at least 25000 NOK per day of court. If there are more than one day, it will be multiplied by the number of days required per case and there is also a chance to merge some days in case of similarities between the files. 

4- The wage for the lawyer itself is another story. It can be easily up to 100000 NOK per case.

5- The cost for witnesses to show up in the court and all the travel expenses associated with the cases should be added separately.


What if we do not need to go to the court
for individual cases?

If
such good news come true that all the current cases (Kaffash, Emamy, etc)
receive a proper answer and a  fair
treatment, we still need to make sure that the unjustified regulations are
changed and this will be funded from the donations.
Now imagine that the regulations are also changed without spending all the money accumulated. Having the consent of donors; we will donate to similar anti-discrimination activities in Norway or around the world. If a donor was not happy with that, he/she will be refunded after the applicable deduction due to transaction and administration fee. 



Support us now!

It is not easy to change decisions made by highest authorities in a country. It is also painful to lose opportunities, time and money because you are invited by university and expelled by security police, but It is even more painful to be deprived from education.If you also think that this is unfair, help us to make a difference. Together we can change this course towards a dream zero-discrimination world.

story:
Please help Wizard.

He is a lovable friendly lion head rabbit that is part of my family. We rescued him from the shelter and fell in love. He is three years old, litter trained and roams our first floor. Wizard somehow when we weren't home, broke his front foot in his cage. He probably got startled by a noise and freaked out. I have children and I need to show them responsibility. Wizard severely displaced and broke his front foot. He now needs surgery, splinting his foot wouldn't work because of how he broke it. If it wasn't displaced the outcome would have been different. Please help Wizard he is a family pet that is loved so much.  Even if you contribute a $1.00 anything counts and thank you.

story:
Face it guys, if it weren’t for Kevin Lee and Joe Shanahan, our collective experience as fathers, literary scholars, aficionados of music and, maybe even beer, would be much less complete than it is now.

The sense of community that has brought us together can be credited, to a large degree, to these two Dads.  Many of us would never have met were it not for the gin joints, volunteer events and music halls these two have dragged us to. 

Kevin brought us Book Club the first Tuesday of every month. Joe made the annual Talent Night at Metro an event like no other. In appreciation of the sense of community they’ve helped create, we thought a fitting gesture would be to pass the hat, and make a donation to a cause, near and dear to both Kevin and Joe. 

Our plan is to ask all of you to consider donating to the fund that helps send underprivileged students on school sponsored trips, like Space Camp, and Washington D.C.   We aim low, with suggested contributions wherever you feel comfortable ($25, $100, or that used Lamborghini SUV that’s been taking up a garage space), and our deadline is May 31. 

We’d like to present a gift in their honor graduation weekend--and this scholarship happens to be the one associated with Angel Brunch this year. Joe and Kevin both have their youngest children graduating this year. They'll already be balling their eyes out at Angel Brunch. Let's make it even more poignant as we recognize them in a way they'll never forget.

Please keep this secret, and know that this is not an appeal from The Academy of the Sacred Heart or Hardey Prep. It's from all of us. 

As important as the dollars contributed, if not more so, is the number of contributors. There is no greater recognition than that from your peers.  Thanks, and Cheers! 

John Ahearne
JAhearne@rwbaird.com
312-375-7774

Rob Topping
rob.topping@vintox.com
847-563-8218

Jeff Walker
Jeff@ContentCarnivores.com
312-286-9934

story:
L. Hollingworth School for the Talented and Gifted Washington DC Trip

Short Summary

Our names are Aaron Walston and Kerry Horrigan. We both work for L. Hollingworth School for the Talented and Gifted in Toledo, Ohio. L. Hollingworth is a charter school that was opened four years ago to challenge the minds of students in the neighborhood. Our mission statement believes that intelligence plus character is the true goal of education. We strive to guide individual students to maximize their full, intellectual potential.

Our 8th grade consists of nine students. Yes, nine. We have a very small class and unfortunately this greatly affects the cost of each student for our trip. Going door to door is not an option for these students due to the unsafe nature of the area. Our school has a 93% poverty rate which makes it difficult to raise funds. Parents have informed Mrs. Horrigan and myself that they will be unable to help pay for this field trip. This would be a very unfortunate event if a student had to be left behind due to lack of funds.

We chose Washington DC because of the historical importance to our country. Some of our 8th graders have never ventured outside of the state of Ohio. We would like to change this with an educational trip that will be remembered forever.

Please help us with a successful Washington DC field trip.

What We Need

For our trip, we are in need of roughly $13,000 total. We are asking for $10,000 and will find other means for the rest. The money will be divided evenly between the students. This trip will be all inclusive for everyone. We decided to go with a company that designs and coordinates an entire trip including: transportation, lodging, food, and tours.

If our goal is not met, we will be using the money for a closer field trip to the local government buildings. Any remaining funds will be used for the next year's 8th grade Washington DC trip.

Meet the Students

Victor's favorite subject in school is science. It doesn't matter what sub-topic, just as long it is science. He is very interested in the Smithsonian museums to learn more about the history of our world. Victor's future plans are to go to The Ohio State University.

Miguel is part of a family with 11 brothers and sisters. He is a role model for all of his siblings. He enjoys playing basketball with is brothers and teaching them the fundamentals. He has been very interested in The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and would like to visit it.

Jessica is a girl who loves to read. One of her favorite pastimes is reading Diary of a Wimpy Kid. She plans on going to the University of Toledo after high school. Jessica is looking forward to learning about the politicians and how they affect the county.

Mercedez is looking forward to learning about the history of Washington DC even though her favorite subject is math. Mercedez plans on going to The Ohio State University after high school.

Cameron is a very bright individual. His love is computers and programing. He would like to go to ITT Technical Institute of Technology and become a computer programmer. He is looking forward to the once-in-a-lifetime experience of going to Washington DC.

Andrea is very artistic. She loves to read and write graphic novels. Her goal is to eventually go to a school for technology and design and create video games. Andrea is looking forward to Washington DC because she would like to learn more about our country's history.

Alyssa is aware of her education and takes it very seriously. Alyssa would like to become a beautician after high school and possible open her own salon. She would also like to go to Bowling Green State University for buisness.

Fidel is a typical teenage boy. He likes to play sports in his free time with his siblings and friends. His favorite subject is science and would like to go to Bowling Green State University for science.

Jordan's favorite subjects in school are math and science. Jordan would like to attend Harvard University and become an attorney.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help at this time, please send this campaign to anyone you think can. Image us celebrating with a "woo-hoo" for every person you send this to.

story:
Short Summary

Mr. Peter was born in South Sudan, and grew up in Bor Village, South Sudan until he was 12 years old. He was orphaned at an early age, his mother dying without warning and his beloved father having passed away when he was five. He lived with his two sisters and his aunts. Things were good for a while but he still missed the care that only his parents could offer him had they lived. His sisters got married, leaving him to remain under the care of relatives and his life became a nightmare. His life at that time was no different than the life of a homeless person. Having both parents gone, his basic childhood needs went unmet and he was neglected. To turn his life around, he sat down one morning on the street curb thinking about where his life was going while watching the kids who have parents going to the local school Konberk, just 10 minutes away from his uncle home. 
 

Mr. Peter became an orphan fully at age five, and since then he have been struggling for a better life for himself. At that time, he had a dream that he would one day bring changes to his people who are desperately in need of help. Having experienced the tough life of being an orphan has encouraged him to form New Sudan Jonglei Orphans Foundation to raise money and help the orphaned children of Jonglei. “Twenty years ago this was about me but what I say or do today with NSJOF is not about me it is about the orphans who are going through what I went through.” Said Peter. Peter is using the book to raise the awarness about the suffering of orphans in South Sudan. 

What We Need & What You Get

When you contribute $50-$100 you will received handwritten thank you letter and the copy of Lost Generation The Story of a Sudanese Orphan by Peter Garang Deng 

1. I need $4,000 to be able to print many copies of Lost Generation The Story of a Sudanese Orphan. So that I can have enough book to sell during my tour throughout Northeast part of USA. 

2. Helping another human being is one of the most important thing that all of us should. Orphans are suffering and I want to change their lives for better

3. If I don't reach my entire goal the funds will go to New Sudan Jonglei Orphans Foundation and will be used to payoff school fee for orphans that are now in the program.

The Impact

Orphan kids are the most vulnerable in the world for they have no parents providing them with basic care or childhood needs. The Lost Generation project is very unique in the way that all the sales from the book is used toward orphans education.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone have money to give, if that the case with you there are many other ways you can help us  and below are the some of the ways you can help:

1. Ask your friends, relatives, family or coworker to help, 

2. Share the indiegogo campaign to your friends on twitter and facebook and other social network.

Learn more at www.nsjof.org
